PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Michael Beahan) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Public Service: Higher Duties
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned federal Public Servants respectfully submit that:

The introduction of a Public Service Act regulation removing appeals against higher duties of 12 months or less has the potential to undermine the principle of selection on merit and the principle of an apolitical public service and lead to staffing decisions based on patronage and favouritism.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate should:
Disallow the Public Service Act regulation removing the aforesaid appeal right.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Michael Baume (from 71 citizens), Senator Childs (from 121 citizens), Senator Colston (from 90 citizens), Senator Kemp (from 33 citizens) and Senator Troeth (from 32 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: East Timor
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the undersigned draws to the attention of the Senate Indonesia's continued denial of human rights to the people of East Timor.
Your Petitioners ask the Senate to call on the Australian Government to:
1. actively support all United Nations resolutions and initiatives on East Timor;
2. actively support the right to self-determination of the people of East Timor;
3. work for the immediate release of all Timorese political prisoners;
4. repeal the Timor Gap Treaty; and
5. stop all military cooperation and commercial military activity with Indonesia.

PETITION.TITLE: Census
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned shows:
That the current practice of destroying the Census is denying future generations an invaluable and irreplaceable resource of data on medical, historical, social, scientific, and demographic factors.
Your Petitioners request that the Senate should:

Request the Government to review its current policy of destroying the Census; and support a proposal to retain the census forms for release for specific research purposes in either 70 or 100 years time.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Guide
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

PETITION.PARA: 1.We are opposed to the sex guide endorsed by Ms Lawrence, Minister for Health in the Keating Government, and published in the December issue of Cleo.
2.We believe that the sex guide encourages dangerous sexual practices which could have serious medical and moral effects.

PARA.TAB: We request the Senate to call on Ms Lawrence to withdraw her endorsement of this sex guide and for the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, to indicate his disapproval.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Landmines
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the undersigned shows that we are;

disturbed by the fact that every month between 600 and 1200 people (most of them civilians) are killed or maimed by landmines, and their health and maintenance costs are being incurred in countries with insufficient resources to meet the most basic needs of all their people,

concerned that the cost of clearing and de-activating of landmines is one hundred times the financial cost of manufacture, and the human cost is being borne by people who have suffered displacement, war, tribulation and hunger,

and we are greatly concerned that there remains between 85 and 100 million unexploded mines scattered over 62 different countries, inhibiting the ordinary movement of civilians and the farming of fields as people return to their former homes as wars cease.
Your Petitioners request that the Senate should:
ensure that the overseas aid budget contains a substantial allocation for de-mining training programs,
ensure that Australian Government delegations to International fora persuade more countries to become party to, and gratify, the Inhumane Weapons Convention

ensure that Australian Government delegations to International fora promote and support an amendment to Article 6 of Protocol II to prohibit the use, development, production, stockpiling and transfer of landmines.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Care
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Senators in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows: the unjust and inequitable nature of the Government's policy to restrict Childcare Assistance where a parent is outside the workforce to 12 hours per week. This policy will cause hardship to lower income families, to the children of those families, and child care workers. The Government should be condemned for breaking its promise to ensure access and affordability in child care.

Under the Government's policy parents will have to pay full cost fees after 12 hours of childcare per week if one parent is outside the workforce. This will widen the gap between rich and poor, and many child care workers may lose their jobs.
Your petitioners therefore ask that the Senate should oppose the passage of this Bill into law.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to amend general business notice motion No. 1862 standing in my name.
—Is leave granted?
—I am happy to listen to what Senator Baume has to say; so leave is granted.
—I thank the minister. The amendment is to the last paragraph of the motion. The amended motion reads:

PARA.TAB: That—

SPEECH.PARA: (a)the Senate notes:

PARA.TAB: (i)the statement by the Chairman of the National Gallery of Australia, the Hon. Lionel Bowen, reported in the Australian, that the panel he chaired to select a successor to Ms Betty Churcher on her retirement as Gallery Director had conveyed its unanimous choice of Mr Michael Lloyd to the Department of Communications and the Arts in August 1995, and

(ii)the claim by the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Mr Lee) that his department had not passed the recommendation on to him, so that he did not reject the unanimous recommendation to appoint Mr Lloyd when he decided to reappoint Ms Churcher for a further year; and

SPEECH.PARA: (b)there be laid on the table, by the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator McMullan), immediately after questions and motions to take note of answers to questions, on 13 November 1995, all relevant documents relating to the failure to appoint Mr Lloyd and the reappointment of Ms Churcher, including any requests by the Minister to the department not to be officially advised of the selection committee's unanimous recommendation and any advice or recommendations on this matter from the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) or his department.
I ask that this motion be taken as formal.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is there any objection to the motion as amended being taken as formal?

—by leave—In relation to the amended motion of Senator Baume, at the whips' meeting last night it was agreed that the matter be postponed because there was no request to have the matter declared formal. The procedure is that we normally ask that you notify the whips of all the parties and when that is done it is raised at the meeting and it is declared formal.

—by leave—Senator Jones is somewhat correct. What I said at the whips' meeting last night was that I would speak to Senator Baume and see what his thoughts were. I did not fully agree that it was going to be deferred. I do not think anyone can say that. Anyhow, it can be sorted out.
—by leave—I understand that situation. Unfortunately, I was not in a position last night to advise our whip of the state of this motion. Could I relieve the situation by moving another motion?
—The easiest way is to postpone it until it can be sorted out.
—by leave—I suggest that during the day we sort it out and come to some agreement. Perhaps Senator Baume could postpone it until a later hour this day when we can deal with it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because it is an issue which is controversial, pursuant to contingent notice standing in the name of the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Hill), I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Baume moving a motion relating to the conduct of the business of the Senate, namely a motion to give precedence to General Business notice of motion No. 1862 standing in the name of Senator Baume for this day, relating to an order for the production of documents by the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator McMullan).

SPEECH.PARA: I do that because this is a matter of significant controversy. This is a matter which has received enormous publicity. This is a matter which does not go in any way to the capacity, talent, skill, or enormous achievements of Mrs Churcher, who has been reappointed as Director of the National Gallery of Australia.

PARA.TAB: This goes to the credibility of the government, the credibility of the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Mr Lee) and the credibility of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in the sense that they have interfered in the selection process in a way that has damaged Australia's standing in the art world. That is not simply my judgment: that is the judgment of many people, some of whom have been quoted in newspaper reports. Editorials have been prompted on the unfortunate nature of the ministerial intervention.

It is clear, and has never been denied, that the selection panel appointed to find a new Director of the National Gallery of Australia on the retirement of Mrs Churcher at age 65 unanimously recommended Mr Lloyd. The Hon. Lionel Bowen, a former Labor Deputy Prime Minister of Australia, was chairman of that committee. The minister chose to ignore the recommendation. He says he never received that recommendation. Quite frankly, that may be the official truth but the unofficial lie because he asked not to be given that recommendation and so the department did not pass it on to him.

This is an incredible situation. It is incredible on lots of scores. I and Senator Chapman have moved in this place amendments to various acts, including, I might say, the National Gallery Act, relating to the age limit of 65. In other words, had our amendments been passed, then this issue may never have arisen. But it has arisen and the fact is that a selection committee found unanimously that Mr Lloyd should be made the director.

I have no comment, and I do not wish to comment, on whether that was a good or bad recommendation. What concerns me is the manner in which this government intervened in this process. It is all very well to say it is up to the minister to make the appointment. But we had a unanimous recommendation by a selection panel—in this case, as I said, chaired by a former Deputy Prime Minister of this country—which was ignored, which was treated with contempt and which has damaged the status of Mr Lloyd. What sort of position is he in now? Unanimously recommended, but unacceptable to this government.

What we need to know, what this Senate needs to know and what the Australian people need to know—certainly evidenced from the volume of press interest and correspondence to the editor—is exactly what happened. Did the minister advise the department not to give him the unanimous recommendation of the selection panel? If not, why did the department choose not to give it to him? What have the minister and the department got to hide?

Perhaps even more significant, we all know that the Prime Minister of this nation likes to dabble in things artistic—certainly, French clocks and Mahler. What role did he play in this? Would Mr Lee have done this on his own? We all know that Mrs Churcher, who is a fine woman, is a personal friend of the Prime Minister. I hope that was not a factor in this matter. But we must know to what extent Mr Lee was simply the monkey and the Prime Minister the organ-grinder.

I think it is vital that this matter, which has damaged Australia's reputation and which has raised question marks over the National Gallery of Australia, should be resolved, and it should be resolved by providing this Senate with the documents. That is why I have moved this motion. I think it is a very important matter and it should be resolved as quickly as possible. I have asked that the relevant documents be laid on the table as soon as practicable after the Senate resumes on 13 November 1995.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is unusual for us to face this situation in the Senate whereby a senator uses the device of suspending standing orders before the Senate has even been given the opportunity of indicating whether the motion should have been declared formal or not.
—This has been on the Notice Paper for days.

—Just hold your horses. Senator Baume sought leave to move an amendment to his motion. I was not aware that that was coming before the chamber, but in a very magnanimous gesture I did agree for leave to be granted to allow Senator Baume to move an amendment to his motion. Before seeking leave for the amended motion to be taken as formal, Senator Baume was on his feet moving a motion to suspend standing orders. That in itself, I might say, is extraordinary. I thought Senator Baume would know more about the procedures of this place than to allow such a procedure to occur.

PARA.TAB: But I might say, anyway, that we have had an explanation from the government whip about what occurred at the whips' meeting last night. We have also had a statement by leave from the opposition whip about those processes. I direct all senators' attention to the `red', at `Placing of business'. The `red' reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Baume to postpone general business notice of motion no. 1862 till the next day of sitting (relating to the appointment of the Director to the National Gallery of Australia)

That is where this matter was left at the whips' meeting—and Senator Harradine is nodding in agreement; he is aware of this. It is an extraordinary thing for you to do, Senator Baume, to come into this chamber, having had an arrangement made at the whips' meeting dealing with the business before this chamber, an arrangement made that was agreed where the matter was to be postponed—

TALK.START.PARA: —Not on my instructions.
—Read the `red', Senator.
—Not on my instructions. You said I asked for it. That is wrong.

—Through you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that was where the matter was left at the whips' meeting. There was no formal request from Senator Baume to progress this matter. The usual courtesies were not complied with at all, Senator. No senator, no party in this chamber had this particular request distributed to them or sent to them—no-one—and that yet again is another fundamental breach of the courtesies and the processes of this place.

PARA.TAB: Then, at the conclusion of this discussion at the whips' meeting, the opposition whip said to the other whips and those present at the meeting that if there were to be any change on what the whips' meeting decided and what has been recorded in this `red', if there were to be any alteration to that procedure, then he would take the responsibility of communicating that to his fellow whips. And that did not happen either.

I have to say, Senator Baume, what you have done today is, without doubt, a complete breach of the processes, the procedures and the courtesies of this chamber, and everyone in here knows it. I would say that the suggestion made by the government whip was a sensible one, a very generous one, to have a look at this some time later in the day after question time to give people an opportunity to look at the amendment. The amendment was not circulated, either. You are really kidding, Senator Baume. We are trying to extend the courtesies of this place to all involved, but your proposition is an absolute disgrace. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I feel that there has been a communications breakdown, and that communication breakdown has presumably taken place on that side of the chamber. I acknowledge that Senator Baume sent around his notice of motion asking whether we had any objection to having it made formal, so that courtesy was given to me, certainly. But, with respect, we come here this morning and see the `red' which says:

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Baume to postpone general business notice of motion no. 1862 till the next day of sitting—

That is on the `Order of business'. Then there is the additional point that leave was sought by Senator Baume, and that leave was granted, to amend the motion. So I would say there has obviously been a breakdown of communication. So far as I am concerned, I am not prepared to vote for the current motion for the suspension of standing orders. I think what ought to be done is what was being suggested by the government whip, and I thought by both whips—that is, have it sorted out later on in the day.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was at that whips' meeting myself last night. I do recall the question coming up. I think what happened—I have been trying to think of exactly what happened—was that the government whip suggested that, because he did not believe the motion had been sent around to government senators, it should perhaps be deferred. I think what then happened—I hope I am not saying the wrong thing—was that the opposition whip said he would check that out. Being a whip myself, I know it is very difficult to get around to absolutely everything you have to do. If something slips past you, well, it slips past you. I have never seen Senator Panizza do anything in bad faith; I have never seen Senator Jones do anything in bad faith.
—No-one is suggesting they did anything in bad faith.

—Well, I don't know. I agree with Senator Harradine when he says that there has been a breakdown in communications. I did receive a copy of the motion from Senator Baume ahead of time. In fact, I would take some of the responsibility for the amendment because I asked Senator Baume this morning if he would move that amendment, and he said yes, he would. Then he got up and did it immediately, which was terribly expeditious for us but unfortunate in that nobody else had seen it.

PARA.TAB: I think Senator Baume agrees with me that probably the best thing is to do what Senator Jones suggested a little while ago—we should adjourn this matter now and get back to it after question time. I would like to see it resolved today, if that is possible. But I think it should be later on today when we can sit down and be very calm about discussing it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do think there has been some failure of communication. Senator Bourne is correct in saying that we, for our part, undertook to seek further instructions. Nonetheless, the fact remains that this matter has been under active consideration at the whips' meetings. All parties have been aware that it has been our intention to bring the matter on for debate. It certainly has been a matter of very active public controversy. The government is fully aware of the extent to which this matter has been canvassed in the media and the fact that we have been anxious to have these documents tabled.

PARA.TAB: I think what Senator Bourne says is generally correct. I would concede that, even though the amendments that Senator Baume made by leave this morning were entirely inconsequential and technical, the fact is that it appears on the Notice Paper giving the formal impression that the matter was not going to be taken at this point in time.

Having said all that, I think it is perfectly plain that the government has been prepared for some days to deal with the merits of the argument—I know that is the last thing Senator Faulkner would want to deal with. Can I therefore suggest that we deal with this matter at a later hour this day. I would suggest 12 noon because that gives the government ample opportunity. There is no need for any extra preparation, I might say. All we are doing is agreeing that, because of the precise form in which this matter has come forward, it makes sense to allow a period of time to elapse. But I would not have thought they needed more than half an hour to get themselves together, if they have not already.

In those circumstances, postponing the matter for a couple of hours seems to me to meet the concerns of all sides. We do not want a long debate on the subject; we simply want the matter to be disposed of today. If it is put off until after question time, then it eats into general business, and I do not think that is desirable either. I think it would be much better, quicker and cleaner if we could have the matter dealt with at 12 noon. I therefore propose to move that further debate on this matter be postponed until 12 noon this day.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Childs)—This is a suspension motion—

TALK.START.PARA: —What would happen at that point, I assume, is that we then have the debate on the merits. If the government wants to turn it into a full half-hour debate on the question of suspension and then have a further debate on the merits, that is a matter for the government. But we are all anxious to dispose of the matter promptly and we ought to be able to do that on the merits inside half an hour. If we do it at 12 noon, then I would have thought that would meet everyone's concerns.
—We will be proposing to do it after taking note of answers to questions.
—That is what I thought you were proposing, but I am saying that eats into general business.
—It eats into government business.
—This is the normal time at which you move a suspension of standing orders to bring on a debate on a matter which the government does not want to take as formal.
—You can move a suspension at any time. See how you go.

—I am just saying that where you seek to have a debate on a matter which the government is not prepared to take as formal, that is the normal time to do it. There is no shortage of precedents in terms of debating the matter during the morning. But if it is taken after lunch, I think we all understand where that is going to end. There is a high likelihood that the matter would not even be resolved today. In those circumstances, I think 12 noon is the appropriate time, so I propose to move accordingly.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, the procedural position we find ourselves in, with an adjournment motion on a motion to suspend standing orders, leaves me a bit perplexed. So I seek your guidance on the procedures from here, because I want to speak against that motion and against the other motion also.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Childs)—I think the most practical thing to do is take it that Senator Alston has foreshadowed that proposal. That might allow clarification to take place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, that is very wise. The situation we have here is that the procedural tangle—I was going to call it a procedural stunt, but that would be impolite of me—in which we find ourselves is obscuring the substance, but let us try to disentangle the two questions.

PARA.TAB: The priority for the moment is to say, `What is the proper way to deal with this matter on a subsequent occasion?' I think we are all agreed now that it will be a subsequent occasion, although we are not quite agreed about when it will be that we will talk about the substance, which I do not think will be all that difficult. I do not see that dealing with the substance of this matter is likely to be all that difficult, although I have to qualify that in one way—I still actually do not know the final form of words that is being proposed. That is the only qualification I have for saying that I think the substance will be easy to deal with, and it summarises the procedural problem.

We are being asked to agree to a motion when we do not know what it says. I am not going to do that, and you cannot blame anyone on this side for not doing that—although I do believe that we will get some reasonably easy resolution of the substance, probably with no debate. I cannot give that guarantee because I have not seen the actual words, but I think that it would probably be with no debate.

So while I do not think it is going to unreasonably eat into general business—and we would obviously not get support to do that if we wanted to, but we do not have any desire to do that; it is not a problem for us in terms of the amount of time available for general business—I think the only reasonable proposal now is that which the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Faulkner), in his usual delicate way, suggested by interjection, which is that we might deal with it directly after motions to take note of answers. I do indicate that we will make every effort to make that an agreed matter that will take no further time. I cannot guarantee it, but I think we can do that, and I will seek to do that.

Therefore, I do not know whether, Mr Acting Deputy President, you want me to suggest that that would be an amendment with regard to time relating to the motion of which Senator Alston has, in effect, given notice, or whether you will simply require us to vote on Senator Alston's motion and then move a subsequent one, or whether procedurally we are better to have Senator Alston's motion withdrawn and move a subsequent agreed motion to deal with the first item after the taking note of answers. Under any of those three procedures, I am sure we can take the procedural issues out of this debate and get to the substance, which I think, with a little bit of time and courtesy, we can then resolve quite simply.

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to the matter, I wish to clarify a couple of positions. First of all, if I look at my notes from last night at the whips' meeting, I have got `defer on No. 1862'. I look at the `red' this morning and it has got `postponed'. So it was very clear that that was the position.

PARA.TAB: At the whips' meeting last night, Senator Bourne certainly raised the fact that she had had a copy of the resolution, but no-one else had a copy of the resolution, including myself and the opposition whip. Normally, whether it is a member of the government or a member of the opposition, unless a member sends a letter around to each whip seeking formality of a motion, we do not deal with it. If it is our member, I say, `No, we can't deal with it because he has not sent around the letter seeking formality.' So we do not deal with it. The same thing applies to someone in the opposition, and this applied on that occasion. We all agreed that we should defer it but that, if there was any change to the deferral, Senator Panizza was to come back and give us the information.

I noted this morning that it was postponed on the printed `red', and that is what was decided at the whips' meeting last night. I had no communication with Senator Panizza or with anyone else in relation to the matter. So with Senator Baume moving the motion and then moving an amendment, it makes it very difficult for senators in this place to understand what it is about. Senator Bourne might know because she discussed the amendment with Senator Baume. We certainly did not discuss the amendment—and we do not know what the amendment is. My suggestion is to move the matter until after taking note of answers to questions. That is one way to resolve the matter and one way of showing courtesy towards procedures in the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I do not have any quarrel with what Senator Jones has said. The sensible way to handle it is for Senator Baume to now seek leave to withdraw his motion to suspend standing orders. I understand that Senator Faulkner will then move for consideration of the motion to be dealt with after taking note of answers this afternoon. I think we can resolve the matter immediately on that basis.

PARA.TAB: Motion—by leave—withdrawn.
Motion (by Senator Faulkner) agreed to:

That General Business notice of motion No. 1862 standing in the name of Senator Baume for this day be called on immediately after consideration of any motions to take note of answers to questions today.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee: Joint

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Deputy Chairman of the Human Rights Subcommittee of the parliament and on behalf of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, I present the report entitled Human rights and progress towards democracy in Burma, together with transcripts of hearings, minutes of meetings and the submissions and evidence given to the inquiry. I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate, indeed the whole parliament and informed people of Australia, have been for many years now enormously concerned about the transgressions against human rights in the country of Burma. In this chamber alone about 20 senators, at one time or another in the last seven years, have expressed very real concern at developments there, with the suspension of democracy and the persecution of the elected majority from the 1990 election and, in particular, of the leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi. Senator Hill and Senator Schacht have for many years expressed their concerns about developments in Burma.

PARA.TAB: In 1993, two years ago, Senator Chamarette gave a notice of motion that eventually became a formal motion of this chamber. It was passed by all of us. With great conscience and without controversy, it was adopted. The terms of that motion drew attention to the lack of democracy and the transgression of human rights in Burma. As is our norm, the President of the Senate—and Senator Beahan was a former member of the Human Rights Subcommittee—passed on that resolution to the Burmese ambassador in Canberra, U Saw Tun.

The ambassador replied. His reply was not to the satisfaction of the Senate. The reply is set out in the introduction to the report. The Senate did not allow the inadequate response from the representative of that country to be received and noted without comment. Accordingly, Senator Reid moved a motion, which was supported by all senators, that the original resolution and the response of the Burmese ambassador be referred to the Human Rights Subcommittee for inquiry and report. This was in March last year.

Over the last 18 months we have carried out a very thorough inquiry. I wish to commend particularly those senators who attended almost every meeting and who were very active. I refer to Senator Harradine and Senator Bourne, who are in the chamber. Senator Margetts, Senator Reynolds, Senator Denman and others were also involved and should also be commended.

Throughout the inquiry I had the honour to be the deputy chairman. The chairman at the beginning was former Senator Loosley. I admire the tenacity with which he went about the conduct of this inquiry.

We have now published a thorough report on the situation in Burma. I have here a huge pile of paper which includes material that was before the United Nations, before the Human Rights Commission and before the ILO. It is a very sorry picture that is described of refugees displaced out of Burma and into Thailand; out of Burma and into Bangladesh; forced labour; and military interventions into every part of the country.

This is most offensive not only to the Senate, Australia and the Australian government but to the general international community. I say that because of the United Nations resolutions that continued to be passed while that situation remained in Burma. The international community took great offence at a military group taking control of the country. That group was called the SLORC, the State Law and Order Restoration Council. What a parody of words in the title of the present de facto government of Burma!

At the election in 1990, the National League for Democracy, as led by Aung San Suu Kyi, had the support of the people. That explains why we have a photograph of the elected leader of the people of Burma on the cover of our report. We have references in our 38 recommendations to the need for her to be immediately involved in negotiations with the SLORC and for there to be a full restoration of government in Burma by allowing the elected parliamentarians to take their place in the parliament.

We do not see this as a simplistic matter. It is not a matter of waving a flag and everything will be ordered in this part of the world. We truly acknowledge in the report that Burma is a country on the edge. It has a large border with China and a large border with India. This is the country in Indo-China that has been most cut off from the rest of the world from the time of its independence in 1947. Burma has a geography which makes unity, order and democratic government somewhat difficult.

There is an enormous range of languages in Burma. Everybody speaks in common parlance of the Shan, Chin, Karan, Kachin and other minority groups that are calling for a federation style approach to solutions for Burma. The jungle borders with Thailand are of enormous physical difficulty to Burma, as is the interior of the country. The problems are not the result of the ageless circumstances of the people of Burma; they are, we believe, the direct outcome of the suspension of democracy and the policies of the SLORC that trespass upon every field of human rights.

In the late 1940s, the world community adopted the United Nations Declaration on Human Rights. That has stood ever since. We see this as the most relevant document to judge the situation in Burma. It is because of this failure in every area of human rights that we again draw to the attention of the Senate, the people of Australia and the international community this assessment of the need for continuing action by the international community to see restoration of democracy and the end to these transgressions against human rights.

There are some 38 recommendations in the report which are all addressed to the Australian government. The committee has looked favourably upon the benchmarks policy of the Australian government. In appendix 10 we have an outline of the benchmarks that the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Evans, has outlined and which he has argued in ASEAN and international forums as being the appropriate preconditions for any more positive relations with the country.

Time forbids me to say more than that. I note the careful work and excellent contributions to this report of our secretary, Margaret Swieringa. I thank all the members of the Human Rights Subcommittee of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade for what is a substantial report that must be given very careful attention.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I probably agree with pretty well everything that Senator Teague has said about this report of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. I believe it is a very good report. It is one of our shorter reports. We generally take a lot longer to go through things. There was an enormous amount of evidence. Almost all of the evidence, with the exception of four or five submissions, pointed to the fact that there is a major problem in Burma today and that these are certainly the worst problems in South-East Asia today.

PARA.TAB: It is very obvious that Burma is a country where there is very clear delineation between right and wrong. In South-East Asia it is probably the clearest we are going to see. The committee's conclusions are all very strong and I think that says something. This committee is comprised of members from the wide spectrum that we see in this parliament. We all agreed on several things, and I will just quote a couple. The first line of the first conclusion states:

SPEECH.PARA: Reports continue to be made of gross human rights abuses in Burma, `consistently and on a wide scale.'
We heard an awful lot of those. It continues:
The gap between the statements made by various representatives of the Burmese Government and the actual conditions of life for ordinary Burmese people appears to be very wide.
I think that is putting it very diplomatically. It goes on:

. . . the problems that arise for states because of the demands by minority groups for self-determination and independence . . . this issue alone represents one of the major security issues facing the world today.
Certainly nobody could disagree with that one. The final conclusion I will quote states:

Today, since the SLORC deprived the elected government of power in 1990, most of the gross human rights abuses committed by the Government result from that act of illegality, the opposition it has engendered and the systematic attempts of the SLORC to destroy the National League for Democracy and any political opposition to its rule. The Government lacks accountability; its rule is arbitrary; it has dispensed with a rule of law and has resorted to rule by decree. There has been little progress towards democracy.

I would have to agree with that. At the moment the constitutional convention amounts to a farce. It will have to be very substantially changed before the international community will accept any findings that it comes up with. I believe this is a very good report. I would also like to thank Margaret Swieringa, our secretary, who has done an excellent job on it.

PARA.TAB: I would just like to make one final comment before Senator Margetts speaks. Senator Margetts has put in a dissenting report to this report. I feel I really ought to defend myself and other members of the committee. I do not believe that what Senator Margetts has put in her dissenting report is actually a dissent. I think we would all agree with pretty well everything she has put in it. It is a pity she is not on the Human Rights Subcommittee because I am sure she would have a lot of very interesting and good input, as we see by this report. I do not believe it is a dissenting report.

I will just go through a couple of things she said. Her first recommendation is about ministerial level contact, which is already government policy and we mention that in the report. I think it is a good policy. I do not think there should be ministerial level contact except in very exceptional circumstances such as going to see Aung San Suu Kyi, which I think would be a good thing. Apart from that, no, I do not see why there should be any ministerial level contact and I do not think anybody else on the committee does either. I think that fact came out quite clearly in our committee's deliberations.
Her second recommendation is in fact one of our conclusions, so we agree absolutely on that one. There is no question there. The third recommendation is an interesting one on heroin and states:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Australian government inform the public of the major sources of heroin being imported into Australia . . .

If that recommendation had been brought up to the committee, and it is one that I accept we did not think of, certainly I would say it would have been agreed to by every member of the committee. I think it is a very good one and I wish it had been brought up so we could have agreed to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was brought up.

—It was not brought up before the committee because Senator Margetts is not on the committee. If she were, and if she had brought this up, I am sure we would have agreed to it. I would have agreed to it. I imagine Senator Harradine would have agreed to it. I cannot imagine Senator Teague disagreeing to it. It is a good recommendation. The next recommendation states:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the event that government officials plan to visit Burma, such visits are predicated . . .

That is good too, but we do not have any government officials planning to visit Burma. That is a good thing too. I would rather we did not have any government officials visiting Burma. They do not at the moment and they do not intend to. I think that is very good.

PARA.TAB: Recommendation No. 5 is one of the recommendations of our last report. It would have been a very good idea to have put it into this report. I wish we had. It is one of our recommendations, and we agree with it. The country economic brief on Burma should be withdrawn. We deal with it under chapter 6. We disagreed with that country economic brief. Every country economic brief should include human rights information; that is one thing that we all agreed on in this report. I hope that that happens in country economic briefs around the world when they deal with Australia as well as every other country.

Finally, I quite like recommendation No. 6. It is quite a good recommendation. But the issue did not arise in any of the evidence, so we just did not deal with it in the inquiry. But it is rather a nice recommendation. If we had heard anything about the issue, I would have agreed with it. I will make one point to defend myself. I will do it before Senator Margetts gets up so that she can get stuck into me if she feels like it. I believe that she has not put in a dissenting report. It is like a personal report. I would quite like to have put in one myself. It does not dissent from what we have said. It agrees with what we have said, and extends it in a couple of areas. One area that it extends it in is an area that we did not cover. We had no evidence on it. But it was a good idea.
I would like people to know when they are reading the Hansard and this report that the committee does not disagree with what Senator Margetts said. Senator Margetts has put in an extra report.

TALK.START.PARA: —They did, to every single one of those.

—I was not at the main committee meeting because I cannot get to them. I have a standing committee meeting then. Senator Margetts is telling me that the main committee disagreed with every one of them. I find that very difficult to accept, especially since three of them are our recommendations. It demonstrates a real problem with the joint foreign affairs committee system in that it has to go through so many levels of agreement. When you have unanimous support for something at one level, it is very difficult when you then have to go to another level and get unanimous support there.

PARA.TAB: I agree with everything in this report, including what Senator Margetts is dissenting from. I do not believe that it dissents from anything the Human Rights Subcommittee has put in this report. I do not believe that Senator Margetts is dissenting from what the rest of us on the Human Rights Subcommittee have written in this report. I agree with everything in the entire report, including what Senator Margetts has said. I imagine that most members of the Human Rights Subcommittee would, too.

I will finish by saying that there was little disagreement in the evidence on the way that Burma should be handled. I hope that the government and the opposition, as a possible future government, will take a great deal of notice of this. Last week, I was at a symposium on Burma, as Senator Chamarette was. I was a bit surprised by the comments made there about Burma by a member of the opposition. I hope that the foreign minister in the next government—be it the current Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans), a member of the opposition, another member of the current government, or me—will take everything in this document into account when they decide what Australia's view will be on Burma in the next government. This is a very comprehensive document about what ought to be, and currently is, Australia's view on Burma.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Bourne has mentioned, I have included in this report on Burma a report which is marked as a dissent. It is probably more correctly a qualifying statement. I appreciate the work that the committee and the committee secretary have done in producing this report. It was by degree. I was reluctant to change a report that was produced by a committee. I understand Senator Bourne's comment that being on a defence and trade subcommittee on one's own is perhaps an even more different experience. Support on those issues would also be nice.

PARA.TAB: But support is not always possible. As someone from the government said yesterday, `We only have 19 backbenchers, Senator, to attend all the committees.' I said, `Talk to me about it. We have two for front and backbench work.' It is very difficult to even cover the vast array of committee work.

However, as a matter of degree and even definition, the government appears to have shied away from the term `constructive engagement'; but that, in fact, is what we are seeing in Australia's changing relationship with Burma. And that is the level of concern which I have endeavoured to express.

For instance, there was a difference of opinion on whether or not it is better to have engagement at a ministerial level at forums. The trouble is, if Burma is invited to a number of the forums, including ASEAN, such an invitation legitimises the SLORC government. That really sends the wrong signal—the same kind of signal as that sent by a former Prime Minister who travelled to that country. That trip was used considerably by SLORC and waved around as a symbol of their legitimacy.

An invitation to SLORC to attend ASEAN is a two-edged sword. We would tend to come down on the other side: by inviting SLORC to ASEAN, you give them the legitimacy they crave. That will not necessarily help restoration of a legitimate government.

There is still an Austrade office in Burma. Despite all the rhetoric about Australia not trading with Burma, I can see no reason why we should have both an Austrade office and two staff. I understand they are local staff, but we have heard again and again from Austrade that there is a very small Austrade dollar which we have to use very wisely.

The retention of local staff is not a reason to keep an office open where we have no official trade relationship with a country. If we do not have a relationship, then we do not have an Austrade office. If we have an Austrade office, even if we do not have an Australian representative on it, then we send the signal that we are keeping the doors open on trade development. At this stage, that is the wrong signal when we have seen no real movements towards establishing the democratic process and improving human rights in Burma. That is why the statement was made.

On the reference to an inquiry to create a code of practice, such a reference to the subcommittee might have been good. However, it is an effort to make a positive contribution for the future and it is something that may be picked up and worked on by government—and we hope that it will be. It is more a qualifying statement and a matter of degree. It is more a case of being a little stronger in some of the recommendations because of concern that the wrong interpretation may be taken by SLORC through limited engagement being interpreted as a recognition of legitimacy by the SLORC government in its current form.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal Sen B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the members of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, I am pleased to present the committee's annual report of activities for 1994-95, and I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: The report, which is the 339th tabled by the committee since 1951, presents an overview of the committee's activities for the last financial year.The committee began the practice of presenting annual reports to parliament in 1976. The committee's decision to prepare annual reports was explained in the 1979 annual report in the following terms:

In reporting this way to Parliament, the Committee has recognised its responsibility as a statutory body to report on its activities. This Committee has always taken the view that bodies established by the Parliament should report to the Parliament and has been the vanguard of encouraging increased standards and regularity in reporting.

This statement is still valid now. The last year has been particularly busy for the committee. During the year it has tabled seven reports, which was two more than in the previous financial year. The most significant report tabled was report 331, which contains results of the committee's review of the package of three bills intended to replace the Audit Act 1991 and of the committee's consideration of the government's proposal to establish an audit committee of parliament.

PARA.TAB: Report 331 contained 39 recommendations to further enhance this package. The committee was gratified to see that the government adopted the vast majority of those recommendations. Senators will know that some 13 months after the tabling of the committee's report the three bills and the motion to establish an audit committee are still to be debated in parliament. They contain a number of contentious issues: firstly, the Auditor-General's mandate to conduct performance audits in government business enterprises; the extent of the parliament's involvement in the appointed process for auditors-general and the most important form for an audit committee; and, finally, certain provisions relating to the disclosure of sensitive information.

The committee remains of the view that the recommendations in report 331 are sensible and constructive solutions that should be further considered and potentially taken up. The parliament has before it a rare opportunity to modernise the Commonwealth's financial management and accountability framework. If we cannot reach agreement on the outstanding matters in the next two weeks and enact the legislation before the end of this session in parliament, the opportunity will pass. This will be a great tragedy.

Because of the upcoming election and the uncertain legislative priorities in the new government, the reforms contained in the bills will go unmade until at least July 1997 and could potentially be abandoned altogether. Delay of this magnitude would be detrimental to the good management of the Commonwealth and public accountability. However, whatever the eventual outcome of the debates in the Senate and the House, the committee considers that its review demonstrates that the parliamentary committees can play a valuable role and that contributions to the legislative process can help ensure that legislation is of the highest quality.

During the year the committee also tabled report 336, Public business in the public interest: An inquiry into commercialisation in the Commonwealth public sector. In this major report, the committee concluded that commercialisation and corporatisation have led to major improvements in the efficiency and effectiveness with which Commonwealth agencies provide goods and services. However, the committee found that commercialisation has not been without its costs and in some cases the transition could have been managed in a better way.

The other reports tabled during the year cover a diverse range of topics, including the use of the Australian government credit card by Commonwealth agencies, the sale of Aussat and best practice for the sale of Commonwealth assets and, finally, the construction and acquisition of six new Collins class submarines for the Royal Australian Navy.

The committee was also active during the year with several ongoing and new inquiries into the administration of Commonwealth-state agreements, specific purpose payments, cash management in the public sector, accrual reporting, whole-of-government reporting and fiscal responsibility legislation. Reports for some of these inquiries have now been tabled and it is planned to table reports for the remainder of the inquiries before the end of this session.

A major highlight of the committee's year was a visit to New Zealand as part of the committee exchange program established by the Australian and New Zealand parliaments. The centrepiece of the visit was a meeting between the committee delegation and the New Zealand parliament's equivalent of the JCPA, the Finance and Expenditure Committee. The meeting provided the delegation with an overseas perspective on some of the common issues facing the two committees. Discussions evolved around the role of committees in the New Zealand parliament; New Zealand's experience of public sector reforms; and the relationship between parliaments and their auditors-general. I must say on a personal note that it was particularly valuable in terms of our discussions on accrual accounting and fiscal responsibility, which are matters which we are currently considering.

While in New Zealand, the committee delegation also met with a number of other individuals and organisations. The purpose of these additional meetings was to gain a New Zealand perspective on some of the issues facing the Joint Committee of Public Accounts in its inquiries in Australia. In summary, the opportunity to discuss issues of mutual interest with our counterparts in the New Zealand Finance and Expenditure Committee and a great number of public and private sector representatives was invaluable.

Another activity in which the committee has been involved is a watching brief over the tax law improvement project. This is a task that the committee is continuing in 1995 and 1996. We look forward to very positive results coming from that process.

The Joint Public Accounts Committee has had a very productive year—something which would not have been possible without the unstinting efforts and active involvement of the committee members. I have enjoyed immensely my time with the committee. I particularly acknowledge the efforts of Grant Harrison, the secretary of the committee, and the other members of the secretariat who are of a particularly high quality. They have been pro-active, dedicated and meticulous in all their work. I would like to thank them on behalf of the members of the committee. I commend the report to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts I present report No. 340 Cash Matters: Cash Management in the Commonwealth and move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, it gives me great pleasure today to table the committee's 340th report entitled Cash Matters: Cash Management in the Commonwealth. This report is the result of the committee's review of two reports presented to the parliament by the Auditor-General. The first report was Audit Report No. 22, Efficiency Audit, Cash Management in Commonwealth Government Departments and the second report was Audit Report No. 10, Efficiency Audit, Cash Management in Commonwealth Government Departments. Both audit reports resulted from the same performance audit, the first being an interim report and the second being the final report.

PARA.TAB: The committee's decision to review these reports was influenced by the same reasons which caused the Auditor-General to conduct the audit: firstly, that the Commonwealth manages huge amounts of cash each year; and secondly, that any improvements in cash management practices would potentially result in substantial dollar savings. In a nutshell, good cash management endeavours to match patterns of expenditure with patterns of revenue. In the Commonwealth, responsibility for this task is shared between individual agencies with deliver programs or collect revenues and the central economic agencies—the Department of Finance and the Treasury—which are involved in forecasting overall cash needs and engaging in short-term borrowing when cash holdings are predicted to be insufficient to cover forthcoming payments.

When short-term borrowings are made, the Commonwealth incurs an interest expense known as public debt interest expenditure. In recent years, transactions to fund public debt interest have been the single biggest source of real growth in Commonwealth outlays. The budget papers for this financial year, 1995-96, show that the past two years have seen such expenditure grow from $6.6 billion to $10.08 billion this financial year. At the strategic level, good cash management involves the prompt banking of Commonwealth revenues and the development of payment schedules which recognise opportunity costs and revenue peaks.

The scale of the task is immense: in 1995-96 the Commonwealth's revenue is expected to total $110 billion, while outlays are expected to amount to $122 billion. Figures like this merely confirm that there is a need to pay special attention to cash management.

On the revenue side, it is important that the Australian Taxation Office and the other revenue agencies have sophisticated systems in place to quickly process and bank incoming receipts, which in peak periods can amount to more than $1 billion per day.

On the expenditure side, Commonwealth agencies need to pay far more attention than they have in the past to making payments in a way which not only meets the Commonwealth's program objectives but at the same time protects the Commonwealth's financial interests. This is true both of the Commonwealth's own purpose outlays and of the Commonwealth's payments to the states, which in this financial year amount to $34.2 billion, or a little less than one-third of the total outlays.

The committee's current inquiry into the administration of specific purpose payments to the states has drawn attention to the significant cash management implications of these payments. There is ample evidence, for example, that by making special purpose payments before they are needed for program purposes, the states are able to invest the money and make significant interest windfalls. In effect, this is a form of hidden subsidy to the states. It is an issue I expect the committee to return to in the report of its SPP inquiry, which will be tabled before the end of the current parliamentary session.

Another issue which is crucial for effective cash management is the need to accurately forecast cash flows. It is this activity which enables the containment of public debt interest expenditure. The committee has recommended the establishment of a series of cash forecasting benchmarks based on national and international best practice in both the public and private sectors. Treasury should also routinely monitor and evaluate its cash forecasting performance against these best practice benchmarks.

There are also a great number of agency level functions which can have a marked aggregated impact across the Commonwealth. These agency level functions include: negotiation of prepayment terms, particularly for specific purpose payments to the states and territories; invoicing promptly for goods and services sold; expediting collection of amounts due; purchasing goods or services later without jeopardising program objectives; negotiating more favourable purchase payment terms; reducing the amount of inventory held; spreading payment terms; and paying invoices only when they fall due.

The key message is that all agencies have a role in maximising the Commonwealth's cash management outcomes. Only efficient and effective management of these day-to-day functions by departments will achieve the levels of cash balances necessary to minimise borrowing and subsequently the net public debt interest cost to the Commonwealth.

Commonwealth agencies maintain over 2,000—that is correct—bank accounts. It was of great concern to the committee that the Audit Office had discovered that several agencies were unaware of the number of accounts they maintained. It is an essential discipline that proper bank account records be kept. To do otherwise is an indicator of extreme laxity on the part of agency managers and exposes Commonwealth funds to significant risks.

In considering how cash management might be improved across all Commonwealth agencies, the committee came to the view that the potential for savings, the number of issues involved in good cash management and the absence of any whole of government monitoring or analysis pointed to the need for increased central focus in the Commonwealth, at least in the short term. Accordingly, the committee recommends in this report that Finance should play a more prominent role in providing guidance for line agencies as well as in the monitoring, analysis and reporting of cash management performance on a Commonwealth-wide basis. The central focus on cash management recommended in the report could result in Finance performing a corporate treasury function for the Commonwealth.

One of the issues to emerge during the committee's review was whether or not the group of accounts maintained by the Commonwealth at the Reserve Bank and used for the targeting of cash balances was the most appropriate. Evidence provided to the committee suggested that in practice the target group of accounts has already been expanded by Treasury to include the overdraft group. As this wider group is the one which is used by the Reserve Bank to calculate the Commonwealth's interest bill, it seems logical to the committee that the target group should be formally expanded.

An associated, and perhaps more important, issue is that of the level of balances in these target accounts. The government decided in 1989 that the average cumulative balances in the target accounts should be maintained in the $0-300 million range. The committee believes there is now scope to further refine this target range, towards the lower end, thus providing additional savings. The committee recommends that Finance and Treasury should discuss and agree on optimal cash balances or, alternatively, that the issue be resolved by a review process.

This leads me to the final issue. In the audit reports, the Auditor-General pointed to areas where better cooperation between Finance and Treasury could result in an improved cash management performance. Report 340 looks in more depth at this relationship between these two key central agencies. The report reflects the concerns of committee members that a number of important issues which appear to have been under discussion or review for some years have yet to be satisfactorily resolved.

It seems to the committee that better cooperation and communication between these two agencies could have seen a number of these issues resolved some time ago, with consequent benefit to the Commonwealth. Whilst both the committee and the Auditor-General acknowledge that there has been improvement in the working relationship between Finance and Treasury since the audit began, the committee believes there is scope for further cooperation.

Given the range and significant nature of the issues requiring resolution, the committee recommends that the Minister for Finance (Mr Beazley) should commission a high level review of cash management in the Commonwealth. The review team should: (a) have a chairman from the private sector with expertise in corporate Treasury functions; (b) consist of senior representatives from the Departments of Finance and the Treasury; (c) include a senior representative of the Australian National Audit Office as a member of the review team or as an observer; (d) focus on the cash management issues which remain unresolved; and (e) report within six months of being established.

The committee believes that such an externally-led review will enable a fresh perspective to be brought to the issues—a perspective unencumbered by inter-agency sensitivities. This is an important recommendation dealing with an important issue. The size of the Commonwealth's public debt interest bill and the potential savings which could flow from better cash management are too big to ignore.

In conclusion, I would like to express our thanks to those people who contributed to the review by preparing submissions and giving evidence at the public hearings. I would also like to thank the staff of the secretariat for assisting the committee in preparing the report. I commend the report to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
