SPEECH.PARA: INTERNATIONAL SHIPPING (AUSTRALIAN-RESIDENT SEAFARERS) GRANTS BILL 1995
This bill gives effect to an important element in the Government's package of shipping reform measures which was announced in the Budget on 9 May 1995.

The reform package continues the improvement in efficiency and competitiveness of Australia's major trading fleet, and assists in closing the competitive gap between Australian shipping and its major international competitors.

This bill introduces from 1 July 1995 an annual taxable grant payable in arrears to Australia's international shipping industry employers, based on the PAYE tax liabilities of seafarers on Australia's international trading ships.
In addition to the introduction of the grant under this bill, the reform package includes two other key elements:

Firstly, the extension from 1 July 1997 until 30 June 2002 of the existing capital assistance measures available under the Ships (Capital Grants) Act 1987 and the associated accelerated depreciation regime under section 57AM of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936. These measures, which at least equate to the capital incentives provided by other shipping nations, will encourage the continued investment in modern ships. The necessary amendments to the two acts will be introduced in due course.
Secondly, the implementation of the complementary industry efficiency reform measures developed by the shipowners and maritime unions in the Maritime Industry Restructuring Agreement known as MIRA.

These include a greater flexibility in the operation of the seafarers engagement system (the pooled labour scheme for ratings) and other measures which provide ship operators with the kind of cost savings and other benefits more generally associated with company employment.

The Australian Shipowners Association has estimated that, across the current major trading fleet (which includes both coastal and international trading ships), savings of some $15 million per year can be achieved under MIRA.
The reform measures introduced by MIRA will also deliver cost savings and efficiencies to the offshore industry supply fleet, which services Australia's offshore petroleum and gas industry.
The structure of the Government's reform package is based upon the recommendations of the August 1994 report by the then Chairman of the Shipping Industry Reform Authority, Mr Rae Taylor AO.

This report recognised the achievement of the reform programs implemented by Government and the shipping industry since the early 1980s. These reforms had focused on reductions in crewing levels, a radical restructure of seafarer training and the introduction of modern, technologically advanced, fuel efficient ships into the Australian fleet.
Over the past decade Australian shipowners have invested some $1.6 billion in new tonnage; the average age of ships in the Australian fleet is 11 years, compared with 18 years in the world fleet.

In 1983, a typical Australian trading ship had a crew of 33; today that figure is 18. While in 1983 the Australian average crew size was well in excess of OECD levels, our crew levels are now lower. These are remarkable achievements.

Over recent years there has been a trend by OECD national flag operators towards registering their vessels under open or international registers. These registers typically offer attractive taxation regimes and the ability to replace wholly national crews with lower-cost mixed nationality crews, predominantly from the developing countries.

The Taylor Report found that, as a result of this changed overseas situation, the competitive gap between Australian ships and comparable overseas ships operated under international registers was about $2 million per ship per year.
The Report, having examined the main areas of cost disabilities affecting Australian shipping, concluded the PAYE taxation regime had a major impact on Australia's competitive position.

Accordingly, the Report recommended removal of the PAYE taxation cost element from Australia's international trading ships in order to match the position of overseas ship operators, whose crews are either exempt from PAYE taxation or where the taxation impact on crew costs is offset by other concessions.
The Government accepted the thrust of the Taylor Report findings.

After examining a range of options in the crew taxation area, the Government has decided that a grant based on the notional tax liabilities of seafarers serving on ships trading internationally would be the most effective and practicable means of achieving the objective.

Mr President, the bill now before the Senate introduces from 1 July 1995 an annual taxable grant payable in arrears to Australian shipping industry employers, based on the notional PAYE taxation liabilities on the earnings of Australian-resident crew members on ships in Australia's international trading fleet.

Seafarers will, of course, have their PAYE tax deducted in the normal way and, like every other taxpayer, will be able to claim the rebates and deductions to which they are entitled in respect of their total earnings for the year.
Mr President, I now turn to the details of the International Shipping (Australian-resident Seafarers) Grants Bill.
Part 2, which takes in clauses 3—7, explains the expressions and definitions used in the bill.
Clause 3 defines an eligible ship to mean an Australian-operated commercial trading ship with a deadweight tonnage of 2,000 tonnes or more.
Clause 4 defines Australian-operated ship to include ships on demise charter to Australian entities, as well as ships owned by Australians.

Clause 5 defines the meaning of international voyage. This is an important definition as time spent on international voyages is one of the key criteria for qualifying for the grant. Calls at intermediate Australian ports as part of an overall international voyage are permitted, provided any coastal cargo carried between Australian ports does not exceed the international cargo on board.
In clause 7 are to be found the general definitions such as "seafarer", "Australian-resident seafarer" and "seafarer berth".
These again are important definitions as the grant is only payable in respect of bona fide, duly qualified, seafarers who are ordinarily resident in Australia.

Mr President, I would mention at this point that the term "seafarer berth" is used throughout in the bill in the sense of a crew position or job on the ship; rather than to simply mean a cabin or bed. By adopting the concept of the seafarer berth and using the notional tax on the award wages or enterprise agreement wages, as applicable, for that berth, the computation of the grant amount is reduced to a relatively straightforward calculation.
Part 3 of the bill which covers clauses 8—12, contains the elements for establishing the entitlement to the grant and calculating the grant amount.

Clause 8 sets the basic parameters for entitlement to the grant. Essentially, the grant is payable to the employer of the crew of an eligible ship, which has spent the requisite number of days in international trades.

Clause 9 sets out the method of calculating the amount of grant unit for each seafarer berth. Factored into the grant calculation is the number of days in the year that each berth is actually occupied by an Australian-resident seafarer.

Therefore, Mr President, if any berths are occupied by non-residents or if any berths are unoccupied during a repair or lay-up period, or because the ship is sailing short-handed, then the grant units calculated for those berths will be reduced proportionately.
The grant amount is simply the sum of the grant units for the seafarer berths on the ship.

Clause 10 establishes the eligible employment period, which is the period in respect of which the grant is paid. This clause also determines that the grant is to be paid to the actual employer of the crew and that the employer must be an Australian entity.

A number of ship operators in Australia appoint a management company to look after the day to day running of the ship, including crew related matters such as paying salaries and making the PAYE tax deductions. In such circumstances it would be the management company that is the actual employer, not the operator.

Because of the notional linkage between the grant and crew PAYE income tax, it follows that the employer of the crew is the appropriate recipient of the grant. Clearly if the employer and the ship operator are not the same entity, they will need to reach a commercial agreement on the allocation of the grant monies once paid.

If the employer employs the crew on a ship for the whole year then the "eligible employment period" is the whole year. If the employer only employs the crew for a part year, then the "eligible employment period" would only apply to the part year.

These eligible employment periods are not transferable. For example, if during the period covered by the first employer the ship is wholly engaged in international trading and during the period covered by the second employer the ship is mainly engaged in coastal trading, the international trading days accrued by the first employer could not be transferred to the second employer.
Clause 11 sets out the formula for calculating the minimum number of days in international trading to qualify for the grant.

Mr President, you will note that the formula excludes non-operational days of repair, maintenance or lay-up from the minimum days calculation. There will thus be no advantage for an operator to obtain repairs or lay-up the ship overseas simply in order to accumulate more international trading days.

However, once a ship has crossed the minimum days international trading threshold, then the grant is payable in respect of the berth occupancy over the full eligible employment period, which would include any days of repairs, maintenance or lay-up.
The grant will be paid annually in arrears after receipt of appropriate documentation from the employer.

The amount of grant is determined by clause 12 of the bill. The grant payable is the sum of the notional tax liabilities calculated on the award or enterprise agreement wages relating to the various seafarer berths on the ship.

The method of determining eligibility and calculating the amount of grant is very straightforward and will not impose a significant administrative workload on the employer in substantiating a claim for a grant.
The arrangements will be administered by the Department of Transport, with the departmental Secretary being the nominated decision-maker in respect of applications for grants.

There are appropriate safeguards in the bill to enable authorised persons appointed by the Secretary to make any necessary investigations to verify the substance of claim applications and prevent fraud.

In common with other legislation involving administrative decisions, clause 22 of the bill provides for an Administrative Appeals Tribunal review, if there is dissatisfaction with a decision made in relation to a claim for grant.

The bill also facilitates Parliamentary scrutiny of the scheme. Clause 25 requires the Secretary to submit to the Minister of the day a return of the grants paid in the previous year, and for the Minister to table the returns before both Houses of Parliament within 15 sitting days.

Mr President, through this bill, the crew taxation disadvantages for Australian operators will be eliminated. Furthermore, by providing the benefit direct to employers, the whole amount will be directed to narrowing the competitive gap.
Mr President, this bill, together with the industry reforms implemented through the Maritime Industry Restructuring Agreement, will promote a more competitive international fleet.

It must be remembered that as recently as 25 years ago, Australian shipping had minimal involvement in international trades. Now there are some 30 ships regularly trading overseas. These ships are competing directly with overseas competition at prevailing international freight rates largely by exploiting market niches. This Government's previous shipping reform measures have played a major role in this achievement.

The grant to be implemented by this bill is an integral part of a new shipping reform package which raises the benchmark for Australian shipping and provides the wherewithal to take the industry into the next century.
It continues the cooperative reform process begun in the early 1980s and provides new initiatives to allow Australian shipping to improve its competitiveness in the international shipping market.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
CRIMES AMENDMENT (FORENSIC PROCEDURES) BILL 1995
This bill is long overdue.

Its purpose is to amend the Crimes Act 1914 to implement the recommendations of the ALRC Report No 2 on Criminal Investigation, submitted as long ago as 1975, and reaffirmed in greater detail, after a thorough examination of the issues, in the Fifth Interim Report of the Review of the Commonwealth Criminal Law in 1991. Even in 1975, the ALRC was of the view that `the probative value of this kind of evidence is such that it ought to be obtainable and admissible, provided that enforceable safeguards for the accused are built into the system'. Whatever else may be said about forensic evidence, nobody says that it should be ignored, and nobody says that it should be rejected as a tool of law enforcement.

The Review of Commonwealth Criminal Law noted that there was no general Commonwealth law dealing with the medical or forensic examination of a person in lawful custody, and that the majority of State and Territory laws merely authorised a medical examination where reasonable grounds exist to believe that an examination of a person will afford evidence as to the commission of the crime or offence involved (cf s.353A(2) Crimes Act (NSW), s.236 of the Criminal Code (WA), and s.81 of the Summary Offences Act 1953 (SA)).

In such general provisions, doubt exists as to the extent of the power, even on the basic question of whether or not samples may be taken without consent. The recent Fernando case in NSW clearly demonstrates this. In that case, the two men charged with the murder of nurse Sandra Hoare, refused to supply blood samples and challenged the NSW legislation. The NSW Court of Criminal Appeal held that the legislation did not in fact authorise the taking of blood samples without consent.

Following this decision, an amendment was quickly made to enable blood, hair or saliva samples to be taken in NSW without consent, although no additional safeguards were added at that time. Indeed, the fact that safeguards vary between jurisdictions is of concern. Some of the current legislation contains virtually no safeguards at all. Other acts have basic protections such as examination by a medical practitioner, limitation on the presence of persons of the opposite sex during the examination, and provision to the person of a copy of the report. Even the requirement for a court order is not consistently provided where there is lack of consent or where the use of force is required. For example, none is required in South Australia or Western Australia.

The need for consistent, and if possible uniform, laws throughout Australia, especially those laws which profoundly affect the rights of Australian citizens in the criminal justice system, has been increasingly recognised during the life of this Government. We have seen the passage of the foundation provisions of the Model Criminal Code, which is a major step in modelling a co-operative scheme for removing basic inconsistencies in principles of criminal responsibility throughout Australia. The Crimes (Search Warrants and Powers of Arrest) Act 1994 performed the same function in relation to arrest and search powers.

The time has now come for the Commonwealth to grasp the nettle which has been enjoying largely uncontrolled growth for more than twenty years and apply the same principled and balanced regulation to the role of forensic science in the investigation and prosecution of criminal offences. It is clearly wrong, when, as a nation, we are rightly proud of our record of freedom and justice in a world where, sadly, neither of those things can be taken for granted, that different rules may apply to different groups of Australians depending purely on where they live, some of those rules being uncertain or oppressive.

The Model Criminal Code Officers Committee (which is the body working towards a uniform criminal Code to be adopted by all Australian jurisdictions) prepared a model Forensic Procedures Bill which was widely circulated for comment to about 600 groups and individuals, representing many interests—defence lawyers, investigators, prosecutors, judges, academics, law societies, bar councils, civil liberties groups, human rights organisations, women's groups, victims groups, legal aid organisations, government Departments and interested individuals. When the Commonwealth commenced its own consultation process, a revised bill was again circulated. Over 60 submissions were received, analysed and, as far as practicable, recommendations were incorporated into the bill. Few submissions advocated the complete abandonment of the exercise. Most were concerned with the striking of the correct balance between the civil liberties of the individual and the requirement for the police to have adequate investigative powers.

Both the Model Criminal Code Officers Committees Bill and the Commonwealth Bill are modelled on the Victorian legislation, which, in turn implemented the recommendations of the Victorian Consultative Committee on Police Powers of Investigation. I would say that seldom has a proposal requiring a delicate balance of civil liberties and law enforcement concerns been subjected to such a degree of scrutiny prior to its introduction to Parliament.
I will now describe the effect of the bill and the proposed government amendments.

First, I wish to clarify that nothing in this bill prevents the police requesting non-suspects to undergo forensic procedures, as sometimes occurs, in order to narrow the field of investigation. The proposed legislation applies only to suspects as defined in the bill.

Unlike most of the current state legislation, but consistently with the Victorian provisions, the Commonwealth Bill makes a clear distinction between intimate and non-intimate forensic procedures. Intimate forensic procedures consist of the external examination of the genital or anal area, the buttocks, in the case of a female, the breasts, and the taking of an intimate sample (ie blood, saliva, a buccal swab, pubic hair, and samples taken by swabs, washing, scraping or suctioning or the taking of a cast or photograph or lifting by tape from previously described intimate areas). The proposed legislation does not authorise any internal examinations except of the mouth. All procedures must be carried out by persons appropriately qualified for the particular procedure.

Non-intimate procedures relate to those parts of the body not defined as intimate, the taking of non-intimate samples from non-intimate parts of the body, including from a nail or under a nail, hair other than pubic hair, photographs and casts and, in some circumstances, finger prints, foot prints, toe prints and palm prints. However where a person is in lawful custody the applicable law for the taking of fingerprints, footprints and palmprints is found in Part I AA of the Crimes Act.

In addition to those safeguards providing appropriate protection of a person's privacy and dignity which are common to all forensic procedures (of which I will speak later) unless a suspect gives his or her informed consent after receiving all relevant information, including the right to refuse (all of which must be recorded) no intimate procedure may be performed except by order of a magistrate. However, if a person is in lawful custody, non-intimate procedures may be carried out by appropriately qualified persons as ordered by a constable. These orders are subject to the same conditions as apply when a magistrate makes an order, and can only be made if the non-intimate procedures can be conducted within the custodial time limits provided in Part IC of the Crimes Act. Special procedures providing support and safeguards apply to children, adults incapable of comprehending the proceedings or giving informed consent, and to Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders.
Where a magistrate makes an order for the carrying out of a forensic procedure he or she must be satisfied on the balance of probabilities not only that:

PARA.TAB: the person is a suspect and
on the evidence before him or her, there are reasonable grounds to believe that the suspect committed a relevant offence

SPEECH.PARA: but also that:

PARA.TAB: there are reasonable grounds to believe that the forensic procedure might tend to confirm or disprove that the suspect committed a relevant offence; and
the carrying out of the forensic procedure is justified in all the circumstances.

SPEECH.PARA: The bill also specifies that, in considering the justification of any order, the magistrate must balance the public interest in obtaining evidence relevant to the offence, against the public interest in upholding the physical integrity of the suspect. It enumerates a number of matters relevant to that balancing of interests, including any practicable alternative means of obtaining evidence and any reasons given by the suspect for refusing to consent.

A court order is required, not only for intimate procedures where the suspect does not consent, but also for non-intimate procedures where the non-consenting suspect has not been arrested, where a suspect is unable to give informed consent by reason of youth or mental incapacity, or where the Part IC custodial time limits have expired or will expire before the proposed procedure can be completed. The criteria to be taken into account are the same in each case.

Normally suspects will be present and able to contest any application for such an order. However, urgent interim orders may be sought from a magistrate to carry out a forensic procedure which must be done without delay, for example where the sample to be taken is of a highly volatile or perishable nature. Such applications may be made by any electronic means but the suspect and his or her lawyer (or interview friend for those categories of persons warranting special support) must be given an opportunity to communicate with the magistrate. The magistrate may make appropriate orders, including arrangements for the final hearing of the application. The applicant must record full details of the application and send a copy to the magistrate. If that record does not accord with the magistrate's record in all material respects, the order is taken to have had no effect. Any sample obtained as a result of the interim application may not be analysed unless it is perishable. If it is analysed, the results may not be disclosed to any person unless a final order is obtained. If the final order is not granted, the sample must be destroyed and, if any analysis of the sample was done, all copies of the results must be given to the suspect.

The question of performing forensic procedures without consent on suspects who may or may not have been arrested for the relevant offence has aroused strong feelings in many who provided submissions in the consultation process. It will no doubt concern many of my Parliamentary colleagues, and has been deliberated over by the government at length.
However, in the Government's view, it is justified for the following reasons;

PARA.TAB: The criteria, which I just quoted in some detail, set a very high standard and the magistrate must be satisfied these are met before making an order for procedures to be performed without consent. There must be evidence before the magistrate providing reasonable grounds to believe that the suspect committed the offence. If the magistrate is satisfied on this ground, then he or she must also be satisfied that the procedure is likely to produce probative evidence and, even if it is, that the conduct of the procedure is otherwise justified. That means that the forensic procedure cannot be sought by the police merely as a fishing expedition.

Under Commonwealth law, arrest is a step of last resort. As well as the common law criteria for arrest, other conditions apply. Unless a constable, or in the case of a warrant, a magistrate, believes on reasonable grounds that proceeding by summons would be ineffective to ensure the appearance of the person before the court, or to prevent further criminal acts, including the destruction or fabrication of evidence and harassment of witnesses, a lawful arrest cannot be made.

However, apart from strictly legal justifications, I believe that it is quite reasonable, in the interests of effective law enforcement, to request, and if necessary require, suspects to undertake relatively simple procedures either to exonerate themselves or to provide evidence that could confirm their involvement in a relevant offence. For example a man who is a prime suspect in a rape case may decline to provide a sample of saliva or blood to enable a DNA match with semen found on the victim. There is little difference in principle between evidence obtained from conducting forensic procedures and evidence obtained by means of a search warrant. I simply do not see why, as in the Hyland Case in Tasmania, it should be thought justifiable for police to have to wait 10 years, and for the victim's family to suffer an unresolved situation for 10 years, because a suspect refuses to consent to a forensic procedure and the law has no power to require him to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: The bill provides a comprehensive scheme for obtaining forensic samples from adults, children under the age of 18 years, and persons incapable of managing their own affairs. It sets out the powers and obligations of police when carrying out the procedures, and details the many safeguards to protect the rights of individuals, with particular provisions for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders, children, and the incapable. These include:

PARA.TAB: the right to an interpreter and the provision of full information about the relevant procedure and the suspect's rights in a language likely to be understood by the person;
the right to be present at an application for a coercive procedure to be authorised, to be represented, make representations and to cross-examine;

the right to have a medical practitioner chosen by the suspect, present during most procedures, a medical practitioner of the same sex, if practicable, limitation on the numbers of constables that may be present during the carrying out of a forensic procedure, and restriction of the presence of opposite sex constables to cases of necessity;

SPEECH.PARA: Where reasonable force is permitted to obtain a sample from a non-consenting suspect, the bill expressly prohibits that being done in a cruel, inhuman or degrading manner, and also provides that procedures must be conducted in accordance with proper professional standards. Additionally, the bill makes it clear that nothing in the Part requires a medical practitioner or dentist to carry out a forensic procedure, even though an order may have been made.

A maximum limit of 4 hours on the reasonable time for which a suspect can be detained for the conduct of a procedure is a further safeguard. As in Part 1C, certain time is excluded in calculating the expiry of the four hour limit. Such time includes waiting for the suspect's interview friend, lawyer or doctor to arrive or allowing the suspect to communicate with a friend, relative, lawyer or interpreter.

As well as providing time limits on time for which a suspect can be held for the conduct of the procedure, the new Part repeats those safeguards provided to arrested persons under Part 1C which are applicable to the conduct of forensic procedures. These include the right of certain suspects to interview friends, the right of all suspects to contact a lawyer and to communicate with that lawyer in private whenever possible, the right to an interpreter where necessary, and tape recording of requests for consent and the conduct of procedures.

However, in my view, a most potent safeguard in the present bill is provided by the legislative barrier to admissibility of evidence which is obtained from forensic procedures which are carried out in breach of the legislation. If there is any breach, the prosecution must justify to the court that there are

good reasons why the statutory scheme was not followed. In such a case the probative value of the evidence will not, by itself, justify its admission. The bill indicates a number of matters which the court must take into account in considering whether to admit such evidence, including the gravity of the contravention and whether it was intentional or reckless. Evidence is also inadmissible by the prosecution, with no discretion on the part of the court, where material was not destroyed in the circumstances required by the legislation. There are comprehensive requirements for the destruction of forensic material and inadmissibility of evidence derived from it, where proceedings have not been commenced within a certain period or where they have been finally determined.
I should like to mention three further points which have caused some concern.

The first is the provision which permits the fact of a person's refusal to comply with any reasonable direction for the carrying out of a forensic procedure on a person, given by an authorised person, to be admissible in any proceedings against the person in a court, provided he or she has first been warned of that possibility. That is, admissibility is not limited to proceedings for non-compliance with a court order, or obstructing an officer in the course of his or her duty, but is admissible in the proceedings for the offence for which the forensic procedure was required. Accordingly, it is open to the jury to draw an inference from the person's refusal to permit the taking of the sample, which could involve the conclusion that the person had reason to fear the result of the procedure. One could, no doubt, imagine innocent reasons for resisting certain procedures, and these could be cogently put to the jury by the defence, with supporting evidence. However, I believe that where serious offences carrying heavy penalties are involved, without some serious consequence rendering non-compliance of doubtful value, a mere non-compliance offence with the usual low penalty would be an ineffective deterrent It could defeat the value of the coercive provisions in the legislation—the penalty a price willingly paid by a guilty suspect to avoid the availability of damning evidence of the more serious offence and there would be little point in proceeding with this legislation.

The second matter is the retention and use of forensic material. There are two aspects to this. The bill provides for a database to be set up and maintained for statistical purposes. That database must be designed in such a way that the information contained in it cannot be used to identify any individual on whom a forensic procedure was carried out. Such a database will be used for a purely scientific purpose to develop norms against which the degree of probability that any particular forensic material came from a particular person can be assessed.

The second aspect is the requirement that information about a person obtained from a forensic sample taken under the bill may not be recorded or retained in a personal records system if that sample is required by the bill to be destroyed.

However, nothing in this bill affects the taking, retention, or use of a forensic sample, or of information from that sample, where that is authorised by another law of the Commonwealth or of a State or Territory. It is not intended to repeal any other Commonwealth provisions that might exist—although these can if necessary be revised in due course. Nor is it intended to create any inconsistency with existing State/Territory provisions. It is expected that these will be revised as State/Territory legislation is developed to build up a national uniform scheme.

Finally, I will briefly address criticisms that forensic evidence in recent years has fallen into disrepute, that it is not infallible, and that juries, blinded with science, may give disproportionate weight to evidence of dubious validity. However, as I noted previously, no-one suggests that its use should be abandoned and almost everyone acknowledges its value when properly used.

All I wish to say on that issue, is that the present bill is concerned only with the procedural aspects of collecting and using forensic material. The procedures which are currently available are subject to varying, often minimal, safeguards. This bill aims to balance the need of law enforcement to have access to an investigative resource, which is constantly being developed and refined, against the right of the individual to live free of arbitrary intrusion by the state and free of arbitrary interference with his or her physical integrity and dignity.

The products of the procedures provided by the bill, like the products of any other investigative technique, are weighed and evaluated as they pass through each of the filters provided by our criminal justice system: first by the investigators themselves, then by the prosecutors and their experts, then by the defence and its experts, and finally by the jury. Like all other evidence, it is subjected to the rigours of the adversary procedure. Experts are examined and cross-examined, the judge directs the jury on the applicable law and the standard of proof which must be satisfied, and the jury considers its verdict, taking into account all other evidence admitted as relevant in the proceedings.

If the view that this bill is bad and should be rejected because forensic evidence is less than 100 per cent reliable were applied to all evidence, the criminal courts would be cleared and no-one would ever be convicted. The standard of proof that is applied by the jury in a criminal trial is `beyond reasonable doubt'. That is a high test. In my opinion we must do the best we can with the means currently available to us. We must neither sacrifice civil liberties for expediency, nor reject available investigative techniques because they fall short of the standard of perfection.
The only financial implications arising from the bill involve minor costs associated with training which will be absorbed in the normal budgets of relevant agencies.
Other aspects of the bill are described in the explanatory memorandum which I now present.
I commend the bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth Bank Sale Bill 1995 puts in place the necessary legislative framework for the sale of the Commonwealth Government's remaining 50.4 per cent shareholding in the Commonwealth Bank of Australia (CBA), as announced in the 1995-96 Budget on 9 May 1995.

The Commonwealth's decision to sell its remaining Commonwealth Bank shareholding reflects the significant changes which have occurred in the Australian financial system since the early 1980's and the changes which have occurred in the Commonwealth Bank since 1990.

The deregulation of the financial system and the increased competition within the Australian banking sector in particular, has significantly weakened the case for majority Government ownership of a commercial bank. The Australian banking sector today is significantly more competitive, efficient and responsive to the needs of consumers and the Australian economy in general than was the case when this Government came to office in 1983.

There is no compelling reason why the Government should continue to hold a majority shareholding of a commercial bank in this environment. This view is shared by various State Governments which have recently privatised or announced plans for the privatisation of State Banks. For example, the State Bank of New South Wales was sold to Colonial Mutual in late 1994, the Bank of South Australia was sold to the Advance Bank on 1 August 1995 and the Western Australian Government recently announced its intention to sell a controlling interest in BankWest to the Bank of Scotland.

The Commonwealth Bank has undergone significant change since 1990. It is now a public company operating under the Corporations Law with a substantial private sector shareholding. This follows the two public share offers in 1991 and 1993, which resulted in around 49.6 per cent of the Bank's shares being held by both retail and institutional investors.
Despite being the majority shareholder, it has been the Commonwealth's long standing policy not to interfere in the commercial operations of the Commonwealth Bank.

The sale of the Commonwealth's 50.4 per cent Commonwealth Bank shareholding will provide a number of important benefits. The sale will contribute to the Commonwealth achieving a budget surplus in 1995-96, significantly reducing the need to raise public debt, to the benefit of all Australians and will place the Commonwealth Bank on a similar commercial and legal footing to that of its competitors. The sale will also provide an excellent opportunity for existing or prospective small shareholders to acquire shares in the Commonwealth Bank.
Mr President, I now turn to the details of the bill.
The Commonwealth Bank Sale Bill 1995 provides:
the necessary amendments to the Commonwealth Banks Act 1959 to facilitate the sale of the Commonwealth's CBA shareholding;

detailed transitional arrangements for the Commonwealth guarantee of the liabilities of the Commonwealth Bank and the Commonwealth Bank Officers Superannuation Corporation (CBOSC) and an on-going Commonwealth guarantee of the liabilities of the Commonwealth Development Bank (CDB);
for the conversion of the CDB and the CBOSC from statutory authorities to Corporations Law companies and for the conversion of the statutory superannuation fund of the CBOSC to a trust;

that the Commonwealth Bank body, which includes the CBA and its subsidiaries, will be, as far as practicable, subject to legislation after the sale consistent with other private sector companies and approved banks;

that the Commonwealth Bank body and its shareholders are not disadvantaged under section 63A of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 as a result of the change in ownership resulting from the sale of the Commonwealth's CBA shares;
that the CBA and the CDB will be provided with appropriate transitional arrangements regarding protected business names;

for the retention, post sale, of employee entitlements accrued in pre sale service under the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988 and the Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits Act 1973; and
the necessary consequential amendments to other Commonwealth legislation.

The bill provides appropriate transitional measures for the Commonwealth guarantee applying to the CBA's liabilities consistent with the Treasurer's Budget night announcement. These arrangements ensure that the CBA's depositors, creditors and superannuation fund members are treated fairly as a result of the Commonwealth's sale of its shares. The arrangements are broadly comparable with those applying to the sale of the State Bank of New South Wales.

The transitional arrangements relating to the Commonwealth guarantee of the liabilities of the Commonwealth Bank and the CBOSC commence at the `Effective Date', which is defined as the time at which the Commonwealth's CBA shareholding falls to below 50 per cent, or 9 May 1996, whichever is the later. The transitional period for which the guarantee applies depends upon whether the liability is a demand deposit, a term deposit or any other liability.
The transitional arrangements provide for:
the guarantee of all demand deposits for a period of three years from the Effective Date;
the guarantee, until maturity, of term deposits outstanding at the Effective Date or made during the three years following the Effective Date; and
the guarantee, until maturity, of all other liabilities and off-balance sheet obligations outstanding at the Effective Date.
The bill provides that the Commonwealth will continue to guarantee all of the liabilities of the CDB as is currently the case.

The bill also provides that the Commonwealth will guarantee the liabilities of the CBOSC (or the superannuation fund) for a person who was a member, retired member or beneficiary before the commencement of the relevant provisions of the act. This section preserves for these persons the guarantee currently contained in the Commonwealth Banks Act 1959.

The Commonwealth and the Commonwealth Bank are to negotiate appropriate accountability arrangements relating to the Commonwealth guarantee of the liabilities of the CBA, CBOSC and the CDB. These arrangements, which will be negotiated before the Commonwealth sells any of its shares, will be of a contractual nature and will be binding on the Commonwealth Bank.

The bill provides an exemption from the possible application of section 63A of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 relating to the deductibility of losses on bad debts. This provision seeks to ensure that the Commonwealth Bank body and its shareholders are not disadvantaged as a result of the change in ownership resulting from the sale of the Commonwealth's shares. This is irrespective of whether the sale is structured in such a way that an intermediary or intermediaries are interposed between the Commonwealth as seller and the buyers of the Commonwealth's shares.

The bill also exempts various transactions associated with the sale of the Commonwealth's CBA shares from most State and Territory taxes, levies, fees, duties and charges. This measure is intended to enhance the attractiveness of the sale to potential purchasers. The Commonwealth, however, has indicated its in-principle support for providing relevant States and Territories with an ex-gratia payment compensating them for stamp duty forgone in relation to the sale.

The bill does not impose any legislative restrictions on the ability of foreign interests to acquire shares in the Commonwealth Bank. Post sale, the CBA will be subject to the same foreign investment regulatory framework that applies to other Australian banks.

International investors will be permitted to participate in the public sale of CBA shares as was the case in the 1993 sale. Foreign participation will expand the market for the CBA's shares which is in the interests of all shareholders. It would be pointless to deny such participation when foreign investors can buy CBA shares on the Australian Stock Exchange.

However, the Commonwealth Bank will remain predominantly Australian owned immediately after the sale and will have a dispersed share ownership given the application of the Foreign Acquisitions and Takeovers Act 1975, the Banks (Shareholdings) Act 1972 and the allocation policy which is expected to apply for foreign investor participation in the sale.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Future of the Commonwealth Development Bank

SPEECH.PARA: The proposed sale arrangements not only provide for the retention of the Commonwealth Development Bank with its existing Charter and the Commonwealth Guarantee of its liabilities, but will also enhance the CDB as an independent financial institution aimed at providing specialist banking services to the small business and rural sectors.

The CDB will continue to be 91.9 per cent owned by the Commonwealth Bank and 8.1 per cent owned by the Commonwealth. The Commonwealth will continue to pay an annual subsidy to the CDB to undertake the banking activities defined in its Charter.

The bill provides for the conversion of the CDB from a statutory authority to a public company under the Corporations Law with its own Memorandum and Articles of Association. The CDB's existing Charter will be removed from the Commonwealth Banks Act 1959 and replicated in the CDB's Memorandum of Association.

The conversion of the CDB to a public company with its own Board of Directors will enhance its position as a specialist financial institution. This is consistent with the proposed granting of a separate banking authority to the CDB.
The retention of the existing Commonwealth guarantee arrangements for the CDB will ensure that the CDB can obtain necessary financing on a competitive basis.
Prior to the Commonwealth's CBA shareholding falling to below 50 per cent, a shareholders' agreement will be entered into between the Commonwealth and the CBA on various matters relating to the CDB.

This agreement will detail the annual subsidy determination and review arrangements and will contain an undertaking from the CBA that it will not exercise its voting power to amend the CDB's Memorandum and Articles of Association while an adequate Commonwealth subsidy is in place.
The shareholders' agreement will be made available when it is finalised.

The bill will provide the CBA and the CDB with a 10 year transitional arrangement regarding various protected business names. At the end of the 10 year period, the CBA and the CDB will no longer have any specific legislative protection of their business names. This provision is intended to provide the CBA and the CDB with sufficient opportunity to develop appropriate commercial strategies to utilise the value of their protected names. This will be to the benefit of both existing and future CBA shareholders.

In conclusion Mr Speaker, the sale of the Commonwealth's remaining CBA shareholding will provide a number of significant benefits to the Commonwealth and the Australian people as well as existing and prospective CBA shareholders. The proposed sale arrangements will ensure that the Bank's depositors, creditors and superannuation fund members are not disadvantaged by the sale. The arrangements will also ensure that the specialist banking functions of the CDB are retained to the benefit of the small business and rural communities.
I commend the bill to the Senate and present the associated explanatory memorandum.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Telecommunications (Service Providers Class Licence) Direction No. 1 of 1995, made under subsection 204(1) of the Telecommunications Act 1991, be disallowed.

SPEECH.PARA: The government's intention for the Telecommunications (Service Providers Class Licence) Direction No. 1 of 1995 is that it will promote competition, diversity of content, technical innovation and new investment in broadband services delivered by cable. I am moving this motion of disallowance because it is the Australian Democrats' firm belief that the direction will achieve none of these aims.

PARA.TAB: The direction will not promote competition. Instead, it leaves crucial decisions about competing pay operators' rights of access in the hands of the cable owner duopoly. The direction will not promote diversity of content. What new content industry producers will have the confidence to invest, if access to the main delivery systems is at the whim of the cable owners. The direction cannot promote technical innovation if new services cannot gain access to the level of infrastructure they need at prices which are both stable and reasonable. The direction will not promote new investment in broadband services if those services cannot be assured of the access they need to the paying public.

The reality is that the direction is simply the government's compromise response to the very clever legal device Optus used to ensure that, when it built its broadband network, Telstra could not demand access to that network. Optus determined that it, as carrier, would install and maintain the broadband network, but the network would be owned by Optus Vision and, because Optus Vision would not be a carrier, it would not be covered by the rules requiring carriers to give other carriers access to their networks.

Austel's report on the Optus Vision structure, issued in November 1994, found the structure was legal under the Telecommunications Act. But, in Austel's view, the structure's avoidance of carrier obligations did not fit comfortably within the pro-competitive spirit of the act or the government's policy intentions. Austel's report recommended that Optus Vision should follow the same rules as carriers. Optus Vision should permit carriers and competing service providers to connect to its network on the same basis as required for carrier networks, and Optus Vision should be subject to the same pricing principles and carrier arbitration procedures as the carriers.

The government's response—this direction—falls short of those recommendations. Instead, the direction created a new creature, a carrier associate. Carrier associates have fewer obligations on them than the carriers whose networks they own and control. They are free of the pricing rules covering carriers; they are free of the obligations to provide access to other pay TV operators, which are very widely defined in the direction; and they are free from the threat of an Austel direction to provide defined levels of access to their networks. Not surprisingly, Telstra's response was to immediately create its own carrier associate and gain similar exemptions from carrier responsibility for its broadband network or, rather, the network it is building and then handing to its carrier associate.

The rationale for the direction does make some sense, but not altogether. The amount of capital required for building broadband networks is in the billions of dollars. Carriers need at least some initial period to protect what will be small, but hopefully growing, revenue streams from the networks, and requiring carriers to give open access to a rival would clearly threaten that revenue source. It would be like insisting that every time a developer builds a new shopping centre, he or she must give rival developers access to the new shops. And with the rival's access to new shops goes the loss of profits and the rents necessary for our developer to build the shops in the first place.

The reality is that the networks being built are not like shopping centres. They are being built using the carrier's powers and immunities from compliance with local planning rules and state and territory laws for the protection of national heritage sites and for the protection of the environment. Our hypothetical developer must comply with all relevant rules and regulations to build that new shopping centre—carriers do not. The increasing public outcry against new telecommunications towers and facilities means that these new networks are being built at a great cost to the public.

There is a second and much more important difference between our hypothetical shopping centre and the broadband networks. One shopping centre more or less makes almost no difference to national goals, but the broadband networks will be Australia's information highways to the future and central to Australia's entry into the information age. The broadband highways have the potential to bring new education and health services to areas starved of those services. They can provide avenues for new creative Australian talent. They will be a major factor in Australia's international competitiveness.

As both the Broadband Service Export Group and the government's Creative Nation statement stressed, the information highways are essential for the development of new multimedia content. Clearly, access to those highways is the key for Australian success. Yet the direction governing access to those highways falls short of those national goals. It recognises the legal device of carrier associate and, with that, the evasion by carriers of their full responsibilities for access under the act.

The Democrats do recognise the commercial reality of large investment decisions being made by both carrier associates based on the set of rules provided by the direction, and we are not seeking to jeopardise the very large sums being spent on broadband networks. What we are seeking through this motion is for the government to change the direction's rules to strike a better balance between the need for commercial certainty and the need for access to Australia's new information highways.

Specifically, the Democrats have three major concerns about the direction, and we hope they can be addressed. Our first criticism of the direction is its definition of `pay TV service'. The significance of the definition is that carrier associates must provide access to their networks, except to other pay TV services. Therefore, the wider the definition of `pay TV service', the wider the exemption from that access.

Under the direction, `pay TV service' includes not only subscription television broadcasting services but also subscription narrowcasting services and services which provide movies on demand. Our concern is that there are many services, including community and local services, or very specialised, niche narrowcasting services, which are of no commercial threat to carrier associates, yet which could be refused access to carrier associates' networks under the current `pay TV service' definition.

We understand that both Optus Vision and Telstra Multimedia are developing proposals under which new community and independent content providers can gain access to their broadband networks. To the extent that results in access to more diverse independent programming, we welcome those proposals. Our second concern is the lack of an unbundling requirement to carrier associate networks. Austel can now require carriers to supply specific levels of functionality or transmission capacity to service providers after an inquiry into the feasibility and the impact of making such a direction. Carrier associates are not subject to the same unbundling provisions, even though the networks in question are built by carriers under carrier powers and immunities.

Finally, there are very limited remedies for people seeking access to broadband capacity but refused by carrier associates. Austel has a very general power to promote competition in the telecommunications industry but it does not have specific powers to arbitrate over access disputes or direct that access be provided to carrier associates' networks on fair and reasonable terms.

One solution we strongly urge to the government would be to mandate that each carrier associate set aside a percentage of channel capacity for open access. The danger in not doing so is that, otherwise, carrier associates can insist that all their channel capacity be taken and, therefore, claim they cannot provide access for independent content or service providers. There is no appeal mechanism which could test that claim.

Also, by setting a percentage of capacity for open access, the government can ensure that as broadband network capacity is increased, capacity available for open access is also increased. Open access cannot be seen as a threat to carrier associates. If the press is to be believed, the carrier associates, Optus Vision and Telstra Multimedia, are nowhere near filling the 60 plus channels available on the coaxial cable which they are now installing. Indeed, the fact that Foxtel was willing to go to court to confirm its ability to carry all five free to air television channels must indicate that there is spare capacity somewhere on their network.

What mandated open access may well do is encourage new, independent content and encourage service providers to develop their products and their services. Surely, more independent providers seeking more access can only result in more money in the carrier associates' coffers. We are disappointed that the coalition has already telegraphed that it is not going to support this motion. Their press release calls our motion `well-intentioned but misguided'. While I agree with the first part of the description, I have to disagree with the second. This motion is not misguided.

We recognise that if the direction were disallowed, there would be no rules governing carrier associates' behaviour, rather than the flawed ones now operating. What disallowance would do is force the government to develop new and better rules, something which Senator Alston has tried to do in the past—I might add—and which would strike a better balance between the very understandable and genuine need for carrier associates to have regulatory certainty when making massive investments and the equally important policy objective of having more open access to ensure more diversity of service and content providers.

The other very important objective in moving this motion is to signal now that the Democrats believe this carrier associate regime should end when the direction says it will, in 1997. We note the government's statement in both the telecommunications policy principle post-1997 and the explanatory memorandum that the direction might be continued until 1999 if there is `appropriate competition' in pay television delivery using cable.

Given the proposed Australis-Foxtel merger and the more precarious position of Optus Vision as a result of the merger, it is extremely difficult to even contemplate there being anything like the kind of competition in cable which could justify an extension of this direction. In this we do agree with the coalition's call for an immediate government commitment that the direction will end in 1997 with the beginning of a more competitive telecommunications regime. The government has promised very significant changes in the post-1997 telecommunications regime. Carriers will be differently defined and, if the principles are reflected in the legislation, they will include what are now defined as carrier associates.

The access regime outlined in principles will also be stronger and will require carriers, which would include carriers associates, to give mandatory undertakings about interconnection and access rules. There will be an arbiter, the ACCC, with the powers to scrutinise and enforce those undertakings. There should be no need for this direction in the post-97 environment.

The Democrats will be carefully scrutinising draft telecommunications legislation for the post-97 environment to ensure that the principles adopted by cabinet are translated into a more open access regime which provides a fair return for the large investment needed but which also provides for fairer, more open access rules to encourage the sort of service and the content diversity which will benefit all Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a very important motion. The Australian Democrats, and Senator Bourne in particular, have given it a lot of careful attention. They have addressed many of the issues that have concerned us. I suppose where we disagree is the outcome if the current regime were to suddenly lapse. I do not for a moment think that the government would do anything about it, simply because in the run-up to an election it would suit their purposes to suggest that there was chaos by allowing a black hole to develop. That, in a sense, is a part of the procedural difficulty we have. It is all or nothing. You cannot amend the motion or the direction. You either allow it in whole or disallow it in whole.

PARA.TAB: We have taken the view that we have got this far down the track. Both carriers have been led on, in a sense, by the government to a point where it would be very destabilising to suddenly pull the plug half way through. That is in large part a fault of the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Mr Lee) for taking such an inordinate length of time to make a decision. His original announcement was in November last year. He proposed a regime which was unique, in my understanding, in the world. Australia alone, of all countries, would have a duopoly regime which would allow a duplicate roll out. There was a potential for an overbuild of $3 million to $4 million. That would extend to 1997.

In the classic words, which no doubt were drafted by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), if there was appropriate competition they would extend that regime until 1999. If ever there was a licence for special deals, backroom discussions and grace and favour decision making, surely this has to be it. It is a classic example of the way this government operates. There is no transparency. There are no principles that people can understand. There is no coherence in the regime they put in place. It is all discretionary. `If you do us a favour, we will do you a favour. We reserve the right to decide whether or not we want to help the carriers at a later point in time.' That is an outrageous basis on which to approach this issue.

The government had a number of choices before it back in November last. I am sure the Senate recalls those extraordinary words of the Prime Minister about the Optus Vision proposal being the greatest scam since Murray Farquhar. In typical fashion, the Prime Minister totally distorted that proposal.

We all know there have been exclusive regional franchise areas in places like the US, the UK and Canada. They have generally proceeded on the basis that in a defined geographic area only one carrier has the right to roll out the cable. A fundamental requirement, which as I understand was implicit in the Optus Vision proposal, was that they do it on a common carrier basis. Others would be automatically entitled to access that cable. You would not have duplication. You would have one carrier owning the cable, and other operators having an entitlement to access it. That was one formula that could have been adopted.

Another model, which is certainly not unusual, is to maintain the distinction between carriage and content and to require that there be a utility that owns all the cable and then all those wanting to operate pay television services would interconnect to that system. It would be at arms length. You would not find one carrier beholden to the other. That was certainly an option that was available at that time. Instead, what the Minister came up with was this hybrid and very unsatisfactory compromise that involves 2 1/2 years or possibly 4 1/2 years of duopoly protection.

Once again, I think it is quite clear that they have sought to muddy the waters by including the pay television exemption in the carrier associates direction. The whole concept of carrier associates is a device in many respects to avoid the consequences that would flow from the carriers otherwise being required to provide common carrier facilities which would automatically entitle others to access them. Given that that device is in place, it is simply extraordinary that it took the minister from 24 November last year to 22 August this year to table this direction. Our problem is that, with the best will in the world, the Democrats' proposal does not take account of what water has flowed under the bridge since that time.

There is no doubt that Optus in particular, which is challenging the incumbent and therefore is taking most of the risks in this business—and, after all, Telstra is effectively using taxpayers' funds to fund its roll out—is using private sector funding and has gone a substantial way down the track. To use the blunt instrument of disallowance to effectively change the rules of the game halfway through would introduce a great deal of uncertainty into the environment in which the carriers would be operating. That is why we have made it clear that we are not prepared to simply disallow the entire direction.

There are a number of aspects of that direction that continue to concern us. It is quite clear that the government has given no indication of its intention to extend the pro-competitive open access requirements for telecommunications, which will apply beyond 1997 to broadband interactive services. There is no reason in principle why you should not have the same regimes. There is certainly nothing in the carrier associates direction which would justify that differential treatment.

What we find in the carrier associates direction is a range of qualifications that make it much more difficult for service providers and others to get access to a carrier's cables for broadband interactive services, even to the point where a carrier is allowed to refuse access because it might interfere with their future capacity. That is a tailor-made invitation for carriers to simply argue that at all times there is no surplus. Anyone who is familiar with the bandwidth that can be eaten up with virtual video on demand will understand that it is not a very difficult matter to simply have four or five channels dedicated on a permanent basis to the showing of one particular movie at 15-minute start-up intervals. It is not a very difficult matter to effectively squeeze out your competitors and to argue that there is no surplus capacity.

Our amendment is very much designed to flush the government out. I look forward to Senator McMullan elaborating on what the government's principles are, what would determine the desirability of extending the duopoly, what is meant by appropriate competition, and indeed whether the government has given any thought to that proposition at all other than simply reserving the right to make grace and favour decisions down the track.

We think that is a totally unsatisfactory basis for decision making, but it is almost second nature to this government and part and parcel of the fatigue that has overtaken it in recent years. It is no longer interested in sensible, transparent regimes. It is not interested in giving all those who want to get into the industry a degree of certainty so that they can plan accordingly.

It is very unsatisfactory, for example, that the government simply refuses to address Austel's report on service provider access to the current carriers basic network. Austel tabled its report back in March this year. There has been absolutely no government response to that. There is going to be no mandated interconnect regime, so once again those wanting to compete are left to effectively beg Telstra for access at reasonable rates. There is nothing to stop Telstra saying no. Austel's report states:

SPEECH.PARA: Austel's assessment of the performance of the service provider industry indicates that it is not as yet performing in a way which would be expected from an efficient industry displaying the characteristics of commercially sustainable competition. Austel believes that under the current market conditions and carrier strategies it is highly unlikely that the government's objectives relating to effective competition, increased consumer choice and greater technological and service innovation in the service provider industry are likely to be achieved to a substantive degree.
Then it goes on to say later:

There is little genuine price or non-price competition occurring in the service provider industry. Many customers do not believe that they are receiving the price and other benefits potentially available in an effective competitive market. Currently, profitability across the voice resale segment of the service provider industry is generally low. A major factor which is adversely influenced by the profitability and return on investment achieved within the industry is the range of strategic barriers to entry resulting from actions of one or both of the carriers.

In other words, this is yet again another duopoly arrangement which effectively ensures that there cannot be a competitive market. We find it extraordinary that, whilst the government is at least promising to introduce a pro competitive, open access regime for telecommunications—and I must say I still reserve our position until we see the fine print that will translate those 99 principles into legislative form—the fact remains that at least it is on the record as espousing the principle of competition in the area of telecommunications after 1997. But the government is not prepared to do that in relation to broadband interactive services. That is simply another example of why this industry is fundamentally unhappy with the government's patronage system, which is now endemic.

PARA.TAB: I will be interested to see what the government has to say, given that it will obviously oppose the disallowance motion, as to whether it is in fact prepared to support our call for an immediate commitment that it will introduce an open access regime for cable pay television from July 1997. Indeed, I do not think there is any good reason why the Democrats could not support that proposition as well. Given that they have a fair idea of the lie of the land and the ultimate outcome, it may well be that at least we have achieved something in this chamber if that motion is passed. Irrespective of the result today, I do not think there is any doubt that we both—that is, the Democrats and us—share the view that it is simply an untenable proposition to argue on some unarticulated basis that you ought to be able to extend duopoly arrangements through until 1999.

There is another matter that also gives me concern, and I will listen with great interest to see whether the minister is prepared to respond. If he does not, we will all draw the appropriate conclusions. In an article by Fred Brenchley on Monday this week he talked about the deal that had been originally struck by News with Telstra which gives Foxtel a 25-year exclusivity for pay TV on Telstra's cable system. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Indeed, some analysts believe that the merger fine print even extends this deal.

We are not privy to that deal. I would have thought that the government, as the ultimate shareholder in Telstra, would have every capacity to scrutinise that deal. Given that Mr Lee was boasting on AM only a matter of four or five weeks ago that he has very close and continuing relations with the Telstra board, I would have thought they would have been duty bound to bring the matter before him and to get the government's approval.

PARA.TAB: We know the government turned a blind eye to things like the formation of the Packer-Murdoch-Telstra consortium and Telstra's purchase of 10 per cent of Channel 7 for $60 million. They were very major threshold decisions in terms of blurring the distinction between carriage and content. But the formation of the Foxtel joint venture is another thing again. I would be absolutely astounded if the government was not acutely or intimately involved in the negotiations that led to that agreement.

The government is clearly in a position to throw light on whether Fred Brenchley has it right. I cannot believe that he has. It is possible that there might be a non-compete clause that would say that if either News or Telstra wished to get into the pay television business they had to do it through the medium of the joint venture. In other words, they could not separately compete with themselves as partners in the joint venture. If that were all that was involved in the 25-year restrictive covenant exclusivity clause, it would still allow third parties to have automatic entitlement to access to the cable networks. If Mr Brenchley is right, he is saying that third parties are locked out for 25 years or more. That would make a mockery of even the possibility of extending to 1999. So I hope that the government will clarify the position on that critical issue.

I will conclude by saying that we have a number of very real and ongoing concerns about the implications for competition as contained in the carrier direction. Given the lapse of time and the fact that it is a blunt instrument—it is all or nothing in terms of allowance or disallowance—we are not prepared to support the Democrats' principal motion.

But we do have an amendment which offers a very real opportunity for all parties in this chamber to at least show that it is the view of the parliament that, from 1997, competition ought to be introduced. If that is not the government position—I suspect that it will not be—there will be a very clear difference between the major parties in the run-up to the next election. We will be on the record as being pro-competitive. They will be on the record as once again wanting to do the same old patronage deals to decide when they think it is appropriate, depending on who knocks loudest on their door or who rents them hardest and longest. That is not the basis on which we think decisions ought to be made in an industry that has enormous competitive consequences and opportunities for Australia. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Omit all words after "That", substitute: "the Senate calls on the Government to immediately give a commitment that it will introduce an open access regime for cable pay television from July 1997".

TALK.START.PARA: —This debate could become obsessive in its technicality. It is appropriate that Senator Bourne and Senator Alston, who have been dealing with this in great detail with the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Mr Lee), have not gone into an excess of technicality and eye-glazing detail that becomes possible in some of these debates. We have tried to move generally to the principles with which we are dealing. Some of the issues ranged well beyond the issues that we are dealing with in this disallowance motion. I accept that there is not an infinite number of forums. People took this opportunity to raise some issues. If the minister wishes to respond to those that do not relate particularly to this debate, that is a matter for him. The debate will go on in public.

PARA.TAB: I want to confine my remarks mainly to the central issue of the disallowance and then briefly to Senator Alston's amendment. Nobody would be surprised to know that we are not supporting either motion.

For the record, the background is known to all the participants in the debate. It is necessary to put all the various elements of the government's action in context. On 24 November 1994, Mr Lee announced that the government would act to ensure that the access provisions of the Telecommunications Act 1991 would, with a limited exemption for pay television, apply to broadband cable being installed by the carriers. The catalyst for this was proposals by Optus and Telstra and their partners to construct cable networks to deliver a range of telephone broadband and pay TV services. The announcement also followed a report by Austel on the Optus and Telstra proposals. Direction No. 1 of 1995 gives effect to that policy. That is the sequence of background events.

What is happening? Austel is currently implementing the direction, as set down, by preparing class licences that will enable access by service providers to the broadband cable. It is important to remember that, without the direction, cable that was installed by carriers but owned by a related company—under the mechanism, for example, that Senator Bourne referred to—would not be subject to the access provisions of the Telecommunications Act. Under the act, access provisions apply to cable owned by carriers but not by a related company. Let us look at what it all means for policy. At the end of the day, it is about what the policy principles are and what themes we wish to pursue.

The policy direction provides for access to these broadband networks for the purpose of supplying telephone and broadband services. In some ways, the focus of attention always flows back to pay TV, but we should not underestimate the significance of that to ordinary Australians.

This open access framework should promote competition in telephony, technical innovation and competition, diversity and development of Australian content in the provision of the interactive broadband services of the future. The direction does provide a limited exemption from this access framework where access is required to provide pay television services. The exemption is often what draws the attention. That is not unusual; it is not exclusive to this area of policy—it is where attention tends to focus. But we cannot afford to focus only on that and ignore the implications for other elements of the policy that underpin and the action that flows from the direction.

The exemption will apply, as everybody knows, until 30 June 1997, with a possible extension or a maximum period to 30 June 1999 if there is appropriate competition in the delivery of pay television services using cable. This limited exemption needs to be put into full context. It is only for a limited period and it does give carriers an incentive to roll out their networks rapidly. It also gives a clear indication to industry of when full access to broadband cable infrastructure will be available to all service providers, and a strong signal to the consortia that there must be appropriate competition. It is an exemption that recognises the commercial reality. The need for carriers to have incentives to justify the expenditure is currently estimated to be in the order of $7 billion involved in installing the cable.

The new infrastructure will encourage competition not only in pay television services but also in local calls and a range of broadband interactive services in the years to come. It provides that incentive to cable builders by allowing the owners of the cable to earn revenue from the provision of pay television content rather than revenue from just selling the carriage component of those services.

It is necessary to remember once again for the record—because I know Senator Bourne and Senator Alston know this, but we need to make it clear and more comprehensive—that the existing Trade Practices Act will apply to carrier associate behaviour. That act has well-established provisions to deal with abuse of market power and anti-competitive conduct. We all know that the Trade Practices Commission, as currently constituted, has been prepared to speak up strongly about these issues when they have arisen.

The access framework being established by the direction will also provide an appropriate transition to the open access telecommunications arrangement post-1997. Provision will be made to continue the general exemption for pay television services from the full force of the post-1997 access policy until 30 June 1999, but it will only be granted if appropriate competition exists.

As foreshadowed in the minister's 24 November statement, the government has encouraged both Optus Vision and Telstra Multimedia Pty Ltd and Foxtel to make available some capacity on their networks for community access and education. The government has been advised by both consortia that they are currently developing initiatives to provide services for community and educational purposes. So it is important that we have those elements in the equation that is flowing and which we do not wish to see disrupted by the uncertainty that would flow, inevitably, from this disallowance.

An uncertain regulatory environment which would inevitably follow from disallowing this direction could well discourage investment. It is important that we minimise uncertainty in the industry, given the significance of the telecommunications industry in general in Australian life and the significance of the proposed investments in cable in particular. The direction seems to the government to strike the right balance between encouraging cable roll-out and ensuring open access to the cable infrastructure for all service providers in the medium term. I should have thought we all agree that we want to achieve both those goals—but what is the balance that we want to strike between them?

The policy was first announced in November.
