There has been some issue about whether it has perhaps taken undue time to finalise the direction first foreshadowed in November 1994, but it was a direction that involved complex policy and legal issues. We are dealing with new types of infrastructure and services. There has been extensive public consultation since November 1994 in preparing the direction. I would have thought the Senate would have felt that should be the case; they would have supported that. There have been two full rounds of public consultation since November, two drafts of the direction being circulated to industry, consumer and government groups or their representatives. We appreciate the fact that many people provided comments during the preparation of the direction and put a lot of effort into that. It was greatly appreciated by the government.

On the general question, what we do not want to see, and this is, with regard to this matter, consistent in this small part with Senator Alston's view—I did not agree with some of the other parts—is if as a consequence of a last minute objection to the policy reflected in the disallowance here that were to place in jeopardy continuing investments in the cable as well as to deny access to cable for telephone and broadband service providers. I do not think we can sensibly proceed in that manner.

I will turn in a moment to Senator Alston's amendment, but I want to make a brief response to one other point that Senator Bourne made earlier about disputes between carrier associates and service providers. My understanding is that any dispute between a carrier associate and a service provider about any of the matters covered in the direction may be dealt with by Austel. In accordance with its powers of enforcement of class licence conditions, Austel also has power to investigate complaints about carrier associates not complying with the conditions of their class licence under part 15 of the act.

The government has a strong expectation that carrier associates will cooperate fully with Austel in the implementation of its direction and the administration of the relevant class licences. If it is necessary, we will seek any legislative amendment that may be appropriate to ensure that the clear intentions of the direction can be achieved. I hope that goes to address the concern that Senator Bourne raised on that matter.

Senator Alston's amendment is essentially the tenor of what we expected. I am not sure we actually thought he would move an amendment but the tenor of his remarks was not surprising. He would no doubt be aware that the direction currently provides for the pay television exemption to cease on 1 July 1997, but that the government will review the exemption in the lead-up to that time in a situation where the environment is changing rapidly. To be absolutely specific in the detail about exactly what we are going to do in this rapidly changing environment in 30 June 1997 is extremely difficult and probably in the end not helpful, but the general principle is that if there is appropriate competition and only if that competition is there in the delivery of pay television using cable the government will allow the exemption to continue for the maximum period of five years, that is, until 30 June 1999.

Even then it will not be unlimited; it will a very brief extension. It is not a question of who is for competition and who is against; it is a question of whether three years or five years is the appropriate timetable and what develops over the next 18 months that enables us to make a balanced judgment about whether or not the three or the five is the appropriate timetable; keeping open that option but stating clearly the underlying principle that will determine the decision that we will make then.

When you get to making a decision, all the factors that go in and the principles that are applied to that evidence will have to be made public and be a matter of some debate here in the Senate and in the wider Australian community in the normal nature of decision making in a democracy. So for those reasons, while I think it is an issue of great import and it is appropriate that we have had the debate, the government will not be supporting either the disallowance motion or Senator Alston's amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise briefly to record the Greens' views in relation to this motion of disallowance. I have read Senator Bourne's argument in relation to this proposal. We often hear about competition policy in Australia. What we really see throughout the world is not increasing competition but decreasing competition. Massive investment is required in areas of media and communications. We know that this is one of the few areas within our investment regulatory environment where there are still rules about the level of overseas ownership, the level of cross-ownership, and so on. Other industries are very quickly going into oligopoly or monopoly situations which are not particularly competitive. It simply means that there are not too many rules about what happens these days.

PARA.TAB: In the case of major investments, we are getting massive oligopolies throughout the world. In Australia we are getting cross-ownership of the media, telecommunications, and the superhighway. It is of great concern that, when competition is mentioned, there is some level of understanding of what it means. If what we are doing in regulations is actually entrenching that global oligopoly or creating the potential to entrench the global oligopoly without allowing access for local participation, then perhaps we have to take it more carefully.
On balance, I support Senator Bourne's motion for disallowance. I will not be supporting Senator Alston's motion to change the wording of this motion of disallowance.

TALK.START.PARA: —In summing up, let me say that where Senator Alston and I disagree is in the area of whether competition diversity, technical content and new investment are encouraged by using the current flawed rules, or whether it is encouraged by removing those rules and forcing better rules to be drafted. I believe that removing the rules and forcing better rules to be drafted is preferable. I cannot agree with Senator Alston that leaving them there is a good thing.

PARA.TAB: Senator McMullan mentioned the Trade Practices Commission. That is something that I should have mentioned in the first place and I thank Senator McMullan for reminding me. As everyone here knows, in the past the Trade Practices Commission has viewed pay TV as a part of the free to air system in terms of competition. At the moment the commission is looking into the proposed merger between Foxtel and Galaxy. I hope the commission will look at the system in terms of competition in the pay TV system. If it does that, it will be obvious to anybody whether competition is enhanced or diminished by a merger of two of the three systems now operating.

I was pleased to hear the minister say that Austel has wide powers in relation to disputes involving carrier associates. It was my understanding that it did not, but that it had wide powers in relation to disputes including carriers. I hope we can go back and have a look at Austel's exact powers. If Austel does not have those wide powers in relation to disputes involving associates, I would hope that we would try to give Austel much wider powers in that area as soon as possible.

Senator Alston mentioned the separation of carrier and content. I think it is a good idea. I am glad that Senator Alston thinks it is a good idea. He may recall that this is one of the goals that I tried to achieve when the Broadcasting Services Act was debated in 1993. At that time Senator Alston found that he could not agree with me and, as a result, it was not included in the act. Perhaps he has changed his mind now. We will see what happens next time I try that one on.

I thank Senator Margetts for her support. I agree that competition is diminishing all over the place at an extraordinarily rapid rate. That is certainly occurring in the pay TV industry at the moment.

Of course carriers want regulatory certainty. But if the carriers persist in using contortionist legal devices to ensure that they can get around the rules—which is exactly what they do all the time—then they must expect that the parliament, the ultimate regulator, will try to bring them back to the original spirit of the legislation. Let me just remind everybody that we are trying to achieve the promotion of competition, of diversity of content, of technical innovation and of new investment. I do not believe that this direction achieves any of that.

On Senator Alston's amendment, I have said all along, for weeks, that I agree with what he is saying here. But this is second best to my motion. Certainly, this should not go until 1999; it should finish in 1997 at the absolute, complete and utter latest. I agree with Senator Alston but, unfortunately, his motion has to come up before mine is voted on. I think my motion is a much better option than his motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —You know yours is going to lose, but you can make sure ours wins.

—That is a very good point. Senator Alston says that mine is going to lose, but I could make sure his will win. I would rather mine won. This may surprise you, but I would rather mine won. So I am going to vote against your amendment and hope that mine wins. Something may happen in the 50 seconds in between the two.
—An act of God.

—You never know. You must never give up hope, Senator Alston, and I won't. But let me also say to Senator Alston: if you want to put this up as a separate motion at any time, I will agree with it and you will have it through. I hope you will do that. Let me finally commend my original disallowance motion to the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Alston's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.
Original question put:
That the motion (Senator Bourne's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Employment, Education and Training References Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Senate Employment, Education and Training References Committee on its inquiry into the past, present and likely future trends in long-term unemployment and the patterns of work and unemployment among older workers, particularly those who have been made redundant or who have taken early retirement, together with the submissions received by the committee and the transcript of evidence.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I have pleasure in tabling this report of the Senate Employment, Education and Training References Committee on its inquiry into long-term unemployment. On 17 November 1994, the Senate asked the committee to inquire into these matters. Most specifically in relation to long-term unemployment, we were asked to inquire into three broad aspects: first, to examine the research on the causes of long-term unemployment; second, to evaluate established programs and current opportunities which enable the long-term unemployed to return to the work force and reveal any legislative or other regulatory mechanisms which constrain those opportunities; and, third, to identify, describe and evaluate alternative innovative strategies being implemented in Australia and elsewhere, which could lead to the re-engagement of the long-term unemployed.

PARA.TAB: That inquiry has now been completed after hearings held in all territory and state capitals, especially urban and suburban areas that are most affected by long-term unemployment—such as Campbelltown, on the outer edge of Sydney in New South Wales, and Broadmeadows in Victoria—as well as regional centres of high long-term unemployment—such as Tweed Heads, Whyalla, Burnie and Launceston. Evidence given in those hearings was collected along with 170 submissions, and they revealed that unemployment, especially long-term unemployment, is one of the most desperate problems facing this country.

One submission to the inquiry from a 42-year-old man who had been without full-time work for 12 years summarised the feeling expressed by many. He said, `I feel abandoned by the system, exploited by the system, abused by the system and held captive by the system.' A woman made redundant from a middle-management position by a municipal council amalgamation commented on how she was `avoided and made to feel a nuisance'. `There was,' she wrote, `a feeling of embarrassment on the part of my employers—a blame the victim mentality.'

Losing a job for many of these people turns out to be the first shock. The difficulty of finding another job is the next. Many believed that they would not get another job. They learnt not to expect one to avoid that crippling sense of disappointment. We had on one occasion a man appear before us who had brought along his sheaf of 200 applications that he had put in for jobs over the last two years, and he had still not received a job.

The long-term unemployed now comprise nearly a third of all Australia's unemployment—a massive rise over the last 10 years. Not only is this a misuse of Australia's human resources, but it multiplies all the ills that are attendant upon being unemployed. It is itself a significant contributor to unemployment. Several groups in our society suffer disproportionately—the youth, the older workers, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, people in some of the rural areas and in the outer suburbs, and people from non-English speaking background.

There has been wide debate about the reasons for this unemployment and what are the appropriate solutions, but the fact is that the debate has produced little by way of major breakthrough to date in overcoming unemployment. This is the matter that gives this inquiry, and the results that come from it, some sense of urgency.

The government heard a very wide range of evidence on what has been happening in this country with the unemployed and with the programs that governments have adopted to bring about a change. What we heard broadly—and the focus, of course, was on current programs—was that Working Nation is not working. Its failure is shown by the fact that, even during the huge boom that we were supposed to have had last year, although long-term employment did come down, there was still a very large entrenched pool of long-term unemployment in this country after the last recession, as there has been after each recession. What tends to happen after a recession is that there is a larger pool of long-term unemployed left than there was after the previous recession. This is a ratcheting up effect and is perhaps one of the most disturbing aspects of the development of this problem.

When we looked at how government programs are addressing these problems, we found major concerns around the country. In the case of the labour market programs, we heard major criticisms of the fact that they were tending to churn the dole queues. There was a negative perception of training, and that perception was not confined to the unemployed. There were doubts over whether Working Nation was decreasing unemployment or merely recycling the unemployed.

Churning the dole queue was an expression we heard in many hearings. The labour market programs seemed in a lot of instances to be recycling the participants, who may go into job training programs for six months but, when they come out at the end of it, a lot are not being placed. We also received evidence that what we are looking at is people being placed for six months and then returned to the ranks of the unemployed because the economic situation in the area is on the downturn. These people face the very real prospect of again becoming long-term unemployed. What we have had is a recycling factor as the dole queue was being churned.

TALK.START.PARA: —So you tell us your solutions now.

—You will get your chance in a minute, Senator Carr. We will get to the solutions. You have a look at the 24 recommendations which you should have agreed to. Programs recycling participants are just costly, short-term bandaids. It was stated in the evidence that participants in work experience programs such as Jobskill, after six months of feeling really happy and up and going, all of a sudden found their placement ended—and they were dead in their tracks.

SPEECH.PARA: Many expressed despair at the outcomes of these programs. One very sad submission stated that it is more comfortable to remain lying in the gutter than to be picked up and dropped back again.

PARA.TAB: With this churning of these training programs involving some work and some training for the long-term unemployed, that is exactly what was happening to them because, in the end, half of them did not receive a job; they went back not to becoming long-term unemployed—by the government's definition—but to the start of the queue. They were newly unemployed, according to the government. So a lot of this drop in long-term unemployment has largely been an illusion. People have been redefined off the long-term unemployment list, just as we find broadly with unemployment that we have great numbers redefined off the list by being called mature age and picking up a benefit on that basis.

One of the most interesting graphs in this report shows not only the government official unemployment rate but also the unofficial unemployment rate; all those people who are desperate to get work but cannot. It includes people who are maybe working a day a week and would really like to work five days a week; and people who have just given up. If you take these figures—and the statistics are in the report—you can in effect double the unemployment rate in this country.

It is a major tragedy that we face that when we got to the height—or should I say the depth—of the last recession, we had, in effect, not 11 per cent unemployment but a real unemployment rate of over 20 per cent. People were desperate to receive jobs but there was just no work available for them.

One of the major problems with Working Nation and a lot of the government programs is that they are trying to hide the extent of the problem and make out that the rate is not as high as it is. There is a huge danger for society in that because if the public is lulled into a false sense of thinking, `Oh, the problem has been fixed,' when it has not been fixed, they do not give it a priority. We are storing up major long-term problems in society. We are developing a social underclass where in some cities and country areas there is more than one generation of unemployment; sometimes there are up to three generations. There are families where people have known no work at all. This not only does tremendous harm to society; it does great harm to individuals.

Some of the more serious criticisms in the report suggest that programs not followed by work are of little value in economic terms and harm the unemployed, particularly older workers. The two major programs, Jobstart and Jobskill, which are used for the long-term unemployed, have caused great resentment among people. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to speak to this report and to put before the Senate the minority report which has been prepared by government senators. This is obviously an important issue which all senators would share in terms of their concern about the very high and unacceptably high levels of unemployment in this country. This issue ought to have been able to attract broad support, but the politicisation of this matter, in terms of the election context, meant that was never possible.

PARA.TAB: This report was commissioned on 17 November last year. Less than one year into the operation of Working Nation, you have made up your minds that this was a failure. You determined from the very beginning that we were going to have a political inquiry into the long-term unemployed. You resolved that and you have repeated that many times since. I refer to the headline in the Age of 5 July 1995—`Dr Kemp: Working Nation a failure'.

You have declared again and again that the whole issue of long-term unemployment was a political one. You would seek to exploit the misery and suffering of Australian workers. You sought to take miserable, political advantage of what is a very serious social problem in this country.

What have you said in terms of solutions? Not a word! The hypocrisy of coming in here with your crocodile tears! Your concern about the unemployed goes to the extent of not having one solution, not one answer to the inherent problems of inequality and poverty that exists in our society.

You had the opportunity, and this was a golden opportunity for the conservatives in this parliament, to actually come forward with your ideas on how to resolve this very difficult problem. You missed it. You squibbed it again.

When all is said and done, you only have one solution. That solution is to deregulate the labour market, to cut the wages and conditions of the Australian working people. That is your solution to unemployment. That is your solution to everything. Your solution is to destroy the organised labour movement in this country and, with that, the living conditions of working people.

What have you said in the report? We have the ideological shibboleths of the Liberal Party coming forward. The miserable and petty minded attitudes of the Liberal Party are coming forward yet again. Cut wages. Cut payroll tax. Undermine the working conditions of Australians. Return taxation powers to the states. It is quite clear in this report that is where you are going.

You have suggestions which are quite clearly out of date. You have not recognised the statements made by the government last week. You are out of date again. You cannot even manage to organise your political stunts in such a way as to recognise the current position. What a pathetic effort.

You say Working Nation is a failure. You do not recognise the enormous success that has been achieved through Working Nation. For a start, you do not have the basic principle of having a political objective of trying to reduce unemployment.

The government said that its objective is to reduce unemployment to the rate of five per cent by the turn of the century. What is your suggestion? Nothing. You said, `It won't work.' That is it. That is as far as it goes. You do not have any policy to address fundamental issues.

There has been success. You do not recognise that employment growth in this country has been remarkable. There have been historic highs. The Australian of Wednesday, 13 September, stated that the long-term jobless rate had dropped to a four-year low. This is the failure that you acknowledge! That is what you say is your position—failure. You predicate everything you do on the presumption of failure. The only failure here is your failure to come up with any workable solutions for the unemployed.
There has been a drop in unemployment in this country. It has dropped to 8.5 per cent from 11.2 per cent. We are well on the way to achieving the target of five per cent by the year 2000.

In terms of vocational education and training, this government is doing more than any government in Australia's history. What do you say? You say we are doing too much. Your complaint is that the Labor government does too much. That is all you are about.
You say we have to cut revenue and the expenditure of government. You say we have got to make sure the public sector is lean and mean. You are saying we cannot do as much as we are doing.

You do not have any answers in terms of the real demands the Australian people are putting on all of us. In your majority report you have basically failed the fundamental test of politics in this country—that is, to come up with some ideas on what you are going to do. We indicate in our report a series of proposals that acknowledge the enormous contribution that Working Nation has made. We acknowledge that more can be done. We say that there is always more that can be done and not what you say, which is that too much is being done. We say that there could be more done in terms of industry policy. We say that more can be done in the area of the provision of physical and social infrastructure.

We believe that the states are hacking away at the education systems of this country. They are hacking away at the health systems of this country. They are hacking away at the living conditions of Australians. They are undermining the work of the national government in terms of trying to restore full employment to this country.

What do you put? You put to us propositions such as the one that Mr Costello put to Prue Goward in June 1995, which was that $11.7 billion has to come out of the public sector. You say that the labour market has to be deregulated. What you really mean, as indicated by Mr Howard, is that the jobsback policy has to remain.

You say in terms of industrial relations and the freeing up of the labour market that workers' conditions have to be reduced. You say that workers are entitled to remain on an award. What you mean is that, given that 3.6 million workers will change their jobs every three years, 3.6 million workers will automatically be outside of your inadequate concept of a safety net. If we ever had a Liberal government, 3.6 million workers every three years would be faced with a situation, as we have seen in Western Australia and Victoria with Jeff Kennett, where contracts would be imposed. This would see a reduction in the standards of living for workers.

What we are suggesting is that there needs to be a sustained period of economic growth. Only a Labor government can deliver sustained economic growth. We say that there has to be a stop to the states hacking into the social fabric of this country. There ought to be things done in relation to further provisions in social security in the longer term as we move towards achieving five per cent unemployment. It will be difficult to get below five per cent and additional measures will have to be taken.

There has to be more work done in the education area and there have to be provisions made to make sure that the states do their jobs in ensuring that retention rates are maintained. There has to be work done in terms of higher education to ensure that the employment and growth implications of the higher education sector are realised. In that regard, we drew attention to a report prepared by DEET, which is a couple of years old, which looks at creating economic growth through enterprise generation and industry research partnerships. We suggest that more action can be taken there.

We suggest that more work can be done in terms of industry policy. We are hoping that the government's innovation statement will provide the vehicle to achieve that. We want to see the high performance industries encouraged, the import replacement industries encouraged, the expansion of export industries encouraged and the promotion of industry modernisation. There ought to be closer partnerships between employers and government.

What we are saying is that in terms of attitudes you have failed yet again. You have sought to have one policy articulated which slashes workers' pay and conditions, undermines public sector conditions and destroys the social wage. That means that under a Liberal government very large numbers of people would suffer in terms of wages, conditions and services provided such as education, health and housing. Your policies would exacerbate unemployment and the inequalities of wealth and power in this society. As a consequence, you do not have any answers other than making the situation worse.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Troeth Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would also like to comment on the Senate Employment, Education and Training References Committee report. I would like to draw attention to Senator Carr's usual tired diatribe on the inadequacies of state Liberal governments. Why should Working Nation not be subject to scrutiny, Senator Carr, in view of the vast amounts of government money that is spent on the schemes that you list on page after page of the minority report? Why should we not look at these schemes to see if they are working properly?

PARA.TAB: You would be surprised to learn that some of the schemes which we looked at are working properly—so properly and so successfully that the most successful ones were promptly chopped off and made redundant so they did not apply to the unemployed anymore. There was not one word in your remarks of genuine concern for unemployed people. You are running the usual political agenda of bashing any initiatives that the opposition puts forward.
In this majority report, we have made recommendation after recommendation of the way in which the existing programs could be made to work better. For instance, recommendation No. 1 states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee recommends that mature age workers (35 and over) who become unemployed be eligible to access labour market programs within three months of becoming unemployed.

In that way they would get quicker access to being re-placed into the employment market. As Senator Tierney said, it has only been reduced to six months, not 12 months. The committee also recommended that:
. . . mature age workers be eligible to access case management assistance and advice in the months preceding the loss of employment.
In other words, they do not have to be unemployed to have access to case management advice, which in many cases takes many months. Recommendation No. 3 states:
The Committee recommends that more Mature Workers' Centres be established in country and regional centres.
If that is not making positive recommendations, I would like to know what is.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope they get a bit better than that.

—They do, Senator Collins. Unemployment is unwelcome whatever its duration but long-term unemployment has particularly disturbing ramifications. The children of unemployed parents have 25 per cent more serious chronic illness, are injured more often and are more likely to suffer deafness than children of employed parents. The manager of a Victorian non-government agency confirmed there were increasing distress levels and an increase in loss of identity among the young with continuing unemployment.

PARA.TAB: One area most severely affected by long-term unemployment is outer west Melbourne where the long-term unemployment rate is eight per cent. My electorate office is in Broadmeadows, which incorporates this region. I had a gentleman in my office the other week who was literally crying with frustration because he had been unemployed for two years and he did not know where to turn. If all these programs are working so successfully, why can he not get a job?

During the hearing we saw witnesses who came from regions such as Broadmeadows who have been stigmatised by unemployment. One young person from Campbelltown, south-west of Sydney, said, `I lived in Campbelltown and people did not want people from Campbelltown.' Those offering training and employment services in the area also spoke of difficulties in placing people in employment because of the stigma attached to the region. There is no doubt that unemployment has become endemic in certain regions. Another frequent criticism heard during the hearing, and one which the coalition has made often, was that all the training programs in the world are useless if there are no jobs at the end of them.

TALK.START.PARA: —We want to hear your policy.
—These are your policies we are talking about, Senator Murphy. It is your government which is running these programs and they are not working.
—What about your policies? Where are they?
—We have them, and they will be unveiled in due time.
—We are always open to good suggestions.

—You will need them in the run up to the election. The honourable member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp), the shadow minister for employment, has regularly stressed concern that training programs are used merely as a smokescreen to get people off the unemployment queues. It is a well-known fact that people only need to be in training or study for one hour per week to be removed from the unemployment statistics, and that no doubt accounts for the drop in unemployment statistics.

SPEECH.PARA: Page 60 of the report says:

Too often there was a mismatch between the training offered, the talents and abilities of the unemployed person and local employment opportunities. There was a perception among the older unemployed, many of the long term unemployed and the jobless in regional areas with severe structural unemployment that no amount of training will make a difference, and that DEET programs are no more than time fillers.
People finish the training programs and start looking for a job. Because they have been trained wrongly or the training program is out of date, there is simply no job for which they can apply.

PARA.TAB: The South Australian executive officer of a training scheme in Whyalla concluded:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . people are sick and tired of training for the sake of it . . . They are disillusioned with training programs that get them nowhere.

There appear to be many elements in this debate. One of the strong facts that came out was that people need to be picked up in the very early months of unemployment while they still have job skills and motivation. One witness said this to the committee:
We need to get to people before they become demotivated and totally debilitated.

There appears to be an element of self-perpetuation in trying to solve long-term unemployment only by waiting until people enter long-term unemployment. The solution must be in part preventative, with early intervention.

PARA.TAB: We need greater flexibility in the delivery of services. When you are over 35 or 40, time becomes very important. You cannot afford to wait six or 12 months, because you slip further behind in the job stakes. This was also highlighted in relation to non-English speaking background job seekers. Not only do non-English speaking background job seekers have difficulty in relation to the problem of unemployment itself; they also face a language barrier. While the minority report quotes that language programs are available to people, they are not the sorts of language programs that are needed to get people ready for employment. This was another element of the debate brought out in Broadmeadows. It is an area with a large ethnic population.

We need much greater flexibility and a much greater sharpening of focus on local problems and the way in which they can be addressed. We heard of some excellent initiatives during the hearings. One was the Forty Plus Employment Group in Ballarat. This group was formed in 1993. It evolved from a vocational services project of the Ballarat rotary clubs. In February this year, they opened an Aussie Workways Enterprise Centre. It was designed to allow mature age unemployed people to work together and assist each other. The main purpose of the group was to establish viable and sustainable enterprises. At this point of debate, there are now over 100 people involved in the organisation. They have a five-year plan to establish Aussie Workways as a major facility for employment generation in Ballarat.

This sort of initiative should be encouraged. Local people know best what local jobs are available and the sort of training that should be available in their local area. As I said, some successful programs have been shut down. We came across instances of JPET in Tweed Heads and Burnie being shut down because it worked well. A job club situated outside a Brisbane jail assisted ex-prisoners to find jobs. It worked well, so it was shut down.

The solutions to long-term unemployment need to be wider ranging than training programs, which have been shown to have very little credibility in the community. A whole extra range of policies should be adopted. Senator Carr's list of programs is there. No-one denies that the programs exist, but they are not working. He needs to concentrate on outcomes, not processes. I commend this committee's report. I endorse its recommendations. I also commend the work of the secretariat.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Childs)—Order! The time for the debate has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murphy Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Select Committee on Unresolved Whistleblower Cases, together with the submissions received by the committee and the transcript of evidence.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: The select committee was established to focus on certain Queensland whistleblower cases and their lessons for the Commonwealth legislation on whistleblower protection which had been proposed by the Select Committee on Public Interest Whistleblowing. The Senate agreed to widen the committee's inquiry to include other cases arising from the previous select committee.

PARA.TAB: However, the committee received a significant number of submissions from other people who gave evidence or provided submissions to the previous committee and a number of additional cases were also referred to the committee by way of submission. In order to meet its terms of reference and to give sufficient consideration to cases, the committee agreed that it could only focus on those cases involving people who had given evidence to the previous committee.

The committee understands the disappointment of many people who made submissions to it on the understanding that the committee may have been able to take up their case. We sympathise with the dilemma many of these people were in as a result of their whistleblowing. We found their submissions valuable in helping us to appreciate the widespread nature of whistleblowers' concerns and in clarifying many of the issues relevant to whistleblower protection legislation.

The committee's inquiry reinforced the conclusions and recommendations of the Select Committee on Public Interest Whistleblowing. The committee repeatedly heard of the devastating impact that whistleblowing had on the lives of the people involved. Many of the people who gave evidence suffered employment-related reprisals and their health and family life were adversely affected. This evidence supported the need for whistleblower protection legislation as recommended by the previous committee.

However, legislation may not be able to cover all contingencies envisaged by whistleblowers. The committee acknowledges that a number of states and the ACT have already enacted legislation in this area. It recognises the jurisdictional and constitutional difficulties requiring separate Commonwealth and state legislation, but considers the formulation of uniform and complementary legislation as essential if we are to achieve a fairer and more equitable process in the area of whistleblowing.

The committee agrees that attitudinal change towards whistleblowers and the investigation of their complaints is imperative within public and private sector organisations and the community generally. The committee notes that public sector developments in ethics awareness and fraud control are taking place. It is essential, however, that if these developments are to have value, they must be strongly promoted and encouraged by senior management and not simply remain as rhetoric. The Public Service Commission and its new commissioner have a crucial role to play in this regard.

The cases considered by the committee demonstrate the difficulties people have in raising their concerns and having them investigated in an objective and independent manner. So often whistleblowers were frustrated in their attempts to right perceived wrongs by investigations limited by the letter of the law.

These difficulties, when combined with reprisals and detrimental consequences for health and family, often resulted in a loss of faith in the system—which is supposedly designed to protect and support them—and generated a general feeling of helplessness. This can force whistleblowers into obsessive behaviour and pursuit of their case with a consuming passion which can then result in a loss of judgment and objectivity in their actions.

The whistleblowers who gave evidence to the committee constantly emphasised the need for independence in public disclosure or whistleblower protection legislation. The previous committee concluded—and this committee concurs—that at the Commonwealth level the most appropriate approach is to establish a small yet powerful independent oversighting agency directed and controlled by a board consisting of representatives from government, parliament, whistleblower and community groups. This approach recognises that investigation of complaints and protection of whistleblowers should be primarily undertaken by existing organisations but with oversight by the proposed agency.

The committee acknowledges the concerns that whistleblowers have with the capabilities of a number of existing organisations. The committee believes that with the strengthening through legislative means of the powers and responsibilities of these organisations, they should develop a greater empathy with whistleblowers and a greater responsiveness to their disclosures.

In its report, the committee also discussed a number of detailed issues relating to whistleblower protection legislation. They include the importance of an initial independent screening to sift the vexatious and trivial allegations from genuine public interest disclosures. People whose disclosures came within the auspices of proposed whistleblower protection legislation could be assured of being directed to an appropriate place for their disclosure to be examined. In this way, no whistleblower would be stranded without knowing where to turn for assistance.

Other issues considered by the committee included the provision of counselling, support, advice and assistance; the conduct of investigations, in particular the public interest value of open hearings and the application of rules of natural justice, not just for the whistleblower but, equally importantly, for the subject of any allegations; access to legal aid and assistance; retrospectivity in legislation; and recourse to the media.

In terms of witnesses and cases, one of the key witnesses to the inquiry was the CJC, which is established under Queensland legislation. It is the responsibility of the Queensland Parliament to determine the functions and powers of the CJC and how it performs its duties. The committee was mindful that a comprehensive report reviewing the CJC had been presented by the Queensland parliamentary committee oversighting the CJC earlier this year and was still under consideration. The committee focused on the role and conduct of the Criminal Justice Commission only in relation to the whistleblower cases it considered. Nevertheless, the committee made a number of observations concerning the CJC.

It is important to remember that the CJC was established as a direct result of the Fitzgerald inquiry. It is an independent and highly powerful organisation. Although the Fitzgerald report highlighted the difficulties of balancing accountability with the need for independence, the resultant accountability is limited. A person dissatisfied with the actions or conduct of the CJC has recourse to the Supreme Court or a parliamentary monitoring committee. The committee is aware of reports in the Queensland media critical of the CJC. It is possible that these critical reports result from the limited accountability options available to people so that they turn in frustration to the media.

The CJC appears to have adopted an embattled and very defensive approach in response to criticism. It has responded in several cases by attacking individuals at a personal level. Whether or not these people provoke such a response by outrageous allegations of their own is immaterial. I do not believe that it brings credit upon a public institution to respond in such a vitriolic manner. Whistleblowers can have no respect for such an organisation and are deterred from seeking assistance from it. The committee was concerned from the evidence it received at the CJC's approach to investigations. The CJC indicated that it was constrained in what it can do by the powers prescribed under its act. Whilst accepting this, the committee believes that the CJC could have done more within its powers to investigate certain cases more fully.

In relation to the cases considered by the committee I would like to make a number of personal comments. In respect of the shredding of the Heiner documents I do not believe there is any evidence of a political conspiracy on behalf of the government. A newly elected government was confronted with a problem created during the term of the previous administration. The government sought advice through the correct channels and, irrespective of whether that advice was correct or not, it acted upon the advice it was given. Nevertheless, from an administrative viewpoint the individuals involved could certainly have been handled more considerately and lot of unnecessary stress and heartache for them could have been avoided.

In the matter of Gordon Harris and John Reynolds, it is clear to me that the actions taken against Mr Harris and Mr Reynolds demonstrated a classic whistleblower dilemma whereby the whistleblower, rather than the disclosures, becomes the focus of attention. The investigations, court cases and appeals to which Mr Harris and Mr Reynolds have been subjected boiled down to Mr Harris being found guilty of disclosing information contrary to the Police Administration Act—an offence determined by a magistrate to be so trivial, and with such mitigating circumstances, that Mr Harris was discharged without having a conviction recorded. It was the committee's view that the severity of the reprisals to which Gordon Harris and John Reynolds were subjected could not be justified and I believe the state should consider some form of compensation for these two people.

The other cases considered by the committee all demonstrated in their own way aspects of the problems encountered by whistleblowers and deficiencies in the current systems in which they must seek resolution to their claims. A particular problem, highlighted in the case of Mr Bill Toomer, is that of considering cases many years after they have occurred. Witnesses have moved on—
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Chapman)—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could he be given leave to complete the statement?
—We are going to run out of time in four minutes. Could I ask for how long leave is sought?
—Incorporate it.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Chapman)—Senator Murphy, you can seek leave to incorporate the remainder.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to finish about one-quarter of this speech and then incorporate the remainder.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I was saying in relation to Mr Toomer's case, evidence may be difficult to obtain and procedures undergo significant change. Mr Toomer's case also highlights the problem of different organisations investigating the same case. In this instance, the AAT and the MPRA conducted inquiries on the same issues but reached markedly different conclusions. However, I believe Mr Toomer has suffered greatly, both personally and financially, as a result of incorrect decisions and poor administrative procedures and, despite the length of time that has passed, he should at least be exonerated from the findings against him with due consideration being given to compensation.

PARA.TAB: I would like to acknowledge the cooperation of all members of the committee in this inquiry. I particularly thank the members of the committee secretariat—the people who organise, study, advise, and do just about everything and anything to ensure that the committee can function and achieve its objectives. To the committee secretary Elton Humphrey, research officers Christine McDonald, Barbara Allan and Rod Adams, and executive assistant Kate Tremble, I extend my personal thanks for their unswerving cooperation and dedication to the task at hand which was not easy.

TAB.EMPHASIS: The remainder of the speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: General Issues

PARA.TAB: The evidence received by the Committee not only highlighted the problems of whistleblowing in general, but also identified a number of other general concerns in the areas of higher education, Commonwealth/State jurisdiction and environmental protection. These primarily related to issues of accountability, but specific shortcomings should be addressed.

SPEECH.PARA: Conclusion

PARA.TAB: Some members have strong views on certain issues, and I am sure they will express them. The Committee has nevertheless presented a unanimous report.

I would hope that the individuals whose cases have been considered by the Committee can gain some solace from the opportunities provided by this inquiry and the observations the Committee has made on their cases. Hopefully they can continue with their lives knowing that the suffering they have endured by blowing the whistle has been recognised and hopefully will have significantly contributed to the development of procedures which will reduce the likelihood of people similarly suffering in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the report. Senator Murphy has made the usual political statement. However, the report was unanimous. I want to make the point that the Heiner documents should not have been shredded. Gordon Harris and John Reynolds were badly done by and we said that they should receive compensation. We also recommended that compensation should be considered for Mr Toomer. I think those three salient points need to be stated.

—I would like to endorse the remarks that have been made by Senator Herron. The one statement that I need to make is that, having begun in a very sceptical state of mind when this inquiry was launched, I turned around 180 degrees. I must say that I am appalled at some of the activities of the Criminal Justice Commission in Queensland. As one who supported the establishment of that commission and the Fitzgerald inquiry, I have come to believe that whistleblowers in Queensland certainly need the support of the public and of this Senate.

—I think tribute needs to be paid to the chairman and the members of the committee, especially the secretariat. This report, with its wonderful cover with so whimsical headlines as `The price of nice' and `Whistle while you work', contains an enormous amount of blood, sweat and tears.

PARA.TAB: The blood relates to the suffering and persecution of many whistleblowers, some who have been named and some unnamed. The sweat represents the hard work of many people—certainly the committee, but especially the secretariat and also the many people of all different kinds who gave testimony to the committee. I think they should be thanked for that cooperation—sometimes willingly given and sometimes not.

Finally, I come to the tears. This is one of those committees where it has been a real pleasure to work with people to try to work together for good. It is a great shame that the government's response to the first report on public interest whistleblowing was not available to be incorporated in the consideration of this one. I just add my words to those of other members of this committee and really hope that the whistleblowers will feel in some way supported by the efforts that have gone into the report.

Debate resumed from 23 October, on motion by Senator Bob Collins:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the coalition, I rise to speak on the International Tax Agreements Amendment Bill 1995. This bill gives the force of law in Australia to a comprehensive double-tax agreement signed with the Czech Republic on 28 March this year for the prevention of double taxation and the prevention of avoidance of taxes on income flows between the two treaty partners.

PARA.TAB: The agreement prevents double taxation by allocating taxing rights to Australia or to the Czech Republic on all forms of income flow between the two countries. The basis of allocating the rights is substantially similar to that adopted in Australia's other modern double-taxation agreements, such as that which was signed with New Zealand earlier this year.

The agreement affects all taxpayers who for the purposes of the double-tax agreement are residents of either Australia or the Czech Republic and who derive income, profits or gains from the other country. The double-taxation agreement applies to Australian income tax and resource rent tax in respect of offshore petroleum products.

The agreement relates to fiscal evasion with respect to taxes on income. It does not extend to sales tax, fringe benefits tax, wool tax and levies, customs duties, state taxes and duties, and the Medicare levy. Similarly, it applies to taxes on income within the Czech Republic. The agreement will automatically extend to any identical or substantially similar taxes which are subsequently imposed by either country in addition to, or in the place of, existing taxes.

There are a number of special features in the agreement which relate to dividend withholding tax, interest on royalties, capital gains and the exchange of information. While I do not want to go into these matters in any detail in the debate today, I draw the attention of interested parties to the speech of the member for Menzies (Mr Andrews) in the House of Representatives and the response of the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Gear. I note from the response by Mr Gear that the double-tax agreements with Malaysia, Romania, Slovakia and Russia are nearing completion and technical checks are being conducted with translations in progress in preparation for signature.

I ask that the government keep the parliament informed as to the progress of these agreements as it is important that we maintain our momentum towards integration into the international economic system. The coalition supports the bill and welcomes the formalisation of this agreement with the Czech Republic and its people.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Gibson for his contribution and commend the International Tax Agreements Amendment Bill 1995 to the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
