DEBATE.TITLE: VOCATIONAL EDUCATION AND TRAINING FUNDING AMENDMENT BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 19 October, on motion by Senator McMullan:
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to rise today to speak on the Vocational Education and Training Funding Amendment Bill 1995. The bill is non-controversial in that it merely provides for the allocation of resources to vocational education and training. This debate provides an opportunity to analyse the government's record in this important sector of our economy.

PARA.TAB: I do not intend to make lengthy comments. I think, however, it would be remiss of me not to highlight what I consider to be a major failing in the Labor government's vocational education and training program. In my opinion and, I would suggest, in the opinion of many others, there is very little point in having a world-class, best practice unemployed work force. Such a work force, while perhaps ready to accept work in the future, will today remain unemployed unless their skills are made relevant to the business environment of here and now. It is merely frustrating and demoralising to allow an individual to be trained or educated in the belief that employment will follow when the training fails to be targeted and has no hope of resulting in long-term work.

If our educational and training regimes are not leading to employment in a growing and expanding economy, then I suggest there is something disturbingly wrong. So how should we assess the schemes and programs currently operated by the Labor government in this area of vocational education and training?

I would venture the proposition that the first step in evaluation is to determine the goal of the program. In making this evaluation, we can look to the words of the government or we can look to the priorities of the government as evidenced by how the government spends taxpayers' money. While I enjoy reading the government's words, I think it might be more rational and enlightening to examine where the government puts the money. Clearly, while words are cheap, it is actions that pay the bills.

In this year's budget papers—1995-96—the government indicates that it will spend $850 million on vocational and other education over the financial year. This amounts to 7.94 per cent of the Commonwealth's spending on education. Of the $850 million, the vast majority is spent on technical and further education, with just $19.9 million being spent on other vocational education institutions.

The Commonwealth's primary involvement in vocational education and training is conducted through a joint Commonwealth-state body, the Australian National Training Authority. Under the ANTA agreement, states are required to maintain their effort in vocational education and training, while the Commonwealth has committed itself to maintaining its levels of financial support and to provide further growth funding.

The bill before the Senate provides increases of $9.469 million in 1995 and $9.192 million next year, in 1996, to the current legislated amounts. The bill also provides a total of $949.88 million in general funding, which includes $22.7 million for off-the-job training to ANTA in 1997 under Working Nation.

At this time I could criticise the government for its mathematical gymnastics in reducing funds to the states over the next three years through adjustments to the process of indexation. However, as these reported savings are in fact only notional and cannot be guaranteed, I shall pass over that issue. The amounts to be appropriated to the vocational education and training area are significant, and it is important that we are able to assess whether their expenditure actually returns an appropriate value to the community.

Let me say that I believe this funding does return value to the community. However, I do not believe the funds are being used to the maximum possible advantage. In this opinion I am no Robinson Crusoe. Major recent research has highlighted the weaknesses in both our system of providing vocational training and the form that that training should take. In the Karpin report entitled Enterprising Nation, the following statement was made:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . it appears incontrovertible that Australian enterprises, training providers and educational institutions are not moving quickly enough to address the new paradigm of management. Many of our counterparts overseas, and especially the leaders in the various fields of industry and education, are changing more rapidly and more extensively, and will be better prepared for the next century.

What Karpin has said is clear. The world does not owe Australia a living and it is moving ahead of us now. We must get moving and react more quickly with better training or risk the potential of being left behind. The writing is on the wall and the message is clear. Either we must establish a vocational education and training structure and a system which is capable of a flexible response to the changing circumstances of modern commerce, or we will be an economic and social backwater not only in our own geographic region but also in the world as a whole.

PARA.TAB: What this will mean is a lower standard of living, greater pressure to sell off our nation's assets and even greater pressure to exploit the vulnerable. Our social safety net will be useless if each and every one of us needs to have recourse to it just to live above the poverty line. So where does our system currently stand? Is it flexible and achievement oriented enough? Does it respond to business, commerce and industry needs or is its existence an end in itself?

In August this year, the Committee for Economic Development of Australia—known as CEDA—released the outcomes of its review of the national training reform agenda. That report concluded that progress had been slow and that the new training structures were too bureaucratic, overly complex and irrelevant to the needs of many enterprises. The report also concluded that the national training reform agenda suffered from a lack of industry involvement. These are very disturbing findings. If our training and education agenda is based on a stifling, complex bureaucracy, which excludes the very people that ultimately must employ the newly trained, then we are patently wasting not only money but also the future potential of thousands of Australians that undertake these programs.

I note that there are two inquiries currently being conducted into the training reform agenda. I trust that those inquiries will lead to a vocational education and training system which is focused on employment outcomes and on the needs of industry and business, and targeted to produce world best results. I trust that these outcomes are the intention of the government. I further trust that they and all involved parties, including the Commonwealth and state bureaucrats, will commit themselves to achieving these results without ego or the positioning for theoretical control and power.

There is clearly a great deal more that I could address in a debate of this kind. However, this is not the right time, even if it is the right place for that debate. I will close by saying that the coalition does support the bill.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot say that I agree with all the remarks in support of the Vocational Education and Training Funding Amendment Bill that Senator Gibson made. He could not help but take a swipe at a number of the government's initiatives. I have to say, though, that the creation of ANTA and the vocational training policy of this government are a couple of the major achievements of any government in many decades to get a national vocational training system into place in cooperation with the states. Of course, we have made major contributions of funds for that new scheme to come into operation.

PARA.TAB: As a minister in the industry portfolio, every day I see the benefits of the new ANTA system providing the highly skilled workers that we need in our value added manufacturing and service industries. So I do not accept Senator Gibson's remarks that the government has failed in this area. I believe we have a very significant achievement that we can be proud of but, above all else, that the Australian people can be proud of. I commend the bill to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: PRIME MINISTER AND CABINET (MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS) BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 29 March, on motion by Senator Crowley:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister and Cabinet (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill 1995 is an omnibus bill which amends four separate acts, the Economic Planning Advisory Council Act 1983, the Parliamentary Allowances Act 1952, the Parliamentary Presiding Officers Act 1965 and the Public Service Act 1992. It is a non-controversial bill, in all aspects, and the coalition will not be opposing it.

PARA.TAB: The first of the main provisions of the bill seeks to amend the Economic Planning Advisory Council Act 1983. The bill abolishes the Economic Planning Advisory Council, known as EPAC, and establishes the Economic Planning Advisory Commission. This follows an announcement by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on 16 August 1994 that he was establishing a new, so-called economic round table to replace EPAC and that EPAC would be re-established as the Economic Planning Advisory Commission.

I am not sure what has happened to the economic round table proposal. This bill, as I understand it, is solely concerned with the abolition of the Economic Planning Advisory Council and the establishment of an Economic Planning Advisory Commission. The council was a creature of the previous Labor government. It was established after the national economic summit of March 1983. It was intended to bring together business, unions and government.

EPAC has, over the years, fulfilled in many ways a useful role. We have all had criticisms of EPAC from time to time; some of those I have agreed with. Overall, EPAC did play a useful role in various respects. However, like the Accord—and, importantly, it did flow from the Accord—and this government, it has apparently outlived its purpose and will be replaced by the commission. It does away with the auspices of tripartite consultation and will concentrate, I understand, more on advice to government.

The commission is a creature of government. If it is going to be providing advice, fearlessly to government, it does really need to have a surety of its independence. There is no guarantee, either in this bill or anywhere else as far as I am aware, of independence. That is unfortunate.

I hope that the commission will, in carrying out its work, be able to work on the basis that the only useful advice to government is advice that it can convey independently and without fear of retribution if it gives to government advice that the government does not necessarily want to hear. That is a very important aspect. I hope that the government will take that on board in the operation of the commission.

The second and third acts that are amended by this bill are parliamentary acts—the Parliamentary Allowances Act 1952 and the Parliamentary Presiding Officers Act 1965. The bills makes minor technical amendments to both of these acts, principally to remove gender specific language and to update title references.

The fourth act being amended by the bill is the Public Service Act 1992. The bill amends the Public Service Act to implement the recommendations of the Joint Standing Committee of Public Accounts to require departments to report to the parliament by 31 October each year. To do that, the bill also requires that annual reports be presented to ministers by the 15 October, to enable that reporting to the parliament by the 31 October.

The bill makes arrangements for reporting when parliament is not sitting. It allows the minister to grant exemptions from the deadline, subject to advising the parliament. It also provides for the granting to presiding officers of the ability to delegate various personnel and management tasks. The coalition has no problems with those amendments. They seem sensible.

The reporting of annual reports to parliament is an essential process now that the old system of estimates committees has changed. Much more reliance is now placed on the annual reports of departments and agencies. They have become a crucial core element of the data and information available to the parliament for the examination of the workings of government. Therefore, the amendment in this bill to the Public Service Act is a very important amendment.
With those remarks, Mr Acting Deputy President, I repeat that the coalition has no objections to this bill.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Short for his contribution and commend the bill to the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before calling on questions without notice, I indicate that the new arrangement applying a proportionate number of questions to each party, as agreed by the parties, will be applied from today. I would like to thank the whips and particularly the Manager of Government Business in the Senate, Senator Faulkner, for working through that.

—My question is directed to Senator Cook, representing the Treasurer. I remind the minister of assurances of Mr Keating that he had broken the back of inflation, that the inflation stick had been broken and that the inflation psychology had gone. Now, as the Australian Financial Review puts it so well, the devil is back. I ask the minister: why under your policies, your administration, does Australia have to have one of the highest inflation rates in the developed world?

—It is probably worth while recalling when the devil was here last time—not that I accept the `the devil is back' headline of the Financial Review as being an accurate reflection of what is the truth for the Australian economy. I recall that when the coalition were last in government inflation was at 11.4 per cent. That is the devil that the Financial Review refers to, and we now have a headline rate—

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. The question that was asked was: why does Australia now—under your administration, your policies—have to have one of the highest inflation rates in the Western world? That is the question. That is what the people want to know. They do not want to know what happened 20 years ago. They want to know why you are failing. Tell us.

—Mr President, on the point of order: there is no point of order here. Senator Hill, who is a lawyer and knows the standing orders, knows that there is no point of order. He is simply using the device of points of order to interrupt ministers when they are addressing the question within the confines of the standing orders, as last put down by you on Monday of this week, Mr President. I think that if Senator Hill does that again you should draw him to order and sit him down.

—Order! The minister has a right to put a preamble to any answer to a question, and it is too early to judge on relevance when such a preamble is being put. I would draw the attention of the Senate to the fact that there is an increasing tendency for opposition senators to raise points of order very early in an answer, perhaps with a view to disrupting the answer being given. But if that is the case, I will be coming down hard on it.

—The first point I make about the devil is that on a contrast—this government compared with the coalition when it was last in office—you were at the headline rate of 11.4 per cent. The headline rate you are complaining about now is 5.1 per cent. As the Treasurer and as the Prime Minister have both made clear—and, indeed, many economic commentators have supported their view—the underlying rate is probably the more appropriate rate because it is shorn of high volatile factors, seasonal fluctuations and government charges. The underlying rate and the headline rate are such that they are within the budget forecasts and are, therefore, consistent with current economic policy. They are within the forecasts we made in the budget in May of this year.

PARA.TAB: This question invites me to compare us with the rest of the world. One of the things is that you cannot compare economic indicators in isolation from other economic indicators. In relation to the rest of the world, the first thing you would ask is: are the other indicators of inflation measuring the same things as the levels of inflation being measured in Australia? When you ask yourself that question and look at the other indicators, the answer is that they are not, by and large. The headline rate in other countries, by and large, excludes all issues under the statistical category `shelter', which is to say that it does not include what would be the mortgage repayments, interest rates on home loans and things of that nature in other economies. So the first point about this comparison, `Is it apples to apples?', is that it is not apples to apples; it is an apples to oranges comparison—and you should get the comparison of your statistics right, Senator Hill.

The second point is the more important one, because you cannot separate the interdependence, as I have said, of economic indicators. Look at the growth levels in Australia compared with the growth levels in the economies of the countries, Senator Hill, you are referring to. You often like to quote the rear pages of the Economist magazine. Let me look at its economic indicators page. Under the heading `Economic GDP Forecasts for 1995', it says that Australia has the second highest growth of all the developed economies mentioned there and well above a number of the significant economies that you compare our inflation rate with. If you look to the forecast for 1996 where the Economist forecasters predict what growth will be in the economies, Australia is equal first in the world for economic growth.

It is growth that creates jobs and pressure on inflation, that is true. But no-one wants to lose this level of growth. We are looking at a level of sustainable economic growth that creates work for Australians and we are looking at the other economies coming behind us. Their inflation is lower because their growth levels are lower. It is bad news for people in those economies, because of that. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister, of course, has again avoided the question. He has failed to face up to the fact that a short while ago his Prime Minister said, `Labor has beaten inflation.' Now you have the highest inflation rates in the last five years. If you have thrown in the towel, Minister, which is the only interpretation that could be given, do you and does your government understand the effect of rising inflation rates adds to the basic cost of goods and services for the battlers, adds to the cost of their rent and mortgage payments, will further slow business rates, and will add to the mass unemployment which is the principal legacy of Labor?

—I am not sure what the question was. I think it was just a political rave by Senator Hill. I do note that in that rave he was comparing us with us when he talked about the highest inflation in five years. It is higher than it was five years ago but we have had four years of economic growth in this economy. But it is a lot lower than it was 13 years ago, Senator Hill, when you were a member of the government sitting over this side of the chamber, and you were presiding over inflation levels of 11.4 per cent. The Australian electorate do not forget that you are the high inflation, high taxing party. The amazing thing about those levels of inflation of 11.4 per cent—

—Mr President, I take a point of order. The question was not in relation to what the rate of inflation was back in 1983. In 1983, Australia had average inflation in world terms; in 1995 we have the highest inflation in the real world. Could you please ask the minister to be relevant?
—Order! You have made your point of order. Like Senator Cook, I do not know what the question was.
—And you managed 11.4 per cent inflation in the midst of a recession. We have a higher level of inflation in sustainable growth—
—I take a point of order, Mr President. During 1983 Australia had average inflation in real terms. In 1995—
—Are you making a point of order or a statement?
—I am making a point of order. Could you please ask the minister to be relevant to Senator Hill's question, and stop debating it.
—I have already made the point and I am not going to make it again.

—The other thing is we have got an accord with the unions that promises that wages will keep inflation within the range of two to three per cent at the underlying rate, what the Reserve Bank targets. You do not have an accord with the unions. You never will. You hate them. You are at war with them. The Western Australian industrial legislation is an example of what you would do to lose the economy of Australia by bringing on an industrial relations conflict in this country.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Treasurer, Senator Cook. Minister, you have would have seen reports today of Victorian premier Jeff Kennett's startling plan, as the Canberra Times reports, `to strip the federal government of 80 per cent of its tax powers'. Does the government intend to take up this proposal? I also note that the Australian reports that Mr Howard tried to laugh off the Kennett plan but did not specifically repudiate it. Harking back to the Business Review Weekly report `Libs' radical new tax plan', how would the state tax discussed there impact on the states?

—Several newspapers have reported today that the Victorian premier, Jeff Kennett, has introduced a plan which, according to the Canberra Times, is to strip the federal government of 80 per cent of its tax take. It has been described universally as a startling plan. Certainly, that is a description of it. I notice that Mr Kennett today has back pedalled on it to some extent. Obviously, Mr Howard has got to him. He has reduced the amount that he would strip from the Commonwealth of taxation but he has not changed his principle. The important thing here is that he still adheres to his plan, although he is now more negotiable about the level of it.

PARA.TAB: Yes, I did see the Australian report that Mr Howard tried to laugh off the Kennett plan but did not specifically repudiate it.

TALK.START.PARA: —He did so.

—That is an accurate report from the Australian. The government emphatically does not intend to take up such a proposal. There are a number of reasons why we do not, but the chief one among them is that this would effectively break up the federation of Australia and turn it into, instead of being one country with a central government, a series of small countries based on the states and the territories. But, more importantly, the impact of the Kennett plan would be to junk federal government responsibilities in the area of health, education and social security.

PARA.TAB: We heard Mr Howard at ACOSS last week giving the 22 promises of what he wouldn't do—he wouldn't do this and he wouldn't do that on social security. We now know from what Mr Kennett has said that the intention is to devolve those responsibilities to the states and allow the states to scuttle expenditure on social security, to undermine expenditure on health, and to reduce expenditure on education so that Mr Howard can stand centre stage, pristine and pure, hand on heart, saying `I kept my promises' but allow the state premiers, Kennett, Brown and Court, to do the dirty work for him.

I am also asked a question about the BRW report `Libs' radical new tax plan' and what the impact of that would be on a state basis. The BRW article outlined a proposal being studied by the Liberal Party for states and territories to be allowed to levy individual income taxes, initially at a common marginal rate of 16 per cent above the tax-free threshold. Each individual state would then be able to vary its 16 per cent marginal rate to suit their own ends. What that would mean is New South Wales and Victoria would be better off by over $1 billion each; Queensland and South Australia would lose over $700 million each; Western Australia would lose $220 million; Tasmania would lose $360 million; and the Northern Territory, for some reason—obviously, the Liberals do not like them up there in the territory—would lose $837 million.

If the states were to adjust their marginal tax rates to restore their previous level of funding, New South Wales and Victoria could reduce taxes by between 2.6 and 2.9 per cent, respectively. The ACT could reduce tax rates by four per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. This is—what would you describe this as—a speculative debate on something irrelevant to the issue of government administration. This fellow is administering a federal portfolio. The question was not—
—Make your point of order.

—Why don't you listen? The question was not put in terms of whether the minister is intending to adopt some particular formula and what would be the consequences of that for federal administration. He was simply asked to comment on an article that appeared in a magazine, which he has chosen to interpret in a particular political way and to rant and rave about. That is not within the standing orders. It is not the function of a minister to be speculating in that way.
—That is not a point of order.
—Yes, it is.
—There is the point of order there? There is no point of order.

—All the other states and territories would need to increase their levels of taxation. Queenslanders would pay 2.9 per cent more tax. Western Australians would pay 1.4 per cent more tax. South Australians would pay six per cent more tax. Tasmanians would pay 9.9 per cent more tax. If you come from the Northern Territory you would pay 58.3 per cent more tax under this plan to devolve taxes to the states at an income tax level. The government believes that that plan ought to be repudiated. We will not adopt it. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to the Hawke and Keating governments' blatant use of taxpayers' money to fund the trade union movement. Will the minister confirm that answers that I have received from ministers on questions about these payments show that well over $90 million has been paid over to the unions in direct grant funding and that even this huge figure excludes certain large payments—for example, the funding of the Trade Union Training Authority at a cost of more than $10 million a year? Will the minister also confirm that in return for receiving $3.5 million from the trade union movement to assist its 1993 campaign, the Labor government has already shelled out more than $26 million of taxpayers' money since then to the unions in grateful thanks? When will this government cease this disgraceful rorting of taxpayers and this arrogant and dishonest abuse of power and privilege?

—There is nothing disgraceful about the government's activities. There is nothing wrong with the government's activities. Any grant to a trade union goes for a specific purpose and in line with government policy. It would be interesting to know whether Senator Short would ever ask a question on notice about how much money has been given to assist Australian industry and therefore employers in this country. It would be 10, 20, 30 or maybe 100 times the amount that has ever been granted to trade unions.

PARA.TAB: What this government has been about in the last 10 years, in particular, is multiskilling the work force, freeing up the labour market and achieving a productivity driven economy. One of the key partners in that has been the trade union movement. Many employers are grateful for the role that not only the federal government but also the trade union movement has played in this process. They are grateful for the fact that many of the old class warfare cliches have disappeared. They welcome the fact that many of the unions have given up the old shibboleths.

Many of the unions now recognise that the benefits to their members will come as the economy grows. The economy will grow best by increases in productivity, flexibility in work practices and cooperative activities between the tripartite levels of governments, employers and unions. It is in that context that grants have been made over the years. Many grants have also been made in the employer and business areas to increase their productivity. The beneficiaries are not only those who get the grants but also the whole Australian economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. My question refers to the fruit fly outbreak. I ask the minister to advise the Senate what further steps are being taken at the Commonwealth and state levels in response to the outbreak of the papaya fruit fly in North Queensland?

—This is, as I have already advised the Senate, a serious issue. Unfortunately, one of the major problems that occur in these situations is that inaccurate and exaggerated rumours start to circulate in our overseas markets. I was informed this morning that this has already started. It was for this reason that a couple of days ago I urged everybody in here and everybody engaged in the public debate on this serious issue to keep the interests of the Queensland fruit industry foremost in their minds and ensure that the comments are based on fact and not on ill-informed opinion.

PARA.TAB: In order to assist that process, I do wish to inform the Senate of what the current facts are in the situation as it now presents itself. The Commonwealth, Queensland and all other state governments are continuing to work closely in response to the outbreak. All recognise the need for the closest cooperation at the government to government level and informed public debate on control measures also to ensure that any damage from this outbreak is minimised.

Honourable senators would be aware that the Queensland government today has announced a major expansion of the quarantine zone and has instituted associated control measures to meet the requirements of all other states and the Commonwealth. These measures are designed importantly to control the outbreak and also to maximise producer access to markets. I am working closely with my state counterpart in Queensland, Bob Gibbs, to develop and implement satisfactory protocols in an attempt to keep export markets open.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a great pair!

—If you do not think this is important, Senator Tambling, I can tell you it is very important for the Northern Territory, apart from Queensland. I can advise the Senate that all states and territories are accepting fruit from the affected area subject to its having been treated by approved processes. Officers of my department are currently discussing this issue with relevant authorities in our key overseas markets.

PARA.TAB: On the control front, efforts have been intensified to finalise the evaluation of the potential for a successful eradication program. A decision is expected within the next few days and the Commonwealth stands ready to support Queensland in any efforts to eradicate the pest. What should be understood is that Queensland producers and exporters already have in place management and treatment systems to deal with the Queensland fruit fly which enable them to successfully supply both Australian and overseas markets.

The Q-fly and papaya fruit fly have very similar commercial hosts. For example, they both infest plants such as pawpaw, banana, chilli, mango, guava and star fruit. I have already asked the Horticultural Research and Development Corporation to undertake further research to establish whether existing production management and export clearance systems to deal with Q-fly can also deal with papaya fruit fly.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to Senator Cook, representing the Treasurer and the Minister for Finance. Minister, can you explain why the Deputy Prime Minister and finance minister, Mr Beazley, responded to concerns about this year's budget changes to the diesel fuel rebate scheme by ensuring that `core mining activities which previously received diesel fuel rebate continued to do so'? Why has Mr Beazley now been contradicted by the government imposing extra excise collections, estimated to be somewhere between $50 million and $100 million more than is in the budget and the legislation? Is this not another of Labor's hidden, sneaky tax policies? How do you justify another lie to the Australian people on taxation?
—You have the wrong minister.
—I asked the question about Beazley.
—Mr President—
—I call the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction, Senator Schacht.

—As is well known, as the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction I am responsible for the administration of the diesel fuel rebate scheme. The question was about the amendments to the diesel fuel rebate scheme that went through the parliament as part of the budget process. For further discussion the bill was referred to a Senate committee, which I think is reporting today.

PARA.TAB: What Senator Tambling did not mention in his question was that the bill now before the Senate committee came about because at the end of the budget session, at the end of June, unfortunately in their drafting some of the amendments moved by the opposition were technically incorrect and the will of the Senate was not actually carried out. Even though this would have advantaged the government—

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to a point of order.
—It is a point of order and not a question of challenging the facts, I take it.
—My point of order is one of relevance and accuracy.
—Accuracy is not a ground for a point of order.
—The amendments were not the ones moved by the opposition; they were the ones moved by the Greens but written by the government. That is where the mistake was made.
—There is no point of order. Take your seat.
—He should be honest, Mr President.
—Order! Take your seat. There is no point of order.

—On the point of order: there is a standing order that relates to imputations against senators. The imputation from the minister was quite clearly that it was the opposition senators who messed it up. What Senator Crane is pointing out to you is that it was the minister who made the mistake. It is an imputation which is relevant to the standing order.
—Order! Take your seat.
—Can I not finish my point of order?
—I know what you are saying. If you want to go on—
—I see. So I will click my fingers and you will know what I mean.

—I know what you are saying; you have made it quite clear. You are quite wrong. If a senator is aggrieved, there are places in which that grievance can be corrected. It is not in the standing orders in relation to question time.

—I was explaining that the government had agreed that we would introduce an amending bill, which we did, to ensure that the will of the majority of the Senate, even when it was against the government's position, would be carried out. We explained that that bill would be non-controversial and put into the Senate. That was our view. We explained it to the opposition. However, the opposition has now chosen not only to refer it to a Senate committee but also to start raising whole new amendments on new areas of policy determination about who is eligible for the diesel fuel rebate and who is not. The government made it quite clear at the hearing last Friday that those amendments are not acceptable and will be opposed by the government.

PARA.TAB: What Senator Tambling has raised in his question is an imputation that Mr Beazley has given advice that the government is now going back on. That is not correct. You raised issues in the amendments to the bill in the Senate committee hearing last week. We certainly do not agree that there has been a change to who is eligible and who is not. We have ensured that those who were eligible in the core areas of mining and agriculture before this bill was introduced will continue to get the rebate. That is our position.

You are now attempting to expand eligibility to areas that the customs department has always disputed were eligible. That is the correct position, and we will not move from it. As a consequence, the future of this bill, which we put in to ensure that the Senate majority view was carried through, is now greatly in doubt.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question to the monkey rather than the organ grinder. Is it not a fact that there is now somewhere between $50 million and $100 million of additional, sneaky taxes being crept in that were not explained in the original legislation? Did the minister not say that you would have open discussions and bend over backwards to accept those definitions to ensure that all those who have been getting the rebate scheme will continue to get it? Is it not now a fact that the mining exploration, offshore petroleum and limestone for agricultural purposes industries have in effect been fully withdrawn and that you are now imposing extra taxes which amount to more than the $50 million that you put in the budget or the legislation?

—That is not correct. As I said in my answer, for a long time the Customs Service has disputed the eligibility of those areas that Senator Tambling has mentioned. They were being dealt with in court cases. We redefined the sweeper clauses, as they are called, in the bill to ensure that the original policy intent of this measure introduced by the Fraser government in 1982 would continue. The diesel fuel rebate scheme means that the mining industry in this country gets the benefit of $600 million in revenue forgone on excise. The agricultural industry gets $400 million. That is over $1 billion of revenue forgone, because that is the policy intent of the government. We will stick to that policy intent. With these further amendments, the opposition is trying to expand the intent of the bill beyond what it was originally designed for. It is doing that for political purposes to try to curry some short-term electoral favour with a number of people in a particular industry.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to the Prime Minister's comment that his government's $6 billion of tax concessions which prop up superannuation `gives the Commonwealth government heaps of prerogative' in criticising the funds' investment strategies, and I ask: does the minister view the decision by superannuation funds to more than double the amount they have invested overseas in the past five years—some $32 billion worth—as good value for the government's $6 billion worth of superannuation concessions? How many jobs and business opportunities are generated in Australia by the investment of this $32 billion of tax preferred funds overseas? What does it do for Australian small businesses already facing interest rates, on average, four to five per cent higher than big business, assuming, of course, that they can get finance?

—About a week or two ago, I looked at the proportion of superannuation funds invested in Australia and overseas. As I recall, about 85 per cent of superannuation investment was domestic, that is, in Australia. So the proportion is 15 to 85 in the proportionality of it.

PARA.TAB: You have given large figures, but that is indicative of the large pool of investment generated in superannuation by the policies of this government making superannuation a right for every Australian worker and not the prerogative of those who are in high paid jobs or work in the Public Service, as applied when the coalition were in power.

We have made superannuation a right for all workers—the lowest paid and the highest paid—and not just an exclusive group. That means that Australians can look forward to a more dignified retirement than they could have done under coalition policies. And those funds, as you have indicated in this question, Senator Kernot, have grown to very large levels.

The Prime Minister was saying that, yes, tax concessions are provided by Australian taxpayers to superannuation funds and that does give us, as a government, a right to express views and take action about superannuation. But there is a clear dividing line—and one that we will not cross—and that is that we are not in the business of directing where funds should invest.

We recognise that superannuation funds have the savings of ordinary Australians to invest and that the obligation on those funds is to give the best possible return for ordinary Australians who will be the beneficiaries as superannuants of those funds. We think that the best way of managing that process is to allow the funds to make the decisions about investment and not for the government to direct them.

However, we do think—and the Prime Minister has colourfully expressed himself on this a couple of times in the last week—that the direction of funds' investment is not balanced when it comes to considering the need of developmental and venture capital in Australia; that is, investing in companies that want to start business and investing in companies that have just got started and have bright prospects but cannot attract investment in either equity or capital to grow beyond their smaller levels. That is a distortion in our market.

You will recall that earlier this week I referred to the National Investment Council's report which said that our funds are about 3 1/2 per cent less attentive to this area of investment than are typical funds in the United States and the United Kingdom. I was just making the point that we have an underdeveloped venture capital market in Australia and we have a development capital market but still not a strong one, and this is a country which is typified by a large number of small to medium size businesses. If their capital is starved, it is harder for them to grow and bring Australian brand names to the international marketplace. The Prime Minister was talking about that distortion. Because of the tax concessions the government brings, we do have a right and a prerogative to speak about that in this area.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, it is not just a matter of proportionality, is it? There is a policy question here. Why should other countries benefit from Australian taxation concessions which are actually a cost to the Australian taxpayer? On the question of policy, do you not have an obligation to find the right policy balance between members' rights but a serious consideration of the national interest as well, particularly when it comes to interest rates for small business?

—Yes, of course. That last point is entirely valid. The way we address this issue is by taking steps—some of which I have enumerated this week—to encourage a more balanced portfolio of investment by superannuation funds rather than cross the divide that you want us to cross and direct them on the assumption that the government knows best about that type of investment.

PARA.TAB: On the first part of your question, we can have this debate in the chamber all day, but investment in foreign business by Australians gets a return to Australia, integrates us into the international economy more deeply and is a valid form of investment. I would like to see more of that investment at home, but I by no means write off the importance of a balanced portfolio which would include some foreign investment. On the proportional argument here the proportions are quite reasonably balanced, I think.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. Are you aware, Minister, that witnesses before the long-term unemployment inquiry from right around Australia condemned your so-called Working Nation program in the following terms: `I feel abandoned by the system, exploited by the system, abused by the system and held captive by the system.' Specifically in Whyalla: `People are sick and tired of training for the sake of it. They are disillusioned with training programs that get them nowhere' and, `Participants in work experience programs after six months of feeling really happy that they are up and going all of a sudden, when their placement ends, they are dead in their tracks.' Finally and most tragically: `It is more comfortable to remain lying in the gutter than to be picked up and dropped back in it again.' Minister, how can you justify the abject policy failure to 760,000 officially unemployed Australians and what hope do you offer these people with unemployment on the rise again? (Time expired)

—No, I am not aware of those claims in that inquiry. The report, I understand, was only tabled today. I am not a member of the committee but I will have an opportunity over the next couple of days to acquaint myself with that report. But just because I will acquaint myself with it does not mean to say that I will automatically agree with all the polemic that you have just gone on about.

PARA.TAB: If this government had not introduced the Working Nation program—which is a $10 billion program over four years—over that period to help the unemployed, particularly the long-term unemployed, recently enhanced by Mr Crean's announcement to make it even more flexible to help those unemployed between six and 12 months, you would be the first person up here screaming that we are doing nothing. This program, started in May of last year, is the single biggest effort by any Australian government in history to deal with the issue of unemployment. One thing we find interesting is that you have not announced one word of new policy, of what you would do instead of what we are doing. You have no policy at all. We have a detailed policy which, after some 18 months, as has already been explained to you and many others, has worked successfully to significantly reduce unemployment in Australia, particularly long-term unemployment. Senator Tierney was just going on, as he usually does, attacking the government. It is fine to attack the government but you put nothing in its place. Until you do, you have no credibility.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology. Minister, is it true that the Export Finance and Insurance Corporation, or EFIC, provided political risk cover or some other form of guarantee for the Bougainville copper project at Panguna? If so, can the minister advise whether any payment has been made by EFIC to the mine owners or their bankers due to the closure of the mine, the extent of that payment and whether the guarantee was commercially reinsured or whether it was guaranteed by the Australian government?

—I am advised that in 1971 the Export Payments Insurance Corporation, the predecessor of EFIC—and 1971 would put it under the McMahon Liberal government—provided cover against the risk of non-payment for the supply of some $26 million of equipment exports from a wide range of Australian firms to the Bougainville copper project. At that time this was a significant achievement in the face of strong international competition. All payments were met on the due dates and the Export Payments Insurance Corporation did not incur any claim payments. This cover related to payment terms of 10 years and expired in the early 1980s.

PARA.TAB: More recently, EFIC provided overseas investment insurance to two Australian firms which had equipment at the mine site. Claims totalling some $500,000 resulting from damage to this equipment were paid by EFIC in 1991. Beyond this, EFIC has paid some claims to Australian companies that have been exporting to Papua New Guinea, generally where non-payment by the PNG buyer can probably be attributed to financial difficulties flowing from the closure of the Bougainville mine.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it true that the political risk cover to be provided by EFIC for the Lihir goldmine, which I understand does not have any reinsurance backing, was agreed to despite the fact that OPIC, the United States loan guarantee agency, has declined to provide similar cover on environmental grounds?

—I would need to ruminate in my mind to recall the details of the Lihir package. It went through cabinet about three months ago; it seems like about three years ago now. I would have to go back and check. I do not recall that what you have said is an accurate representation of the facts. I will go back to the file and put down a full and proper answer to that question as soon as possible.

—My question is directed to the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to your statement in the Senate last Monday in which you disclaimed knowledge of the recent squalid Queensland $20,000 rent a cabinet exercise. Do you agree with Gary Gray that it was a legitimate fundraising tactic, although the wording may have been somewhat clumsy, or will you unequivocally condemn the sleazy renting of the Prime Minister and his acolytes to the highest bidder? Did the Prime Minister's office approve of this proposal? Can you confirm that a similar offer was made to those attending the Melbourne soiree organised by McIntosh Securities?

—On Monday I made it absolutely clear where I thought the line should be drawn. Senator Alston has done his best to try to murky the waters in that regard. I said then that I regard it as quite legitimate that fundraising goes to the question of dinners, seminars, cocktail parties and sponsorship therein. I see no difficulty in that. The way in which that letter expressed it—which I think was very poor wording or just plain stupidity—gave the impression that it was possible to sponsor cabinet. That was rubbish. It was never authorised by the Prime Minister's office, the national secretary, or anyone else. How it got out is a matter for inquiry of those people.

PARA.TAB: You asked me did the Prime Minister's office have any knowledge of this. My understanding is that it did not have any knowledge of this. I do not know if I have covered the whole point of the question, but to reiterate: this government rejects the concept of fundraising for access to ministers on a one-to-one basis.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why does the party secretary keep legitimising it?
—I wonder if Senator Hill has properly read the transcript.
—Why don't you have a talk to him?

—I will come to that in a moment. From the Gary Gray interview to the way it appeared in the newspapers there are subtle variations that distort his position. What Mr Gray was defending, quite unequivocally, was the right of political parties to fundraise. I am sure he agrees with the point that I have made in the Senate: one-to-one access on a fee charging basis is not kosher. The reason I know that is because the following Monday I went and discussed it with the national secretary.
—Why does Gray leave any doubt?

—You see, this is all on Monday morning, I believe, Senator, when the issue was out there in a confused way and was reported in a confused way. I am sure that when he said he agreed with it, he was saying that he agrees with the sponsorship of dinners, seminars and cocktail parties. That is the context Mr Gray put it in. But it was not quite the context in which it was reported, and therein lies the difficulty in trying to resolve the views that Senator Alston has put today, representing, he thinks, the views of the national secretary, and the views I put here in this chamber on Monday.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —You seem to be of the view that Mr Gray might have left some doubt in the minds of people on Monday, but since then it has all been clarified. Let me direct you to today's editorial in the Australian, which says:

QUESTION.PARA: Yet the party's national secretary, Mr Gary Gray, seems oblivious to the mistake. He considers it a legitimate fund-raising activity, although he is critical of the "clumsy" wording of the letter in which the Marketplace offer was made.

If you are saying that you and Mr Gray are in agreement that this was totally out of order, will you come back to this Senate and table a statement from Mr Gray that removes any doubt or ambiguity and that makes it perfectly clear that he completely dissociates himself from that newsletter and that at no time did he ever support the concept of rent-a-cabinet? The other part of my question, which you didn't answer, was whether there was a similar proposal in relation to the McIntosh Securities function several months ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —My standing on the latter point is that they sponsored a dinner, which is totally legitimate, the same as the Fahey government or anyone else. Senator Alston asked me whether I will come into this chamber and table a statement from the national secretary of the Labor Party. I tell you what: I'll comply with that the day you bring a statement into this chamber by your national secretary, Mr Robb, opening up your trust fund that was deliberately constructed to hide massive donations in the last election. You know it, and I know it. I'll do that the day you bring in that statement.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction, Senator Schacht. The minister is proposing to amend the Trade Practices Act seeking to help people engaged in small business. His proposals have attracted criticism that they will too greatly prejudice the sanctity of contract and make the carrying on of business needlessly uncertain. Is that criticism valid?

—I thank Senator Cooney for his question, because I served on his committee some years ago dealing with amendments to the Trade Practices Act in this area. I am able to say that today I announced and published the exposure draft of the amendments to the Trade Practices Act that will give small business a better go in their economic relationship and business relationship with big business in this country.

PARA.TAB: I am aware that there has been some criticism that this could create commercial uncertainty. I reject completely those suggestions. The amendments we are seeking to make to the Trade Practices Act are already in existence in many other Western economies without any suggestion of creating uncertainty in business transactions. The amendments are aimed to create better business conduct in Australia between both big business and small business.

The amendments do not discriminate in favour of small business. In fact, in the draft discussion paper I released today we give an example of where the economic power of a small business was used to get a more favourable position out of a big business than normally would have been warranted. But overwhelmingly, the amendments are drafted to help small business. In conjunction with the establishment of the small business unit within the new ACCC, the new competition commission that is being created, small business will have relevant advice immediately available to them on how they can seek remedy if they feel they are being harshly dealt with.

The most striking feature since I made this announcement in principle over a month ago is that the opposition have yet to declare their position on this issue. I waited for a month because their response initially was, `We haven't seen the actual words of what the amendment would be in legal terms.'

Today it is being released. I now say to the opposition, and to Mr Howard in particular who has gone around this country for the last few months saying that one of the major issues he will be campaigning on is a better go for small business, that this amendment to the Trade Practices Act is all about giving small business in this country a better go. Yet, for a month, Mr Howard has not commented on this issue. The draft is now before him, and I think he is required to respond since he wants to make small business a major issue in the coming election campaign. He cannot go around telling small business he is all in favour of their issues when the fundamental response of small business organisations, through the Small Business Forum, overwhelmingly supports these amendments. They have done so because they see the benefits that they are going to get.

So, over the next few weeks, this exposure draft will be out there for further comment and to give people one last chance to make a comment about whether it is the way the amendments ought to be drafted. I hope the opposition will have the courage at last to declare that it will help small business. If they do not, as minister for small business I look forward in the coming election campaign to hitting the opposition, and particularly Mr Howard, around the head for running away from the big opportunity to help small business with this amendment of the Trade Practices Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the minister adhere to his assessment in the light of the criticism by the Victorian Employers Chamber of Commerce and Industry as articulated by Mr David Edwards?

—There are over 30 organisations in the Small Business Forum. Of those 30, four in one form or another have expressed opposition to or disquiet about the policy intent of this measure. They were VECCI, the ACCI—that is, the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry—the Australian Bankers Association and the Law Council of Australia. As you can see, by definition, some of those organisations would not expect to be representing small business.

PARA.TAB: But, yes, I am aware that VECCI in particular has put out a statement. They have actually written to me, as did ACCI, saying that legislation is unnecessary and that they would put other proposals to me that would mean that legislation would be unnecessary to get better business conduct for small business in Australia. That was four months ago. I am still waiting for their suggestion; it has not turned up—they have no suggestions to make. Overwhelmingly, small business organisations support this proposal.

I have to say to those organisations, particularly ACCI and VECCI, they have to sort out soon, as does Mr Howard, whether they support small business or whether they in fact support the big end of town.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Crowley as Minister representing the Minister for Health. Minister, you will be aware that the Australian Health Ministers Advisory Council has released a report showing that the government has neglected the hepatitis C crisis that Australia is facing. With the epidemic progressing more rapidly than anticipated, and one year after the adoption of a national strategy on hepatitis C, why is the government failing to show leadership by skimping on funds and failing to put that strategy into place? Minister, why has your government allocated less than $4 million over two years to fund the prevention and education of this insidious disease when it threatens to rival HIV-AIDS as a health issue? What is the government doing to ensure quick access to Interferon, the only known treatment for hepatitis C?

—Senator, it is $3.8 million. I am advised that the government allocation of $3.8 million is over two years to improve our knowledge and understanding of hepatitis C through national surveillance and to commence appropriate national education and prevention strategies. I would disagree with your assessment that this is neither here nor there in terms of hepatitis C.

PARA.TAB: I certainly concur with the comment and the government is very aware of just how significant hepatitis C is. Indeed, I think it is only beginning to be recognised as a potential epidemic of very serious size and concern. That is why the government has put that specifically targeted program in place. Senator, I am aware of your concern about Interferon. I do not have any particular information on that point of your question at this time. I will certainly seek that and get it for you as soon as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts. It relates to the installation of mobile telephone towers around Australia. I ask the minister: what has the government done, and what does it intend to do, to require carrier co-location of mobile towers wherever possible; to encourage carriers to fully comply with all relevant planning, environmental, heritage protection and health rules; to ensure that local councils have enough time to fully consult about new telecommunications structures; to improve the information supplied to councils by carriers about their planned telecommunications towers and facilities; and, finally, to improve local councils' knowledge of their rights to consultation and of their rights to appeal carrier decisions under the telecommunications national code?

—There are five parts to that question. I am not sure that I can deal with them all in four minutes but I will do what I can. With regard to the requirement for carrier co-location, the national code requires that, if a carrier installs or relocates a telecommunications tower or similar structure, the carrier must locate the new facility on an existing tower or as close as possible to an existing tower unless it is not feasible on technical grounds, unless it is incompatible with configuration or intended configuration of the carrier's network or unless it is likely to have greater adverse effect on the environment than putting the new facility in another place.

PARA.TAB: The code also requires that a carrier cooperate with other carriers in sharing sites and planning the provision of future telecommunications services. Again, this is unless it is not technically feasible, is incompatible with network configuration or has an adverse impact on the environment. I understand Austel has initiated discussions with the carriers on their endeavours to co-locate and two of the carriers have developed an agreement relating to co-location.

With regard to local councils' knowledge of their rights, the Minister for Communications and the Arts has written twice this year, providing information that will assist local councils in understanding their role and responsibilities under the telecommunications national code. The first letter also provided councils with an information package relating to the national code, containing a detailed plain English guide to the provisions of the code, a copy of the code, the regulations and a list of contacts.

The second letter was written to further ensure that councils were aware of their rights and responsibilities under the code. It emphasised that carriers must notify local councils in writing of proposals to construct telecommunications facilities and must provide enough information at the time of notification to enable the council to assess the activity. The letter also advised that, for mobile towers, when the council and the carrier have not reached agreement during the consultation process about the environmental impact of a proposed installation or modification of a tower, the council can require the carrier to refer the proposal to the Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories.

Both letters to the local councils notified them that, if they considered a carrier was not fulfilling its obligations under the code—including making an incorrect decision—they could refer the matter to Austel, which has the power under the Telecommunications Act 1991 to enforce carrier compliance with the code. In addition, the carriers and the Municipal Association of Victoria have agreed to a guideline on community notification and consultation. The government expects carriers to endeavour to apply this guideline throughout Australia. The minister wrote to carriers in October this year seeking a report on their progress in implementing these guidelines in Victoria and nationwide.

With regard to the improvement of information that carriers supply to councils, the code requires carriers to provide local councils with full details of any proposed activity in their local area. If local carriers are not satisfied with the information, the national code enables them on at least two occasions to seek additional information from the carrier. The information package that the minister supplied to councils explains these rights.

With regard to ensuring local councils have enough time, to ensure that there cannot be indefinite delays to the carriers roll-out there needs to be some upper limit placed on the period of consultation. But to enable meaningful consultation to take place and solutions to be worked through, new consultation procedures were specified in the current code.

With regard to encouraging carriers to fully comply with planning, et cetera, the parliament decided to exempt all three carriers by regulations made under the Telecommunications Act 1991. These exemptions are necessary to ensure that benefits to the public are not prevented. But, when undertaking an exempt activity, the carriers must comply with the obligations imposed by the telecommunications national code and with all relevant state and territory laws that are not specified in the telecommunications exempt activities regulations.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to Senator Ray, the Minister for Defence. I refer to the 400 Queensland sites affected by unexploded ordnance left from the Second World War and consequent effects on land values for these innocent purchasers. I ask: is the government going to extend the 100 per cent funding and no contamination promise to all affected properties which Mr Lavarch gave to the properties in his electorate? What does the government intend to do to assist existing landowners to have their lands cleared for safety and contamination purposes? Despite Mr Lavarch's promise to his constituents, will assistance to other landowners be limited to the government's 1990 policy of no responsibility?

—In 1990, the Prime Minister and the premiers discussed the question of unexploded ordnance—which is not necessarily dangerous material but in some cases is. The decision was to review all sites around Australia, which comes to 1,070. So the government is progressively doing that. At the moment I think some seven sites have been reviewed, going through the past records and history. Once those reviews are available, they go to the Queensland Department of Environment and Heritage and they, in fact, do the classifying.

PARA.TAB: The nub of the problem is that in some cases, of course, there is lack of knowledge or lack of proper advice to the Queensland department as to how to classify. The difficulty is that from the production of the first report, which is a very broad-brush one, to the defining of actual areas affected there is always that no-man zone, if you like, in which worry occurs as to whether property is affected.

In some cases many of these properties, arising out of activities in the Second World War, had compensation offered or paid for any unexploded ordnance or any other contamination of the property. Therefore, all accounts are settled. In some instances, no compensation was either offered or accepted at the time. Basically, that is the case in Mr Lavarch's area.

The argument was not whether those property holders would have their property marked as contaminated; it was: what advice would we in Defence give the Department of Environment and Heritage? One of the things we offered at least—and our view is that most of that area is not contaminated; therefore, the title should not be amended to show it is contaminated—was a random sample. That is the only thing that has been offered to Mr Lavarch's electorate—a random sample, on the basis that compensation was never paid, so that we can clearly define the area.

As to the other six areas so far in which reports have come in in Queensland, it is necessary for us to give advice to the Department of Environment and Heritage as to what our view is of the contamination. On these other sites the historical records are far more accurate, but there may be occasions when we also have to opt for random sampling in some of those areas too if we are uncertain as to what advice to give the Department of Environment and Heritage in Queensland.

We are also trying to do an overarching plan between the two departments to come up with a methodology that will be consistently applied through Queensland—something that has not been done before, and maybe something that should have been done earlier—so that you will not have these sorts of scare campaigns, which I am sure you have picked up, that are often run.

So, in answer to your question, what we are doing about it is making recommendations to the Department of Environment and Heritage so that they can, in fact, classify the land. Where no compensation has been paid, which is not necessarily obvious at the moment, that will be a matter for future government policy. But where compensation has been paid in the past, it is up to the landholder to then rectify whatever problem is on that land. We cannot have double dipping. The one thing I also assure you about is that, if any dangerous ordnance is found, Defence then goes to the assistance of the landholder and defuses and deals with the problem without any charge to the landholder at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister for his comprehensive answer and, by way of a supplementary question, I ask: will the same benefits and compensation be given to all other landowners in different electorates as those offered by Mr Lavarch to his electorate?

—I cannot verify what Mr Lavarch may have said, Senator, but I have said to you here that the only expenditure by Defence which is over and above what we normally do is the random sample surveys, which came in, I think, at approximately $20,000. That is to help us give advice to the Department of Environment and Heritage. Where that requirement is elsewhere—that is, the historical records are too bare for us to be able to make these sorts of judgments—again, we will probably apply the same modus operandi. In terms of compensation, though, if compensation has been paid, it will not be repeated. If it has not been paid, then that is a matter for future government policy.

—In accordance with procedural order No. 16, I ask the Minister representing the Prime Minister for an explanation as to why my question on notice No. 2362, which I asked on 11 August this year, has not been answered.

—The Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet thought it more appropriate to direct that question, as they often do, to another portfolio for answer. They directed it to Treasury for answer. Treasury, however, before they can answer that, have sought advice from Attorney-General's and the Reserve Bank as to whether they can even answer the question. That is where the matter rests. Your raising it today surely will prompt them to expedite that advice and maybe get you an answer as soon as possible. But I can be of no more assistance.
—I have been away for 24 hours husbanding my constituents.
—What are you doing, Senator Crichton-Browne? Are you seeking leave?

—I am about to ask you a question, Mr President. I have been away so I have not been privy to any further discussions or negotiations as to whether or not the coalition have first call on responses to ministers' answers or whether personal explanations can be given. I would have thought that, where there is no other business before the chamber, decency would dictate that any senator who feels that he has been impugned or his reputation tarnished or challenged or in any way threatened should have at the first opportunity a right to put that matter for correction.

PARA.TAB: However, Senator Hill takes a different view. I understand why. At the present time people are more interested in my personal explanations than responses to opposition questions. I am not critical of that. I will bow to whatever decision you ultimately make. I just seek clarification because there are two matters today which I am going to raise by way of personal explanation under standing order 190.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is clearly a matter for the Senate. It is a question of seeking leave when there is no business before the chair, which you have a perfect right to do. It is just a question of convention that we try to keep that until after taking note of answers. But it is only a convention; it is up to the Senate.

—Mr President, given my archaic values and views of life, I would be the very last to change a convention. Therefore, I will concede that my personal explanations should prevail subsequent to the business of the chamber, that being taking note of ministers' answers.

—Yesterday in question time Senator Boswell asked me a question where he asserted that AQIS has only two plant technologists. The reason I did not answer the question at that time was that I did not know what a plant technologist was. It is not an expression that is familiar to me. I thought there may have been a classification of plant technologist and I wanted to give Senator Boswell the most accurate answer possible. I have, in fact, determined that there is no such thing as a plant technologist within AQIS and that—
—Entomologists.

—I assumed, Senator Boswell—and thank you for your interjection—that you were talking about entomologists. `Plant technologists' simply refers to people with scientific qualifications engaged in AQIS to deal with plants. That being the case, Senator Boswell's claim that there are only two is, in fact, nonsense. The situation is that AQIS either employs or has access to a wide range of high level expertise in plant science—
—I said `employs', not `access to'.

—Listen, Senator Boswell, I will answer the question precisely. You heard what I said. AQIS either employs or has access to a wide range of high level expertise in plant science, including entomologists, plant pathologists, botanists and staff with other relevant scientific qualifications. AQIS employs directly 28 scientific positions of people who are in the plant quarantine and export area but have scientific qualifications in those areas—that is, plant pathologists, botanists, entomologists, and so on. Twenty-eight, Senator Boswell, so I do not know where you got your figure of two from.

PARA.TAB: There are 14 positions within AQIS that handle quarantine policy issues in international market access matters. There are 14 positions responsible for technical operational issues in plant quarantine, import clearance and export inspection. In addition, AQIS engages directly, through its state operations, the services of a further 19.3 full-time equivalent plant scientific staff who handle day-to-day program delivery issues. In some cases, these are permanent full-time jobs, and in other cases AQIS engages state specialists, as necessary, on a contract basis.

In addition, as I pointed out before, AQIS has direct access, as necessary, to the plant scientists within the Bureau of Resource Sciences, which, of course, is also within the Department of Primary Industries and Energy. In addition, AQIS contracts, as necessary, high level scientific expertise within the CSIRO, universities and other research institutions. I think that demonstrates, comprehensively, I might add, that Senator Boswell's assertion in the Senate yesterday, which he followed up with a press statement last night, that AQIS has only two people with technical or scientific qualifications in this area is a nonsense.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) to a question without notice asked by Senator Short this day, relating to the funding of trade unions .

SPEECH.PARA: I asked the minister whether he could confirm that answers I had received from questions that I had put to ministers over recent years about these payments, which show that well over $90 million has been paid to the unions in direct grant funding, and that even this huge figure excludes certain large payments—for example, the funding of the Trade Union Training Authority that costs around $10 million per year. When you add up all the money that has gone from this government to the trade union movement in the 12 years since Labor came to power in 1983, on a very conservative estimate, the figure would be a minimum of $160 million.

PARA.TAB: That money has been used in a wide range of areas, including in particular to pay back the trade union movement for contributions that it has made to Labor's election campaigns. During the 1993 election campaign, for example, the trade union movement gave $3.5 million to Labor to assist in the funding of the election campaign. It gave direct donations of $2.1 million and engaged in an advertising campaign in support of the government which cost about $1.3 million or $1.4 million—a total of $3 1/2 million.
