TALK.START.PARA: —What is more disturbing than this blatant rorting of taxpayers' funds is that the government shows no shame at all. It does not have any conscience. It does not show any shame. It does not even show any embarrassment. The Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Ray, got up in response to my question today and said that it was a perfectly legitimate use of taxpayers' money to fund these various activities.

PARA.TAB: There would not be a taxpayer in Australia who would know that their taxes are going to trade union activities in the way that has become an art form for this government. The minister's response today was a classic example of what is, at the very least, the amorality of this government. This government does not know the difference between right and wrong. It cannot distinguish between legitimate uses of taxpayers' funds and legitimate uses of its role in government and those uses which, by the standards of decent Australians, would be regarded as a disgraceful and dishonest abuse of power and privilege.

TALK.START.PARA: —I read with interest an article in the Australian—and I do not know whose article it was—that highlighted all of the—
—What does it say on the by-line?
—I am not quite sure. It says Laura Tingle.
—You can't read.

—I can read some simple things, Senator Campbell. What I found most unfortunate about the article and Senator Short's question, his speech in taking note of the answer and his claims is that they try to infer that unions are the only ones that are in receipt of taxpayers' money.
—Not at all.

—You certainly left out a chunk of others who get money—namely, a lot of employers. If we look at the accurate figures for 1988-89 to now and look at the moneys that have been distributed by the Department of Industrial Relations between employers and unions we find that nearly $21 million has been granted to unions for various purposes.

PARA.TAB: When we look at employers, we find that nearly $43 million has been granted. I do not hear you complaining about that, Senator Short. I do not hear the opposition complaining about the fact that that is taxpayers' money too. You might think there might be some objection from taxpayers about that portion of the money. Senator Short made some reference to other departments.

I am quite sure that the National Party, through Senator Sandy Macdonald and Senator Brownhill, who are in here at the moment, would not want you complaining about all of the funds that are collected off taxpayers in cities, et cetera, that go to assisting farmers and other people, and rightly so, I might add. That is something that we support because we have been implementing those sorts of programs. You are not complaining about that. You are not saying the taxpayers in the city would complain about that, because they should not. It is a very fair thing to do.

It is the role of government to ensure that all the changes that are brought about in various places happen. But, of course, Ms Tingle and Senator Short have chosen to ignore that, to actually pick on unions. It is a great reflection of how you would deliver an industrial relations policy if you are lucky enough to ever win government. If you are ever lucky enough to win government, we know exactly what you intend to do. You will probably turn this around to giving employers the whole lot and the unions and employees nothing.

We talk about political donations. It is a very interesting matter to raise in terms of maybe inferring that unions are using some of the taxpayers' money they receive to do legitimate and very worthwhile exercises and that they have somehow filtered that back to the Labor Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —They do.

—Senator Parer says they do. What about these employers that get all of these millions? What about your trust that you want to keep very quiet and secret? You do not want to identify where all the money comes from in that. You deliberately set it up so it cannot be looked at. Why do we not have a good look at that? Senator Ray was right. Why do you not bring that in here and put it on the table so we can have a good look at it? Why do you not bring it in here so we can tell the people of Australia what it is all really about and where the money came for that? That is what you really should do if you are really honest about the system, if you are really serious about uncovering any misuse of money.

PARA.TAB: It is very easy for the opposition to get up and make these spurious claims about what happens to money and how it is spent. But, again, what you miss is a very important point: a very significant number of employers have joint funding arrangements, I might add, under the Department of Industrial Relations system where over $6 million went to joint union-employer sponsored programs.

When you look at what has happened in the industrial relations system in this country it becomes clearly evident that all the money that is being spent from the point of view of both the unions' side and the employers' side has seen this country become much more competitive, much more efficient and much more productive. That is something that did not happen under you people for 26 years. For 26 years you did nothing. It is a pathetic effort, Senator Short, to come in here and make the ridiculous sorts of claims that you have made here today. It should be totally ignored because it is pathetic for what it stands for.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to comment on the same matter and support Senator Murphy's comments. It is important that we place on the record that what we have seen today is a one-sided representation of the government's encouragement for representatives of employees and employers in this country to improve our industrial relations system, encourage enterprise bargaining and a range of other activities that improve the workplace. These include assistance for migrant workers, learning English on the job and all those sorts of things—all are represented in the gross figures that have been presented in the parliament quite misleadingly today.

PARA.TAB: I pay tribute to the government's efforts in supporting employer organisations in one of my duty electorates. I had the pleasure of presenting grants from the government that were not mentioned earlier today to two employers in the very safe Liberal seat of Forrest: Albany Woollen Mills Ltd and the Bunbury City Council. Both those organisations received grants from this government similar to the ones referred to today to encourage enterprise bargaining within their workplaces. Far from only funding trade unions, we have a very comprehensive and even-handed approach to improving industrial relations and productivity in this country.

Another thing the Liberal Party fails to recognise in their comments in debate is that, since early this century, legislation passed by both this parliament and state parliaments has encouraged the development and role of unions of employers and employees in this country. Our whole conciliation and arbitration system has been built upon the recognition of the role that unions of employees and unions of employers play in this country. We have had legislative support for these organisations for many years.

The Trade Union Training Authority was established by the Whitlam government but was supported by and expanded under Malcolm Fraser, to his credit, throughout his term of government. We are seeing a really right-wing agenda taking hold over the Liberal Party. It is interesting that the comments made by Senator Short today are based on the Institute of Public Affairs document released a few months ago.

Right-wing think tanks are again influencing the Liberal Party to their great detriment. What we are currently seeing in my state of Western Australia is the Liberal Party losing support because of their hard right-wing ideology being reflected in industrial relations legislation. Today we are seeing again an attack on trade unionism in principle. They cannot live with the idea of unionists providing protection to workers in this country.

The classic example of that is what happened in relation to minimum wage conditions in Western Australia. Under the previous Labor administration, minimum wages were set within an award context by the industrial commission after it heard argument from the employers and the trade unions about the appropriate minimum wage. Therefore, an independent umpire set that minimum wage.

What we are seeing in Western Australia under the Liberal IR policies is that they have given the right to the Liberal industrial relations minister to set minimum wages. He recently got a recommendation from the industrial commission as to what that rate should be. He decided to reduce that recommended increase by 30 per cent. He set the new minimum wage in Western Australia at a lower rate than the one recommended by the industrial commission. He did not have to worry about the influence of unions in the system.

PARA.TAB: I congratulate unions and employers on the role they have played in this country. Under Labor governments, they will continue to receive encouragement and support. TALK.START.PARA: —It is absolutely obscene that you have three people from that side of the aisle speaking on this matter. Clearly, they are very precious about Laura Tingle's article. Senator Wheelwright is probably ringing up his office to get some notes sent down so he can make a speech. Senator Burns is having a good scratch of the old skull at the moment trying to think of something that he can say. I guess we will just go through to quarter to four, Madam Deputy President, with these Labor mates of the trade unions.

PARA.TAB: This government is prepared to hand out millions upon millions of taxpayers' money to their union mates to be used for ostensibly blatant political purposes. Laura Tingle's article—and she is called Laura Tingle, Senator Murphy; the honourable senator wanted to make some obscene, sexist point about Laura Tingle because he did not happen to agree with what she wrote in the article—did not tell the Australian taxpayers one important thing. Senator Short referred to it, and that was in relation to the hidden gifts that this Australian Labor Party government gives to its union mates.

This Senate, of course, was informed shortly after the last election of the deal that the government's car hire company, Dasfleet, provided to the Transport Workers Union when it provided something like 72 executive quality vehicles to the Transport Workers Union at rates that were something like 300 per cent below the going commercial rate—delivering a multimillion dollar handout to one small select group.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, on a point of order: I do not mind Senator Campbell standing up and raising particular matters, but there is an obligation to be factual and he simply is not being factual. It is totally unfair on people who have no capacity to come in here and defend themselves.
—Senator Murphy, that is not a point of order—that is a debating point.
—The Transport Workers Union received millions of dollars worth of hidden subsidies. The only reason that the taxpayer is aware that they were given executive quality Ford Fairmonts—
—Outright lies!
—Withdraw that! Madam Deputy President, on a point of order: we saw a disgraceful display of bad language from Senator Murphy yesterday in the chamber.
—You have got to be joking!
—And he now seems to think it is funny that he wants to demean the Senate by his behaviour.
—Goodness me! You are just a pompous little twit.
—You can withdraw that too!
—Senator Schacht?
—I'll withdraw.

—Madam Deputy President, if I can continue with the point of order: Senator Murphy quite clearly used unparliamentary language and then was proceeding to march out of the chamber so that he would not be required to withdraw it. I think that is disgraceful. I am asking that he withdraw the grossly unparliamentary language he used against Senator Campbell. And further, Madam Deputy President, I would suggest that you instruct Senator Murphy that if he continues to do this, it is a gross contempt of the Senate.
—Senator Murphy, will you withdraw those remarks?
—Madam Deputy President, I assume that the words I used were `outright lies' and I will withdraw that. But I will make this point—
—No, Senator Murphy—
—I will replace it with: absolute mistruths.

—Madam Deputy President, I take the point of order that Senator Murphy has no power, entitlement or right to speak in that way when he is supposed to be withdrawing. He is entitled only to withdraw. He is totally out of order.

—On the point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President: it is only yesterday that I heard Senator Short do exactly the same thing and Senator Short was not stopped from replacing `lie' with `mistruth'.

—The difference, Senator Murphy, was that yesterday it was during the speech that he was making. He rephrased his own sentence in a speech that he was making at the time. I accept that you have withdrawn the words used.

—It is a shame we are not being broadcast because the Australian people know that handing out millions of dollars of taxpayers' money is an obscenity. They know that it is tantamount to corruption. They would not expect any better language or behaviour from someone like Senator Murphy or like Senator Schacht. So it is irrelevant because their behaviour is so hopeless—not only their behaviour and language in the parliament but also their behaviour to the Australian people.

PARA.TAB: Ultimately the truth of this matter can be determined by any Australian citizen who choses to look at the facts determined before the estimates committees in relation to the Transport Workers Union. The government and the minister and even the Transport Workers Union and the Australian Tax Office have all confirmed that the Transport Workers Union was given a gift totalling millions of dollars incorrectly by the Australian Labor government through its car hire company. That is just a fact. Senator Murphy could see that. If he wants to misrepresent it, then I guess he can seek to do that and the Australian people will make their judgment.

That is very much the tip of the iceberg. We only found out about the Labor government giving further hidden subsidies to its transport workers' boss mates because I was tipped off by someone who worked in a Dasfleet depot. He said, `Do you know these union bosses come in and get their Ford Fairmonts serviced here?' I was tipped off by a Transport Workers Union bloke who thought it was corrupt. I asked a few questions and we revealed that. So Senator Short asked how many other rocks you can turn up to see where the money goes to the union mates of this government.

The information provided by Laura Tingle in this morning's Australian is what is known through disclosure. We know that that money goes there. We know that many millions of dollars goes into the Labor Party's coffers from the trade union mates at election time to help them win elections. We know that; that is disclosed. We did not know about the Transport Workers Union until the Transport Workers Union person rang me anonymously and tipped me off. Then I pursued it through the estimates process.

The other thing that the Senate and the Australian people should know is that this government has extended this rort, and Senator Hill knows about this, to the student unions. They have granted—what is the figure now?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is $7 million.

—The amount of $7 million of taxpayers' money is now granted to student unions, $5.5 million in Western Australia. I warned in this place that if those unions accepted that money they would be the subject of coercion and interference by the federal minister. What happened last week, Senator Hill? Mr Crean will actually deduct money or give money to unions depending on what they print in their magazines. (Time expired)

—Madam Deputy President, I draw your attention to the fact that there have been three speakers on this matter from the government side and two from this side. I would imagine under normal rules of fairness that this side would be called.
—I have been calling people as they had stood earlier in the debate. It would be the practice to call from either side of the chamber.

—Could I make a comment on that. I remind you, Madam Deputy President, of the history of this process. It has not been in place long and you are not very familiar with it. It was brought in, in effect, to help balance the imbalance that occurs at question time where ministers get four minutes to an opposition questioner's one. The opportunity, therefore, was to predominantly give the opposition the chance to pursue matters that arose out of ministers' answers and thus to even up the balance sheet.
—Where does it say that here?

—No, it does not. I said `practice'. Listen. You were here then. I simply ask you, Madam Deputy President, to take that history and the purposes of the establishment of this standing order into account in determining who should have the call.

—There is no doubt that there ought to be fairness between the sides. I entirely understand what the senator says. As someone said, this is a very precious matter. That is probably a pretty adequate description of how things are seen. There ought to be fairness in the sense of one from each side taking turns to have a say. There is no doubt that two senators have been called but, in fairness to you, Madam Deputy President, Senator Short was called and then two senators jumped up on this side because no-one jumped up on the other side. I personally have no objection to that being equalised in some way.

PARA.TAB: It is an important matter. Just as Senator Hill and those on his side have to defend matters that are put against them, we have to defend matters that are put against us. This is clearly a very important matter. We have allegations of what amounts to corruption. We have allegations of maltreatment of the funds. Clearly that is something that has to be answered. I would ask Senator Hill this through you, Madam Deputy President: does he say at this time that we should not have a chance to answer the issues that are put up to us as distinct from having a balance and each side having a turn?

TALK.START.PARA: —I felt that Senator Cooney made a very constructive comment, as he does so often. I just wonder whether we cannot resolve this issue by allowing all those who wish to speak—briefly of course—to do so, and after the set half hour is finished, the remaining one or two could make their brief contributions to the debate by leave. In that way I think fairness would be satisfied on both sides.

—I think Senator Cooney summed it up very well. The point I want to particularly raise is this: Senator Hill said that there is a convention that the process of taking note of questions enables members of the opposition to have their say about the answers that ministers have given. That is true. The standing orders are absolutely impartial in that they do not ascribe an advantage to either side. Any senator has the right to make a comment.

PARA.TAB: I have to say in your defence, Madam Deputy President, that you called them as people were jumping, and that meant that for a while there were more people on this side because there was no-one jumping on the other side. I agree with Senator Cooney that, in the balance of these things, commonsense means that there are others on the other side who probably want to jump. There may be a couple more over that way. Does that become a precedent? It is up to the chair to try and keep a balance of interleaving speakers and make a prospective or retrospective judgment about circumstances. One could not write these things down absolutely because circumstances change.

Madam Deputy President, I thought you were calling people appropriately as they were jumping to speak on this issue. It is very difficult not to expect a number of government members not to jump on this particular issue when the opening remarks from Senator Short, to say the least, were partisan and controversial—

TALK.START.PARA: —Robust.

—And robust. He is certainly entitled to be robust. I am not whingeing about that at all. It is certainly not unusual to expect that there would be strong views on both sides on this particular matter. To have several speakers on the opposition side taking five minutes and going way beyond the question would be a bit unreasonable. As I said, Madam Deputy President, I think you have actually called the people correctly and with great commonsense in the debate so far.
—Thank you, Senator.

—Could I draw the notice of the chamber to the fact there have been many occasions, particularly when we first commenced to use this system of taking note of answers, where the opposition virtually had the whole of the time to themselves.
—Senators have been most helpful. I am persuaded by Senator Cooney's usual wisdom. I call Senator Baume.

—Thank you, Madam Deputy President, and I thank Senator Cooney for his usual wisdom. I want to say in this debate that Senator Short has massively understated the nature of the problem. Senator Short, while being robust, has also been, if you like, almost reticent in outlining the full extent of this corrupt practice.

PARA.TAB: Senator Short only referred to the evident expenditure and donations to the Labor Party for political purposes, when we all know there were other donations. And I refer the Senate, if people have forgotten, to a speech I made last week relating to the Australian Workers Union where $58,000 was transferred from an AWU slush fund in Queensland, I think it was, to the firm of Phillips Fox and Partners, a legal firm.

This was a repayment of a donation by Phillips Fox to a slush fund in the AWU for electoral purposes. I do not know, frankly, whether that was for electoral purposes of a particular faction within the AWU—it would be a pretty big donation, if it were—or whether it was a way of getting around the electoral laws and not being revealed. It does seem extraordinary when I look at this list that the only donation I see from the Australian Workers Union to the Labor Party is for $35,144. That seems to me to massively understate the volume of effort and support the AWU put into the Labor Party at the last election.

Apart from anything else, there were teams of unionists involved—I understand, at the expense of the union offices—in campaigning and printing, delivering and distributing campaign material not only in the workplace but in suburban letterboxes. In other words, the union machine, which involves a large administrative operation, was massively diverted at election time into huge support of the Labor Party. At whose cost? It was a hidden cost. It is not costed or revealed. Yet it was at the cost of the Australian worker.

That is why I say, apart from any other evidence of hiding this sort of thing, that there is no doubt that Senator Short was significantly understating the financial contribution by the union movement to the Labor Party at the last election, a contribution which was compensated by the government. We see here—and for example I will pick the AWU—that the AWU received grants in 1992-93 of $135,000. But it reveals that its involvement in political donations was only $35,144.

As Senator Short mentioned in passing, on top of donations and on top of all the work the unions were doing, including printing—I would like to see those printing bills—there was specific advertising conducted by the union movement itself. The ACTU, I think Senator Short said, spent over a million dollars.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was $1.3 million.

—It spent $1.3 million on actively advertising itself on political matters in the last election campaign. There were many others. In fact, there was a report tabled in this parliament which revealed the enormous volume of political advertising by unions at the last election. But none of those, as I understand it, are included in this list of donations that Senator Short has given.
—That's right.

—And he acknowledges that that is right. So on top of the evidence here, there is also the direct involvement by way of advertising, which had to be reported, and secret support which must have added up to hundreds of thousands of dollars at the last election by way of printing and so on. In other words, there has been a massive quid pro quo. The grants given by the government simply make it easier for the unions to do this sort of thing.(Time expired)

—I wish to speak on the same matter, Madam Deputy President. I am encouraged to rise to my feet because of the invitation from Senator Campbell. I would point out that for many years I was an active officer of the metalworkers union which has, in its rules, provision for a political fund. It is clearly earmarked, and a certain amount of contributions are paid by each member for that very purpose. It is in the balance sheets each year, and it has the full support of probably about 95 per cent of the members of that union.

PARA.TAB: I want to talk a little bit about TUTA and the money spent by the government in the training of trade unionists. As would be well known to people in this chamber, and generally in the community, people who work for big business for many years have had the opportunity of training in the areas of economics, human resources and personnel management through university courses that to a great degree were financed by all types of governments from time to time over many years.

Trade union officials and activists within the trade union movement were never able to take advantage of those particular courses because of their disadvantaged backgrounds or the fact that they had to go to work very early in their working careers—at 14, 15 or 16 years of age. The unions themselves—some in particular, and the metalworkers union was an outstanding one—and the ACTU expended quite a substantial amount of their income to begin the training of activists in the trade union movement. It was obviously seen by the Labor Party and others in the community to be a useful practice because it led to more responsible unionism, it led to people having the ability to negotiate meaningfully, and it did head off many a confrontation in industry.

Therefore, with that background, the Labor Party quite correctly—and Mr Cameron, who was then the minister responsible—set up TUTA. I have been to TUTA courses on many occasions. On one particular occasion I remember a seminar about how we could enhance industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Didn't the ACTU pull the library out?
—I am not talking about the library. That is another matter that we can discuss at another time. It has already been discussed and found to be fair and reasonable.

PARA.TAB: The particular seminar I attended talked about the agricultural industry and how people could make a contribution towards making it a bigger and better industry that would provide increased income for people on the land and also for trade unionists working in the processing, transport and other industries. I recall that people were invited to that seminar from business—from Elders and other areas—and they made a very good contribution. There was a collective approach. It was all intended to create further wealth in the community and thus benefit the whole community. It was intended to establish an opportunity for people to cooperate, for people to be in every way supportive of each other and to head off any type of confrontation. It was also designed to develop the sort of communications that enhance this particular process.

If anyone wants to suggest, for instance, that such an activity is not in the interests of the community, or to suggest that all it does is enhance the ability of the trade union movement to confront people in industry and to get higher wages or take some benefit of a selfish nature, then I challenge that, because it was nothing of the sort. It was very constructive, and I believe the money was well spent. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, I claim to have been misrepresented. I seek leave to make a statement in respect to a number of matters.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand a document relating to my appeal to the State Council of the Liberal Party has been obtained by the Labor Party and by the media. So as to ensure that it is not selectively used or misrepresented—regrettable as it is to me that it has been made public, because I was very careful about its circulation—I seek leave to have it tabled.
—Is leave granted?
—Table what?
—Senator Crichton-Browne is seeking leave to table the document that he referred to.
—What document is it?
—Could you explain again the nature of the document, Senator Crichton-Browne?

—The document relates to my position in respect of my recent humiliating expulsion from the Liberal Party. It sets out a number of facts which I assert, as you would imagine, in my favour. I am staggered if Senator Hill would deny me the right to have that now tabled, in view of the fact that it is in the hands of, as I understand it, the government and the media. So that I am certain Senator Hill understands, I will read the whole 128 pages out, if I have to. But I would prefer not to do that. In fact, it would be my preference to have it incorporated in Hansard. I can think of no more serious sanction than to be expelled from one's political party—not the least when you have given a lifetime to it. Madam Deputy President, I just say that, with your indulgence, to Senator Hill.
—When you first spoke, I understood you to say that you wanted to table the document.

—I was actually going to go on to say, `However, my preference would be to have it incorporated in Hansard,' but I was intimidated from doing that by Senator Hill's clear agitation. I do formally request that it be incorporated, for reasons which any person in this chamber will understand.
—Is it, in fact, 128 pages, Senator Crichton-Browne? Tabling might be a more appropriate way of dealing with it.
—Madam Deputy President, you have not had the humiliation of being expelled. Expediency is probably very tempting to you, but it is not to me. I would ask that it be incorporated.
—Is leave granted to incorporate the document?

—I still do not know what document it is, Madam Deputy President. I do not know who wrote the document and I have not seen it. Senator Crichton-Browne will know that the usual practice in this place is to show the leaders of the chamber such documents before leave is sought. He is asking me to agree to the incorporation of 128 pages of material. I do not know what the material is. I do not know who wrote the material. I do not know the authority for the material. I do not know the consequences of tabling the material. If Senator Crichton-Browne does not want to tell me whose document it is, at the very least I would ask that he show it to the opposition—the government might not be interested—before we be asked whether or not we give leave.

—I understand the practice and the convention for incorporation certainly is that material should be shown to senators in the major parties—to the whips or the shadow ministers and the ministers on duty. I think that has been a standing convention for a long time. Senator Crichton-Browne, you said it is 128 pages. I have to say that is a very large document to incorporate into Hansard. I have not seen the document but I think you have described it as your appeal to the Liberal Party and so on. I have to say that a document of 128 pages seems a bit excessive in length to be incorporating into Hansard. I presume that you are concerned about having the document obtain privilege. Anyway, as I say, we have less objection to tabling. I do point out that the government has not seen the document either. But I must say that this seems to be more a matter for the Liberal Party than for the government.

—In response to Senator Hill's question, the author of the document is Noel Ashley Crichton-Browne. It is, as I say, 128 pages. I should not have told you that, but I did not imagine it would excite anybody. It is double case and double spaced. It would shrink very significantly into Hansard.

PARA.TAB: But I am really disappointed that we are debating here today—putting aside Senator Hill's concern that he had not seen it—whether or not it is convenient to have my response to being expelled from a political party incorporated in Hansard or tabled. I personally find it utterly offensive and, if I have to, I will read every single world of it into Hansard. It is not my wish. It would be very uncomfortable for everybody, not the least for me, but I will do it if that has to be the case. It is a document, Senator Hill, which sets out my view of events relating to my expulsion.

With respect, through you, Madam Deputy President, I would be very disappointed in this great party—for which I have a great deal of love and affection, and that has not been tempered or changed—if it were to be the case that there was exception taken to me seeking to allow the chamber and the wider community to understand the reasons why I was expelled from the Liberal Party, from a major political party. To my knowledge, I am the first person in the history of the Liberal Party.

If denying me putting my position on the public record is to be the standard, I would say that it could only be a clear misunderstanding between Senator Hill and myself. If he wants to know what is in it, I will read it. But it is, in essence, my objection to being expelled. Shock! Horror! It sets out the grounds and my rebuttal thereof. I understand some of the government have already seen it, so I have been advised. If Senator Hill wants to see it, he is very welcome to it. I just ask in fairness, decency, integrity, honesty and natural justice that, whatever it says—and it is factually correct—I be allowed to have it stand as part of the Hansard record for my family, for my own reputation and for future generations.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to be seen to be unfair. But, as I said to you, the practice is to show such documents before leave is sought. There is good reason for the practice, and Senator Crichton-Browne is a very experienced senator. I know that because we both entered this place together in 1981, which seems to be—
—The only two senators to enter at that time from our side.

—That is right—a long time ago. The practice of showing it to honourable senators before seeking leave to have it tabled or incorporated is because those in the chamber have the right to ensure that it complies with the standing orders. Once it is on the record, you no longer have that opportunity. We all have to operate within a set of standing orders, whether we like it or not. It is the only way in which you can get, to use Senator Crichton-Browne's expression, fair debate in this place and fair debate on what is obviously a very difficult matter.

PARA.TAB: I must say that, on the face of it, it is a document that sets out Senator Crichton-Browne's grounds of appeal—if that is what it is—and his case and will probably be okay to me. But, without having seen it, I just think it is not reasonable for him to expect me to give leave in those circumstances. If he will show me the document, and he might want to proceed with his personal explanation in the—

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. I understood that by arrangement, immediately after questions and the taking note of answers given to questions, another very brief matter was to come before the Senate, and I wondered why it has not.
—He sought leave.

—I did not seek to make a political point today because, frankly, I am still on this side of politics but I observe that the opposition has made a judgment—about which I do not argue—that responses to ministers' answers ought come before personal explanations. I do not know whether Senator Baume wants me to read out the Hansard, but he was like a little beaver on his feet, jumping ahead in the last fortnight—and I see Senator Baume nodding his head, and I do not criticise him for what he did—seeking leave for a personal explanation before one response on a minister's answer was given. I did not say it at the time, because I was not trying to win points. All I am doing now is asking for procedural fairness. In the event that Senator Hill declines my request, I will seek leave to make a statement. That statement will be the document Senator Hill has; and I will read it out.

—The situation at the present time is that when you sought leave to make a personal explanation, there was nothing before the chair. You were granted leave, as you were entitled. There is another matter that had been adjourned and is to come up after the taking note of answers. That will be called on after you have completed the matter. If you have anything further to say in relation to your personal explanation, now might be an appropriate time to proceed with that while Senator Hill looks at the document.
—Senator Hill will still be reading it long after I have sat down.
—I have no problems with page one.

—Page one, just to seduce the opposition, says some very nice things about Senator Hill. I suggest he goes to the last page, just for balance. While Senator Hill is reading a factually impeccable document, written perhaps with less articulation than might be provided by a Queen's Counsel—but I chose to write it myself because it comes from my soul and my heart, and not from a lawyer—I will raise another matter, if I may.
—Still by way of personal explanation?

—Yes. It causes me very considerable grief to raise this matter. If I refer to notes more extensively than I normally would—and I certainly will not be reading them—it is because I do not want to make a mistake in what I say, in the height of what has been for me and my family a very emotional period.

PARA.TAB: Madam Deputy President, you will recall that earlier this year a claim was made in the state parliament of Western Australia that I had been interviewed by the Australian Federal Police as the result of a complaint against me that I had threatened a fellow Liberal senator. Those threats moved within 24 hours to death threats and were associated with the name of a particular senator.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, I am reluctant to take a point of order—and I am trying to read this document at the same time—but I am puzzled. Leave was given to Senator Crichton-Browne to make a statement on the basis that he claims to have been misrepresented. I have not yet heard where the misrepresentation was supposed to have occurred. I would have thought that that is what the Senate should hear first in order that the Senate can be satisfied that the personal explanation that follows relates to the misrepresentation that was claimed.

—I do not mind Senator Hill being the advocate for the defence but one of the great complaints I always got from the government when I was in the chair during question time was that the opposition took so long in their preamble that the last five seconds was the question and the first four minutes was a lecture to the Senate about the failings and weaknesses of the government. Given that nice irony, I claim to have been misrepresented by certain statements made in the press and in the parliament by a member of the House of Representatives.
—On the point of order, I think you are aware that you do need to stick to those matters that relate to your claim to have been misrepresented. I invite you to couch it in those terms.

—I will, Madam Deputy President. Perhaps, on sober reflection, I was a pretty sloppy chairman because I always thought that what was important was to allow commonsense and fairness to prevail, rather than using sharp points of standing orders to inhibit people from having a reasonable opportunity to make an explanation. I do not reflect on you, Madam Deputy President. It is just that I am surprised and disappointed that it has taken me now 10 minutes to get two lines of consequence out.

PARA.TAB: I remind senators, when they make judgments about the relevance of what I have to say, that I spent two days being the subject of nationwide media saturation that I had made death threats against a member of parliament. I would be, as I have earlier said in respect of another document, very disappointed if I thought points of order were going to be taken to prevent my responding to that, however clumsy my presentation might appear to be. I can think of no more foul, vile, unpleasant allegation than that. If there is not some latitude given to allow me to respond that, I am clearly confused about what democracy I am in and what chamber I am in.

I was the subject of two days of media saturation, assertions of the nature which I have just outlined. You will recall, Madam Deputy President, that at the time I chose to make no response. I declined to respond in any way on the allegations. Subsequently, I made a brief statement in the Senate denying the claim, and the Australian Federal Police also put out a brief statement denying the assertion. That was only done with grave reluctance by me. I did not want the facts or the reasons for their inquiries to be exposed because it was what one might loosely describe as a covert operation and it was likely to be compromised if I made any statement. So I and my family put up for two days with my being accused of threatening somebody's life because I thought it was more important that the proper processes of investigation be pursued, whatever price I had to pay. I have since been reluctant to make further comment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. I am disappointed that I have to interrupt. As the senator said, this is a very serious matter. He is saying that it was said that he threatened someone, and obviously an honourable senator should have the right to defend himself in those circumstances. There are processes for doing so. Nevertheless, the method that Senator Crichton-Browne has chosen in this instance is to claim that he has been misrepresented.
—That's the understatement.

—I think that the Senate therefore needs to know where he claims he was misrepresented. It is on that basis that you seek to make your personal explanation, to explain why you were misrepresented. The Senate does not have anything before it at the moment. As Senator Crichton-Browne knows, the usual practice is that `the Sydney Morning Herald said A, B and C and I claim that that is a misrepresentation and the true position is such and such' and you sit down. Where is the misrepresentation in this instance in order that we can attach to it the personal explanation that is being made?
—You are speaking to the point of order?

—Yes. If I did not know Senator Hill better, I would say that he is trying to prevent me from saying anything. I would not be that ungracious. Can I say that, if it puts the question to rest, there are a number of articles, which I have before me, which claim that investigations were stimulated by me for political reasons. It has also been claimed, Senator Hill, through you, Madam Deputy President, that I made threats. If that is not a misrepresentation, what is? It was in every single media outlet, both in print and electronic form, in Australia and, I am sad to learn, even in a London newspaper. If you are trying to gag me from putting the facts straight, Senator Hill, please say so, so I know what I am about and I will attack it from another direction.

—Senator Crichton-Browne, you need to be precise about the misrepresentation. There are occasions in the life of the Senate when you have the opportunity to make a speech expressing your feelings on matters which may have occurred, but this is the time for a personal explanation relating to a misrepresentation.

—I accept what you are saying and that is exactly what I am doing. I claim to be misrepresented. I will give you the articles. There were a number of articles in the West Australian and the Sydney Morning Herald on 28 July. I can go through them. I claim to be misrepresented. It was asserted that I had conducted myself in a certain way and that is untrue. I do not need another forum. Under standing order 190, I am entitled to correct a false assertion and this is a false assertion.

PARA.TAB: If you will forgive me, because of the severity of the allegation, I am taking some time to get the facts. I am disappointed if somebody is trying to prevent me from disclosing the facts because they have something to fear in respect of this matter. I will continue—

TALK.START.PARA: —Just read the bit in the article that claims what you say.
—The claim is that—
—What article?
—Who am I answering to—Senator Hill or God?
—Order! You are directing your remarks on where you claim to have been misrepresented through the chair.

—I will not proffer any advice to you, Madam Deputy President. I do not think you or I need the assistance of anybody on my right in making these determinations. One article in the Australian claims that Mr Cameron has been cleared of certain things which were caused by me as the result of a political campaign. Mr Cameron was asked, `Do you believe today's events were linked to the factional war in WA of the Liberal Party?' Mr Cameron said, `It certainly looks that way.' I will get my office to bring a truck load of papers if you want me to.

PARA.TAB: I have been reluctant to comment on this matter. However, in view of certain events and in view of Mr Cameron's comments in the last few days that he has been cleared, I am compelled in fairness to my family, my staff, my extended family, my friends, myself and, in decency, to all caring people in Australia to put the facts. The Australian Federal Police attended my office on several occasions as a result of a complaint by me. That complaint was that I was subject to what I would euphemistically describe as blackmail. In fact, they were threats. They were offences under section 28 of the Commonwealth Crimes Act that carry a penalty of three years imprisonment—

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. Firstly, Senator Crichton-Browne would make life a lot easier for some of us if he would read the passage that he says includes a misrepresentation and which he says concerns him. He seems reluctant to do that. Secondly, I understood what he was doing was seeking to argue that it was said that he had threatened someone. That does not seem to be the argument that he is developing at the moment, unless I have missed something that is fundamentally obvious to everyone else.

PARA.TAB: Obviously, it is very serious if it is said that a member of parliament has threatened someone. Clearly, that member of parliament—I do not think it has been done in the correct form here—has the right to put the record straight. That does not seem to be what this is about now. This seems to be about the role played by a third party or the conduct of a third party. I am relying on the rather technical point which is that the misrepresentation has not been set out. I think I have good reason to rely on that technical point. The basis of the explanation that has been given so far does not relate to what the honourable senator said it would relate to and that is an accusation that he made a threat against some person or persons.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the point of order, I would never disclose private conversations but I fear that Senator Hill, as a result of my having the decency to tell him what I was going to raise today, is concerned about the bottom line. I have spelt out, Senator Hill, that allegations were made against me of which you are well familiar, as is everybody in Australia who is vaguely capable of reading a newspaper or watching television.

PARA.TAB: Also, it has been claimed by Mr Cameron that the raid on his office was politically motivated as a result of a complaint by me. They are pretty clear grounds for a personal explanation, Senator Hill. I am sure you understand that. I understand your debating point. But, frankly, we are not here on the debating points; we are here on the facts. I have given you the grounds, and I am arriving at the grounds. I am developing the background for my reluctance thus far to make any public comment about it.

The allegation was that the complaint had been made against me. I am correcting that, Senator Hill. You can understand that. I have said the Australian Federal Police attended my office on several occasions as a result of a complaint by me not a complaint against me, Senator Hill, of which you are well familiar. The sections about which I complained were section 28 of the Commonwealth Crimes Act, which says:

Any person who, by violence or by threats or intimidation of any kind, hinders or interferes with the free exercise or performance, by any other person, of any political right or duty, shall be guilty of an offence.

SPEECH.PARA: Section 85ZE of the same act relates to reckless use of telecommunications to harass or menace another person. That is the truth of the matter, not that I was making death threats against anybody.

PARA.TAB: Following my complaints, my wife, my staff and I were interviewed on several occasions by members of the Australian Federal Police. In the case of my wife and I, we were interviewed for many hours. My wife, I might tell you, Senator Hill, and I hope you will not take a point of order here, was the recipient of a disgusting and foul letter put into her letterbox without an envelope which my son collected after school. So hurt and humiliated by it was he that he hid it under a tissue box. When his mother got home, and after being terribly agitated for several hours when he should have been doing his homework, he said, `Mum, there is under that tissue box a piece of paper I think you should read.' It was a most disgusting, vile piece of paper written to my wife and stuck in the letterbox deliberately, in my view, intended that my children should read it, otherwise it would have been in an envelope.

Subsequently, and presumably after extensive and exhaustive inquiries, the Australian Federal Police executed upon the electorate office of Mr Eoin Cameron, the member for Stirling in the state of Western Australia, a warrant which, as Senator Bolkus has said in this chamber on a previous occasion, is not obtained, sought nor executed except under the most serious and grave circumstances. The search warrant named Mr Cameron; his son, Ryan, employed by Mr Cameron as his electorate officer; and two other members of his personal staff. It said in part:

SPEECH.PARA: On or about March 27, April 2, April 4 and June 7, 1995, any or all of the above wrote and/or sent facsimile transmissions supplying threats or intimidation to hinder—

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, I raise a point of order. The matters relating to this search warrant were all in the public media. I do not think there is any secret about that or the execution of the warrant. I vaguely recall seeing it on television. I am still puzzled as to where Senator Crichton-Browne claims to have been misrepresented in a way that justifies a personal explanation. He will not agree with this, but we have been very lenient in not pressing the standing orders more vigorously than what might be entitled and expected in these circumstances.

PARA.TAB: As I understand him, he said that he made a complaint on the basis of communications he received, which he believed may have been in breach of the Crimes Act. As a result of that, certain investigations were carried out. That is very interesting, but certainly no suggestion of any misrepresentation has been made clear to me in this chamber today, which is the basis upon which he has sought leave to explain away. He has to be brought back to that. Otherwise, Madam Deputy President, as you correctly said, if he wants to, there are opportunities and procedures whereby he can certainly come in here and talk about complaints he made and actions that were taken upon those complaints. But this is not the occasion.

It also seems to be very different from where I thought Senator Crichton-Browne was starting this debate, as I heard him, which is that some threat had been made against him as a senator. If you say that he should do so, perhaps he might again come back to the issue of the misrepresentation and explain to me where it has occurred.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the point of order: I give Senator Hill a gold star for inhibiting my speech today and the facts contained therein. I have said that an assertion was made that I had made death threats. I am seeking to reveal quite the opposite.
—But who made that assertion? Where has that assertion been published?
—You know that it has been made in every media outlet in Australia.

—Senator Crichton-Browne, your remarks in the last 2 1/2 minutes prior to this point of order certainly relate to matters of great importance to you, but they are not related to any case presently put before the Senate relating to misrepresentation. They may well be matters about which you would wish to speak, but they do not relate to the specific point of order under which you were given leave to speak. It is necessary for you to quite clearly enunciate the extent and the place where you have been misrepresented to enable it to continue. I also point out that at 4.30 p.m. we will proceed to general business.
—I want to take this one step further. I can tell that Senator Crichton-Browne thinks I am being unreasonable.
—Well, of course you are; so do you.

—I do not, actually. If an assertion has been made that Senator Crichton-Browne made death threats, he has every right to come in here and say that he has been misrepresented. I certainly hope that he has been misrepresented. He has the right to say that it is not true. It might be debatable, but he also has the right to produce any information that supports his demonstration that it was untrue. I would not be taking any points of order on that. But that is not what Senator Crichton-Browne has sought so far to do in this personal explanation. He has diverted to an issue of complaints he made to the Federal Police about the alleged conduct of others.
—Are you going to talk it out to 4.30 p.m., Robert?
—No. I am not trying to talk it out to 4.30 p.m.

—I have said in the clearest term that an allegation was made against me. I am saying it is not true and I am putting the record straight. Is that difficult? Is that churlish? Is that hard to follow? Is that beyond the capacity, competence and intellect of members of this chamber to understand? Vile allegations were made against me and I am putting the record straight. It has been put to me that I am not speaking under standing order 190 within my entitlements. That is an absolute nonsense. I seek leave for an extension of time to continue my remarks.
—Leave is sought by Senator Crichton-Browne to continue his remarks on this issue—it being 4.30 when we would otherwise proceed with general business. Is leave granted?
—For how long?
—For how long, Senator Crichton-Browne?
—It depends for how long I am interrupted, but I should have thought that I could knock it over well inside 10 minutes, probably five.

—Senator Crichton-Browne should understand that we have already squeezed out the matter of public importance on the issue of long-term unemployment today. The next item of business is the industrial disruption in Western Australia. Both are very important public issues. Before I get jumped upon, I am not saying that they are of greater importance than an allegation that is made against an honourable senator that he made death threats—I actually do not think they are. But we have had 20 minutes and if we had started off with putting on the table the public statement of the concern to the senator, which we still do not have—the Senate had it denied it, which we finally got to after 20 minutes and then heard the case in support of the denial—the matter would have been resolved by now. I still have this document on which you sought leave. I have got to page 2 of 128 pages. I do not know what the plan is in relation to that.
—The question is: is leave granted for an extension of time for—what is it, five minutes?
—Five minutes.
—Is leave granted?

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, I take it the five minutes does not include points of order?
—Senator Crichton-Browne, you need to place before the chamber precisely, really, the matters about which you claim that somebody has misrepresented you.

—Madam Deputy President, I have been accused of death threats. Understood? I am saying it is not true and I am telling you what the truth is. I am telling you the truth is as follows, to wit: a warrant was executed not against me, not as the result of a personal complaint against an individual, but after proper inquiries by the police against Mr Cameron. To go on from where I finished off:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . wrote and sent facsimile transmissions and/or letters conveying threats or intimidation to hinder or interfere with the exercise, performance of Senator Noel Crichton-Browne, of his political right or duty in an effort to influence him to resign or withdraw from his preselection or to withhold his nomination as a senator within the Liberal Party, contrary to section 28 of the Crimes Act 1914.
That is what was put before me and I go on to say that—

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, on a point of order: I am very reluctant to do this—
—You are not reluctant.

—I am because I would much prefer to be dealing with the matter upon which you claim to be misrepresented. You are going on to a different issue of an investigation against another person relating to other matters.
—Which is the explanation.
—But you have not made out any connection between that—
—If you sit down long enough, I will.

—At the moment you have not made out a connection between that action and the claim that you have been misrepresented concerning apparent allegations that you made death threats. So, if we could come to that point, I think it would be helpful.
—I have to say to you that, even as a leader with obligations to try to gag somebody who might embarrass your party, you really are going beyond the limits.
—It is important, Senator, that you make it plain who has misrepresented you.

—I've been misrepresented by Eoin Cameron and by every media outlet in Australia, Senator Reid. In fact, as a result of the execution I was attacked in the media by Mr Cameron and, as I recall, by Mr Chaney and one or two others in the Liberal Party who thought it was good sport. Mr Cameron called on me to pay for the cost of the inquiry and has stated that he is seeking legal aid from the government. The Australian Federal Police have as a result of their inquiries with respect to my complaint—

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I take a point of order. I still do not see any connection—and I do not hear Senator Crichton-Browne seeking to make out a connection—between that and the death threats. He says he has been misrepresented by Mr Cameron, but there is no relationship with the issue which he claims is the critical issue on which he is seeking to clear his name, and upon which he has every right to clear his name. But you have to come back to that. Otherwise, if you want to talk about the role others may have played in different matters or other investigations, then there are occasions, and proper occasions, on which it can be done within the forms of this place. It is difficult. I was going to say it is becoming unfair to other senators who want to pursue other matters today—
—That's insulting, Robert, absolutely damned insulting—that some senators have something more important than explaining that he didn't make death threats.

—Order, Senator! There is no doubt about your desire or ability to make an explanation of things that have occurred, and in an adjournment debate or in another place you could range widely as you are doing. Under this particular standing order it should relate to the actual misrepresentation that has been made against you.

—The misrepresentation, for the tenth time, is that I made death threats and I'm saying I didn't and I'm explaining what really did happen. I have explained that the Australian Federal Police made inquiries following my complaints, and not complaints against me. They found that was there was not evidence for a charge. They did not say there was no evidence; they said there was no evidence for a charge. Mr Cameron has stated that the DPP contacted him. He obviously has not got the wit to understand why they would be contacting him and not the Australian Federal Police. It does not seem to have dawned on him.

—I take the point of order again. The question as to whether or not a charge was brought against a third party on the basis of complaints which may or may not have been made by Senator Crichton-Browne relating to other matters is not relevant to the issue of whether death threats were made against Senator Crichton-Browne. Again, I regret to say that Senator Crichton-Browne is using this occasion—he accuses us of being unreasonable—as an attempt to attack third parties but not relating it back to the occasion on which he claims he has been unfairly treated through publication.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I will take but 120 seconds because Senator Hill has forced me to shorthand this thing. I will go into detail in the adjournment, and no doubt Senator Hill will be here as diligently as he is now. I assert that the blackmail faxes came from the facsimile machine located in the office of Mr Eoin Cameron and I assert both Mr Cameron and his staff were involved in the commission and execution of the blackmail against me.

—I take a point of order. The first obvious point of order is that under standing order 193 you cannot make such personal reflections on a person in the other House. That is the first one. The second point of order is again—and Senator Crichton-Browne, who knows the standing orders very well, would know—that it is not only disorderly but, as stated in standing order 193, is `considered highly disorderly'. It is an abuse of process which is quite apparent and entirely disorderly for reasons that are also obviously apparent to anyone who knows the nature of this business.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, what he is seeking to does not relate—he has not made any case that it relates—to the alleged death threats against him at all. Therefore, he is again out of order. As the time has expired, I respectfully suggest that he rethink how he might present his case.

I do not want there to be any misunderstanding at all. If Senator Crichton-Browne claims that it has been alleged that he made threats against somebody I would be the first to stand up here and say that he, as a senator, has every right to clear the record, and I will support him in doing that. But he has to do that. He cannot head off in another direction and seek to do something else. Even if he does that he has to do it under the standing orders. On both occasions he is not doing that. I suggest that he might reconsider how he wishes to present his case and, in the meantime, we can go on with other business.

TALK.START.PARA: —On that point of order: I will not pursue it any further now because clearly Senator Hill is going to jump up every time I speak. I just leave Senator Hill with one sober note: anybody who continues to protest and protect the reputation of the person I have just mentioned does so at the peril of his own reputation.
—That is threatening. Senator Crichton-Browne should be invited to withdraw that.
—Senator Crichton-Browne, would you withdraw that reflection?
—Which reflection was that?
—The reflection you just made in your final remarks.
—I will be thrown out before I will withdraw something which is within standing orders. Would you just explain to me what—
—Senator Hill, I do not think Senator Crichton-Browne was listening when you made that point. Would you make the point again?
—I don't think Senator Crichton-Browne making threats does his position or this institution's any good.

—Stand up, Senator Hill. I can't hear you. Madam Deputy President, could you enlighten me as to the status of the document which I sought to table? It is a very simple, reasonable, fair document, of which I am the architect, which sets out my position in respect to some tragic events that have taken place.
—Leave was not granted and has not been granted at this stage.
—I said that I am more than prepared to read the document and, provided that it is within the standing orders, I would give leave.

—Senator Hill has not yet granted leave for it to be incorporated or tabled. He has not as yet had an opportunity to read it, which he has said he will do. It is a matter which will have to be dealt with subsequently.
—I wonder for how long should I hold my breath? Perhaps Senator Hill could give me some indication of when he intends to make an ex-cathedra decision in relation to the matter.
—I cannot answer that. That is a matter that will have to come up subsequently.

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Michael Baume) agreed to:
That—

PARA.TAB: (i)the statement by the Chairman of the National Gallery of Australia, the Hon. Lionel Bowen, reported in the Australian, that the panel he chaired to select a successor to Ms Betty Churcher on her retirement as Gallery Director had conveyed its unanimous choice of Mr Michael Lloyd to the Department of Communications and the Arts in August 1995, and

(ii)the claim by the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Mr Lee) that his department had not passed the recommendation on to him, so that he did not reject the unanimous recommendation to appoint Mr Lloyd when he decided to reappoint Ms Churcher for a further year; and
