PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 24 October, on motion by Senator Michael Baume:
That the Senate take note of the document.

TALK.START.PARA: —In debating the Australian Dairy Corporation's report, I would like to take the opportunity now to say that the actions of the United States government in relation to dairy exports from their country have been a matter of great concern to the dairy industry in this country. Obviously, the Australian Dairy Corporation is, in some respects, at the front line of what the government has done.

PARA.TAB: I take this opportunity to say that before the Senate rose for the last recess I made some comments about the dairy industry, in particular the subsidies that the Americans were paying on powdered milk product going from the United States to the Philippines. I said to the Senate that I would be raising that matter on a visit to Washington which was to occur in June-July.

I feel it proper that I take this opportunity to recount the meeting I had at the United States Department of Agriculture. Through the courtesy of the United States Information Service and government officials in the United States I had the opportunity to meet with the senior official in the United States Department of Agriculture who is responsible for the allocation of export enhancement program subsidies for agricultural exports. The farm bill sets out a certain amount of money available to EEP. This official and his assistants allocate that portion of the farm bill to particular subsidies on particular products in particular markets.

I thought it was appropriate to raise that subject with him and to say, as I hope honourable senators from both sides of the chamber would say, that it is not satisfactory that these subsidies are used to corrupt an otherwise incorrupt market. The response from the Department of Agriculture was as follows: `It is only 3,000 tons of powdered milk product.' They did not believe that had the effect of corrupting the market.

That may be the honestly held view of the United States Department of Agriculture. It should be a matter of record that that is not the honestly held view of the Australian dairy industry. Subsidies of this nature undermine the integrity of free trade in agricultural products. Subsidies of this nature destroy the fair market price, in this case for powdered milk products in the Philippines.

After an enormous amount of discussion—the argument went on for about 20 minutes—the official in question was forced to concede that every time the United States uses EEP subsidies there are some winners and there are some losers. He concluded that obviously in this case Australia was the loser.

That is an important concession, for the simple reason that hitherto United States trade policy has been predicated, at least in so far as EEP is concerned, on the basis that these subsidies are not intended to corrupt the international market but are intended to protect the international market. The argument that the American government has advanced hitherto has been that these subsidies are used only when the European Community subsidises similar product into that market. The subsidy is designed to neutralise the advantage to the Europeans of their subsidy.

In this case they indicated that we were the losers, not the Europeans. They indicated that Australia was the loser under that subsidy. That should be a matter of great concern. It is also a matter that everybody in primary industry should note. Deep in their hearts the American government must know that what they are doing is damaging to us. I renew the appeal I made there and then that these subsidies should stop because they are damaging the trade of friends of the United States. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.
Debate resumed from 24 October, on motion by Senator Margetts:
That the Senate take note of the document.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the last report of the Horticultural Policy Council. The Horticultural Policy Council has been succeeded by an organisation known as Horticulture 2000 Group, which I chair. The Horticultural Policy Council has had a couple of priorities while it has been in existence over the last five or six years. One of those priorities was to bring about the establishment of a peak body representing horticultural producers in this country. Secondly, the council has been responsible for stimulating debate about a range of policy matters relating to horticultural industries in this country.

PARA.TAB: Certainly, the policy council succeeded very well in the second of those objectives. Over the last few years, it has commissioned a number of reports which deal with fostering particularly the export development of horticultural industries. There are over 100 horticultural industries in this country, ranging from bananas, to citrus, to apples and to walnuts. A number of those industries are sunrise industries, new industries, where a number of critical issues—such as research and development, processing and marketing—are very important in the early stages of development of those industries.

The horticultural industries have been traditionally largely domestically oriented, but a significant change is occurring in that they are now searching for international markets, particularly in Asia. A number of the reports that the Horticultural Policy Council commissioned have stimulated debate not just in the horticultural sector but in the broader agricultural sector.

The Horticultural Policy Council sits along with the Horticultural Research and Development Corporation, another organisation that this government established, that is funded dollar for dollar of R&D for the various horticultural industries. That organisation began in 1988, I think, with quite small funding of $1 million. It is now $15 million or $16 million a year. So it is providing a significant research element in the horticultural sector. We also have the Australian Horticultural Corporation, which is primarily concerned with promotional and marketing type activities.

I would like to place on record the government's appreciation to John Pendrigh, the Chairman of the Horticultural Policy Council. John recognised that the first of its goals that I have mentioned here today—the creation of a peak industry body for horticultural producers in this country—was a very difficult goal to attain. Horticulture is characterised by over 100 different industry segments that are very decentralised with tens of thousands of producers. It is not easy to activate an industry organisation to represent horticultural growers in this country. I know that John Pendrigh and the other members of the Horticultural Policy Council came to the conclusion that that task—despite a significant number of seminars and conferences around the country at both national and regional levels—was, to some extent, beyond them.

The council took a view that, with the creation of Horticulture 2000 by this government, the ongoing stimulation and development of policy could be well handled by Horticulture 2000 and that the Horticultural Policy Council should therefore cease to exist. That is why the report before the Senate is the council's last report. I would like to place on record my thanks particularly to the chair, John Pendrigh. John has been involved in a number of other primary industry activities for this government. He is a man of wide respect and deep experience in the wine industry. (Time expired)
Debate (on motion by Senator O'Chee ) adjourned.
Debate resumed from 24 October, on motion by Senator Woodley:
That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Meat Research Corporation states that the goal of the Japan-Korea markets key program was `to enhance the ability of producers and processors to maximise benefits from the expanding beef markets in Japan and Korea'. Last year when I was on a delegation in Japan and Korea, we saw how the Aussie beef program was going. We picked up one piece of beef one day and had a look at it and it had `Aussie beef' on it. I was expecting to see `Product of Australia', but I saw on it `Product of the United States of America', and I made mention of it in this place. That is how successful the program was. Unfortunately, the Americans were using it, and they have actually used it to good effect, because they have increased market share in Japan and have done a very good job.

PARA.TAB: The Meat Research Corporation makes the point that the market development key program goal is this:

To secure and strengthen current market positions by developing marketing and access strategies which are better than those of our competitors. These strategies have the potential to increase industry gross values of production by up to $1 billion by the year 2001.

SPEECH.PARA: I notice that in the report under the heading `Input requirements for the cattle feedlot industry'—and they are very big—there are some very good figures on the number of cattle that were grain fed in Australia in 1994. The domestic figure was something like 1.2 million, and the export figure was just under 800,000—a total of two million-plus. The optimistic estimates are that in the year 2002 there will be something like 2.6 million grain fed cattle. The pessimistic estimates are that there are not going to be many more than there are now.

PARA.TAB: The amount of grain used to feed cattle, of course, is very important to the grain producers in Australia, because it is a wonderful value adding product when export beef goes through the feedlot industry in Australia, and the best estimate is that about 1.6 million tonnes will be used in the year 2002.

What is of concern to me in this report, which is very well laid out, is the foot and mouth disease status of some of the countries of Latin America, and that is what we have to look out for as beef producers. We have to be competitive, and I will make some points about our competitiveness in a moment. Uruguay is expected to soon be free of foot and mouth disease. The Mesopotamia area of Argentina is expected to be free between 1997 and the year 2000. Paraguay is expected to be free in the year 2005. And Brazil is expected to be free between the years 1997 and 2000. Brazil has something like 144 million cattle, mostly Nellore, so it is going to be a very big competitor with us.

The problem we have as beef producers in Australia, which brings me to the point of the input costs, is that we have a government at the moment that has actually paid lip-service to all our export industries. One of the points that has been made in this report is about the technical barriers to trade, including meat inspection requirements. We all know about that; we are having an inquiry at the moment into the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service. The report talks about the problems with hormonal growth promotants and the minimum residue levels, with which we have just recently had a big problem with helix into Japan.

The point that is really going to make a big difference to beef producers in the future is our competitiveness. The Keating Labor government have not done anything to make us competitive as far as waterfront charges are concerned; they have not made us competitive with our transport costs in Australia. Our transport costs really have a big impact on beef producers. We have wholesale taxes, fuel excise and those sorts of things. Onto the farm and off the farm transport costs are always very big.

We still have the capital gains tax on us as beef producers—de facto death duties. Inflation costs have gone up more than the government thought and more than their good friend Bernie Fraser at the Reserve Bank thought. That is going to make all the input costs to our farming, especially to our beef producers, so much more difficult to bear in the future. It is not going to keep us as a competitive nation.

The New Zealanders are doing us like a dinner as far as competitiveness with beef exports into Japan and Korea are concerned. If we are going to be competitive, we have to get those things right. Basically, we have to have our transport costs and our waterfront fixed up so we can compete with the rest of the world.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that following that contribution on the Meat Research Corporation report and the various issues that have been raised in association with this report, on behalf of the government I would like to make a contribution on this report.
—Make a contribution by taking away some of those taxes and charges on the poor old beef producers.

—I note that you did talk about taxes and charges. I am not going to stray quite that far away from the Meat Research Corporation. But there are three elements that need to be tackled and are being tackled by this government in respect of the competitive position of the meat industry in Australia. The first is improving productivity, including labour productivity and efficiency at meatworks. The second is improving investment levels in new technology at abattoirs, which is also obviously related to both efficiency and productivity levels—
—We are about 1.2 beasts per man day, compared with New Zealand with 3.4.
—I hope you declared your interest.
—I think we should note those interjections about declarations of interest.

—I take a point of order. The whip from the Keating Labor government has just asked me to declare my pecuniary interest. Yes, I am a beef producer; and very proud to be, because I produce export income for Australia.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Herron)—There is no point of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —We got the declaration of interest on the record both through the interjection and by an unnecessary point of order.
—What about your interest as a trade union official, stuffing up the beef industry.
—The third critical issue for reform in the meat industry in this country—
—What are you doing in Queensland, for heaven's sake?

—I hope all these interjections are going into the Hansard—I praised Hansard yesterday for the excellent work they are doing—to illustrate the very noisy and disruptive opposition that we have in the chamber. I listened in silence to their comments about the Meat Research Corporation report but, unfortunately, they do not do the same thing. There is a continual disruption by the opposition because they do not have any policies; all they can do is criticise and say, `We have some policies, but we are hiding them and we will produce them some time.' But back to the meat industry, the third and critical issue for the meat industry—and this is where comparisons with countries like New Zealand are not directly relevant—is that we have a significant transport cost because of distance from the port. That is a very critical cost factor.
—Especially when you have got a wholesale tax like the one you put on us.

—If we read the report—Senator Brownhill, you have read it; as a beef producer you are critically involved and have a vested interest in its activities—the Meat Research Corporation is involved in a number of projects which are tackling these three critical issues: the issue of labour productivity and efficiency; the issue of technological investment at plants; and the distance from ports, which adds to transport costs.

PARA.TAB: I know that Senator Brownhill has been to a number of meatworks. When I was in northern Queensland a fortnight ago I visited a number of meatworks which had varying degrees of technology. It is an unfortunate fact that many of the meatworks around this country are inefficient not because of their labour practices but because their technology systems are outmoded.

TALK.START.PARA: —The tally system—what about the tally system?

—I will get to the tally system in a moment. I have just noticed I have a minute to go. I would love an extension of time, but I know you would not give it to me. It is technological investment that we need to update many of the meatworks. We will not simply improve efficiency and productivity by imposing changes on workers.
—Sixty per cent of those workers wanted to change and you interfered.

—We will not do it by forcing them to give up their wages and conditions and by sacking and bludgeoning them, as is your policy. You support the bludgeoning of workers, individual contracts, taking away the protections of the Industrial Relations Commission—
—I raise a point of order. I think that is a total untruth and I think Senator Sherry should be asked to withdraw it.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Herron)—There is no point of order. It is not my place to determine the veracity or otherwise of statements made by speakers.

TALK.START.PARA: —We know how sensitive the opposition is to that correct claim when they cannot produce their policies to show how they are going to crush workers' wages and conditions. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In 1988, the Federal Airports Corporation was given a difficult task by the government and it has done a good job. It was given a huge debt—a pea and thimble trick—in the Federal Airports Corporation and told to be commercial. Over the time it has done an excellent job with millions of dollars worth of expansions—the most recent being Brisbane's international airport.

PARA.TAB: In recent times the minister for disasters, the Minister for Transport, Mr Brereton, has called down his wrath on what was a good organisation. The former Managing Director, Mr Bill Swingler, left on 31 July 1995; the reason being the minister took away from the FAC the right to charge at airports. Notwithstanding the debt and the job they did, the landing charges in Australia were among the lowest in the world. He decided to take that away so Mr Swingler came to the conclusion that he did not have much of a role left.
On 5 December, the Chairman of the FAC, Mr Conroy, announced that the board of the corporation would be standing down within two weeks. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to place on record my appreciation of the efforts of my fellow Board Members . . .

No-one told the members of the board that they would be standing down. The Minister for Transport had not bothered to tell them that. It really was not a stand-down; it was a request for their resignations.

PARA.TAB: Surprisingly, the new board does not include Mr Neville Wran or Malcolm Turnbull. It does, however, include a close mate of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and Mr Brereton—Mr Peter Sams. Mr Sams is the Secretary of the Trades and Labour Council and has held that position since 1994. He has never worked in the aviation industry or in business. Except for two years, his entire career has been in the trade union movement. He has been put on the board of the Federal Airports Corporation. What are his qualifications? It is very interesting to read about his qualifications. An article in the Saturday portrait section of the Sydney Morning Herald on 14 January 1995 actually points out the background to Peter Sams.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. Is this directly relevant to the report on the Federal Airports Corporation? If it is, the government will have to respond to this unwarranted attack.
—You can respond any time you like. I would love to hear your response.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Herron)—I think it is relevant.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have Peter Sams as a new board member. What qualifications does he have? The article states:

SPEECH.PARA: Peter Sams, the head of the union movement in NSW has had two mentors early in his life.
One was a small Polish woman, who told him . . . he was going to be a cello player. The other was Paul Keating, who guided him through the ranks of the labour movement.
I will just quote from this article, as time precludes us. It states:

PARA.TAB: While music has remained an influence in his life,—

SPEECH.PARA: great for the Federal Airports Corporation—
other powerful forces were shaping his vocation, and Paul Keating was at the forefront of those.

PARA.TAB: By the time Sams decided to leave music for a full-time career in the Labor movement he was firmly under Keating's wing . . . It was Keating who landed Sams his first industrial job at the head office of the Australian Workers' Union.
Unions were a natural progression from his involvement in student politics. Sams had led the first student strike at the Conservatorium against the then Fraser Government cutbacks in education.
Keating again supported him in an aborted attempt to be elected to State politics, by urging him to run for preselection in the State seat of Blacktown at the age of 24.

He signed up his parents as members of the ALP shortly before he was solicited to run, although they were ineligible to vote under the party rules, which require a minimum period of membership. Ironically, Sams ending up losing the preselection by just two votes.

SPEECH.PARA: It goes on to say:
. . . Keating wanted Sams as secretary of the biggest branch in his electorate of Blaxland,—
do you know what for?—
to keep an eye on the numbers for him while he was in Canberra.
The article continues:
Sams remained branch secretary for 15 years and Keating's campaign manager for 10 years.
These are the qualifications if you want to get on a board in a Labor government. It continues:

PARA.TAB: Although the NSW ALP right wing has undergone some cultural changes, it is still intensely tribal. Its most prized character trait is loyalty. That bond was reinforced recently when Paul Keating chose, for his last public engagement of 1994, to speak at the NSW Labour Council's annual dinner as a favour to his old mate, Peter Sams.
It had been Keating who used his influence with the then secretary of the Labour Council, former NSW Premier Barrie Unsworth, to get Peter Sams a job at the council, where he has remained ever since.

SPEECH.PARA: Talk about Coles Myer, you know what the qualifications are to become a member of a board in this government. (Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I was, and am still, going to deal quite directly with the Federal Airports Corporation report, but the opposition is getting a bit agitated because I am speaking on a number of these reports—I point out that two of them directly relate to my portfolio responsibilities. If members of the opposition are going to persist in these highly personal attacks, which has become characteristic of them because they have no policy, then do not complain when government speakers such as me get up to correct the public record.
—What's wrong with that?

—I am going to correct the public record as well as talk directly about the Federal Airports Corporation, particularly in relation to Hobart and Launceston and what is contained in the report on pages 34 and 35. But do not blame us when government speakers get up and respond to your outrageously personal attacks, which is symptomatic of your lack of policy debate—and the policies you do have you want to keep hidden. We really have to prise out of you the so-called tax policy and industrial relations policy.

PARA.TAB: Let me return to Mr Peter Sams, who is a member of the Federal Airports Corporation. Firstly, I would make the point that I am not a member of the right. I think my factional allegiances are well known. I am in the centre left. So I am not a factional colleague, I am not even from New South Wales. My father was born there, and you will probably link that in some way to the right. I know Peter Sams very well. He is the secretary of the New South Wales Trades and Labour Council. That is what gives him an appropriate background to be on the Federal Airports Corporation board.

There is entitled to be a representative of workers on organisations such as this. It is quite common to have that. He is the secretary of the largest peak body organisation in this country, the New South Wales Trades and Labour Council. I think it is quite appropriate that there is a representative of the work force on these organisations.

TALK.START.PARA: —A mate; mates jobs.
—He is not a mate.
—Of Laurie Brereton.

—I can tell you, he is not a mate of Laurie Brereton's. He knows Laurie Brereton. He is a friend, but he is not an uncritical friend. If you read the responses of Peter Sams to some of Laurie Brereton's industrial relations reforms, and they are on the public record, he is not an uncritical supporter of Laurie Brereton. Let us reject that sort of colluding, mateship, uncritical approach of the opposition because it is simply not correct.

PARA.TAB: As far as I am concerned, Peter Sams is one of the pre-eminent trade unionists in this country. Talk to employers in New South Wales. Many of them speak highly of the Secretary of the New South Wales Labour Council as they did of his predecessor, Michael Easson, including some members on the other side of the chamber.

I will turn directly to this report. Look at the financial performance of the various airports. Burnie is not here, which is very disappointing. I recall that some of you got very upset a couple of weeks ago when I talked about Burnie airport, which is one of my favourites. Burnie was privatised some years ago.

Hobart and Launceston are two of the four airports that we are proud to have in Tasmania. It is pleasing to note that the profitability of both the Hobart and Launceston airports has increased significantly. Hobart's profitability is $796,000, and Launceston's is approximately $706,000. The sale of the lease of these two airports, not the freehold sale, will take place some time in the next couple of years. It will certainly take place upon this government's return. This is part of an important aspect of government budget strategy, which is to bridge the relatively small deficit with some asset sales.

What do we have from the opposition, who support in principle selling off everything, including Telecom? They are saying that they will not agree to the sale of airports unless we fix up the noise at Sydney airport and spread the noise around. `Share the pain' were the words of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard). What an irresponsible approach. They have sabotaged the government's budget. They have no policies of their own. They will hold up the sale of an asset because they do not like the noise at Sydney airport. Five years ago, they were telling us to put in the second runway at Sydney. What an irresponsible approach from the opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry Sen The Hon N.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I am conscious of the time. We are to move on to a debate about minimum wages shortly. The Australian Industrial Relations Commission and the Australian Industrial Registry report are very important. The Australian Industrial Relations Commission is one of the most important institutions in this country. Why is it so important? It is important because, unlike most other countries in the Western world, including most countries around the world, we have an independent arbitration system which determines, through awards, minimum wages and conditions for workers throughout the country, certainly in the federal system.

PARA.TAB: One of the important safety nets of our social fabric, including Medicare and superannuation, in addition to the sorts of policies that I have mentioned that this government implemented, has been the Australian Industrial Relations Commission.

At the moment, workers, whether in a union or not, are covered by their particular industrial award. The awards set out in a very comprehensive form the various classifications for each industry with their particular rate of pay and their various conditions—superannuation funds, hours of work, overtime rates and matters of that like.

The important thing about awards, arbitrated and determined by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, is that they protect workers who are not in a strong bargaining position. How would we like it if individual workers had to front up to their employer and individually negotiate their wages and conditions and overtime rates? How would you have equal bargaining power with an individual, sitting down with an employer and asking for a job and having to argue about what they are going to be paid and their conditions of employment?

I submit to the Senate that without an Australian Industrial Relations Commission to determine these awards independently from the individual employee and the employer at the workplace, workers in this country, if required to individually negotiate with their employer, would be at an enormous disadvantage. I see a lot of young people in the gallery. It is nice to see them here. But imagine what would happen if they, as individual schoolchildren, had to negotiate with their school teachers about their attendance at school?

TALK.START.PARA: —Some of them negotiate very well with their teachers.

—They would be in a very difficult position. I do not want to underestimate the intelligence and the capacity of our young people here today, but imagine if they had to negotiate with their teachers. I do not think many of them would be in a particularly strong bargaining position.
—So you think we should treat workers like schoolchildren. Is that what you want to do?

—No, we do not treat workers like children; we treat them with respect. You want to take away the Industrial Relations Commission. You want to strip the protections away from workers. You expect individual workers to have to sit down with employers without any award protection except the basic minimum wage.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting that you are changing your policies as you go along. You are adding things on top of the minimum wage that you want to ensure is in this so-called safety net because you are worried that workers are actually interested in a policy that you are willing to disclose in part. Workers are quite interested in your policy. Workers are starting to say, `Why does the Liberal Party want to destroy our wages and conditions? Why does the Liberal Party want to take away our conditions—our weekend penalty rates, our overtime and night-shift rates? Why does the Liberal-National party want to take away the protections that ensure we get a fair go at the workplace?'

We all know this is what you want to do. You hate workers. You hate trade unions. You want to crush trade unions that represent workers. If you could get away with it, you would take away the independence of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission.(Time expired)
