SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen A.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—

SPEECH.PARA: (a)notes that the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Beazley), when launching the misleading advertisement on 22 October 1995 in which he said `The Court Liberal Government has set the minimum weekly wage at $317.10. A family can't live on that!', failed to mention that:

TAB.TAB: (i)when the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) was Premier for Western Australia, the minimum weekly wage from 24 September 1991 to 20 November 1992 was $268.80 and from then until she lost government was $275.50,
(ii)a series of federal awards which are under direct responsibility of the Keating Government are significantly below the Western Australian State minimum, and

(iii)such federal awards go as low for an adult per week as $238.10, being a classification nine for an unskilled worker in the federal Metal Trades Industry Award, which means that under the Federal Keating Labor Government, it is legal to pay $238.10 a week; and

PARA.TAB: (b)condemns the Deputy Prime Minister of Australia for this misleading presentation and calls on him to explain how under Labor a family can live on $238.10.

SPEECH.PARA: In speaking to this motion before the chamber today it is my intention to correct the lie that has been perpetrated on the Australian people in terms of the campaign being run in Western Australia and the sorts of outbursts we just heard across the chamber. I do not know how those opposite in all honesty can stand up and collectively shout across the chamber that we hate workers. It is absolutely unbelievable that they can do that.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Herron)—Senator Panizza, I ask you to withdraw that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I withdraw.

—The advertisement in Western Australia is a continuation of the beat-up that has seen the misleading and scaremongering tactics that were perpetrated at the last election on the Australian people. Mr Keating survived because of the perpetuation of that lie.

PARA.TAB: In my time today I want to demonstrate how in many instances employees do better under Liberal than they do under Labor, both under the state systems and under the federal system. I want to deal firstly with the situation which has existed in Western Australia for many years with regard to the minimum rates of pay under both Liberal and Labor governments.

As far back as I can remember—I have not gone back to the day dot—there has been a minimum rate of pay in Western Australia. During the period of the last Labor government in Western Australia, the minimum rate of pay fell gradually in real terms. From when Premier Brian Burke came to office it fell from $327.50 in real terms to $300.25 in real terms when Lawrence lost government. There were some variations, but I am not going to go through every detail. Seeing as the children were brought into this debate by the previous speaker, I make the point that it was under Sir Charles Court when he was Premier of Western Australia back in 1981 that equal pay was granted to men and women. It is very interesting that equal pay was granted to males and females in 1981.

Let us now look at the situation which has exised since the so-called Court wave of industrial relations. For the first time in five years there has been an increase in real terms in the minimum wage. It has increased in real terms by $17 to the current figure of $317.10. I think that shows fairly clearly the direction that minimum wages have taken.

The other point I must make—which is not consistent with the other states—is that this gives protection right across the board. It gives protection to those who are under awards if their awards have not been adjusted upwards. It gives protection to those who wish to go into an agreement. It also gives protection to those who have no award or agreement coverage. Western Australia is the only state that does that. It is worth looking at that particular aspect.

Last night we heard a contribution from Senator Chris Evans. I want to comment on a couple of aspects of his speech because he was wrong in so many areas. He said that employees had the protection of everything in awards under the federal system but they do not have it in Western Australia. Under the Western Australian legislation employees have the option of staying within the Western Australian award or going out. There is a duress clause included. When Senator Sherry was in the chamber I sought leave to have this duress clause incorporated. It is a very strict clause. People on the other side of the chamber should take note of it. I seek leave to have this one page document incorporated.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

PARA.EMPHASIS: Commissioner to be satisfied of certain matters

PARA.TAB: (1)Where an agreement is lodged with the Commissioner under section 29 the Commissioner is to satisfy himself or herself—

TAB.TAB: (a)that the agreement complies with this Act;
(b)that each party to the agreement appears to understand his or her rights and obligations under the agreement;
(c)that no party to the agreement was persuaded by threats or intimidation to enter into the agreement; and
(d)that each party to the agreement genuinely wishes to have the agreement registered.

PARA.TAB: (2)Subsection (1)(b) does not apply to an agreement under section 24(1).
(3)For the purposes of subsection (1), the Commissioner may—

TAB.TAB: (a)meet with the parties to the agreement; and
(b)otherwise obtain information in any way that he or she thinks appropriate.

PARA.TAB: (4)Any meeting may be held with the parties together or separately, or with any bargaining agents of the parties.
(1)Where in relation to an agreement the Commissioner is satisfied as to the matters referred to in section 30(1), the Commissioner must—

TAB.TAB: (a)register the agreement as a workplace agreement or as an agreement under section 23(1) or 24(1), as the case may be; and
(b)give to the parties notice in writing of the registration and the day on which it occurred, within 7 days after that day.

TALK.START.PARA: —At this point I think it is worth noting that under the Queensland Goss Labor government there is no duress clause in legislation.

PARA.TAB: I wish to move to that part of the motion which deals with a series of federal awards which are under the direct responsibility of the Keating government. These awards are significantly below the Western Australian minimum. From the research we have done in the last few days we have discovered that the 1993 commercial industrial artists federal award has two classifications out of 10 that are under the Western Australian state minimum. We discovered that five out of five junior rates are under the Western Australian junior rates minimum.

In the licensed clubs managers and secretaries federal award we find that two out of seven classifications are under the Western Australian minimum. In the assistant managerial staff award we find that six out of seven are under the Western Australian minimum. And so we go on. We come to the squash court industry interim award, the theatrical employees federal award and the tenpin bowling industry award. I sought leave from Senator Sherry to table these particular awards so that people can see them.

Of the classifications in those awards we find that 50 out of 84 have adult rates below the Western Australian minimum. I find that absolutely remarkable when we hear the nonsense that is being pedalled on the other side of the chamber and which has been put out in Western Australia. These awards are significantly below those of Western Australia. If these people were under state awards the rate of pay would have to be increased to the minimum established under the Western Australian legislation. This points out very clearly that in many areas the rates of pay to individuals under federal awards are significantly lower than those in Western Australia.

I want to quote a few awards to put them on the public record, but I will seek leave in a moment to table these various awards. Let us take the squash court industry interim federal award. For the first classification, the federal award is $260.60 per week, versus the WA minimum of $317.10. If we go a little bit further down the table, we find $266.50 versus $317.10. One would wonder why this federal government does not like theatrical employees. Listed under theatrical employees we find Bibra Lakes Adventure World, which is worth visiting. It is a very nice place; I would commend it to anyone in this chamber. For Adventure World, which is under the federal award, we find 11 out of 11 sit in a classification on $288.15, versus the minimum rate of $317.10. One can go on working these things through.

What this does is expose the lie that has been perpetrated on the Australian people in that Labor supposedly creates a situation where people get better wages under them than they do under the Liberal Party. I now seek leave to table those awards that I have made reference to, which I cleared with Senator Sherry earlier in the day.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you. In the time I have left, I now wish to deal with the third part of my motion, which refers to the metal trades industry award and clause 9—the $246.10. I know what the other side of the chamber are going to say. I know what Laurie Brereton said yesterday.
—You don't know what he said today.

—What? Did he correct himself? Because what he said yesterday was not correct. That clause 9 is there and, for those people who do not come under any of the classifications from 1 to 14, that is the minimum rate of pay. Mr Brereton also said yesterday that the unions and employer organistions were going to take out that particular clause and that it had been dead for 25 years.

PARA.TAB: I put the proposition: if it has been dead for 25 years, why has it been adjusted twice in recent times? It was adjusted in December 1993 and September 1994. It is a living, breathing, working clause in that award. It has been adjusted upwards by the arbitration commission. The question we have to put as far as the statement that it is going to be removed is concerned is: what are they going to put in its place? That is what we want to know. I hope that when the speakers on the other side of this chamber get their chance to speak on this, they will tell us what they are going to put in its place.

The next point I want to come to in the time I have left is the WA situation. Under the WA system there is a choice—the award or go into an agreement. There is a duress clause, which I made reference to before.

TALK.START.PARA: —Choice?

—There is a choice of where you go. Under that duress clause, which is administered through the state arbitration commission, the individuals—the employee and the employer—can be heard separately or jointly by choice.

PARA.TAB: The last point I make deals with Queensland. It is very interesting when we look at what was said about Queensland the other day by Mr Brereton. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The award rates paid to employees include a margin on top of Mr Reith's $250. I am advised by the DIR that not only are there no full-time adult award employees in Queensland being paid $250 per week but also it is impossible to do so.

Mr Brereton was right, by six days. The rate was moved to above $250 on 20 October 1995. It was gazetted on that date. It was a $6.40 increase and it took the award rate to $250.30. This is under the state station hands award.When I said that in Queensland they were $67 worse off than in Western Australia, I was wrong. They were $66.70 worse off under this minimum award rate.

PARA.TAB: There are many federal awards that are under the Western Australian award. There is a duress clause and there are minimum conditions in Western Australia. I emphasise that. Minimum conditions do not exist in Queensland. Under the Goss government there is no protection for those people who are award free. In Western Australia there is. It is the Goss government that has failed to look after employees in Queensland.

TALK.START.PARA: —You opposed that.
—Through you, Mr Acting Deputy President, I did not oppose that. That is absolutely and totally wrong. That exposes the Labor lie about industrial relations. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw Sen M.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Either Senator Crane does not understand the way in which the federal award system operates in this country or, as I suspect, he does understand but he is deliberately distorting the facts about federal awards. I know Senator Crane has had some experience in this area because of his previous involvement in the Farmers Federation of Western Australia. Senator Crane knows that I have had experience in this area for some years.

PARA.TAB: I would remind Senator Crane of some of the facts rather than the distortions we are getting on award rates of pay under the federal system. It was pointed out in the debate last night, as Senator Crane recognises, by Senator Chris Evans and Senator Murphy—and I know Senator Jacinta Collins will be taking up this issue—the figures you are using have no relevance.

To come in here and suggest that the $246.10 rate per clause 9 of the metal industry award is a real rate of pay that exists in the metal industry is wrong. It demonstrates that you have forgotten anything you knew or are deliberately forgetting anything you knew about the process of minimum rates adjustment under the Accord or through the federal Industrial Relations Commission and the process of establishing supplementary payments. I am sure you remember these things. You were involved in some of those proceedings. I will come back to that in a little while. That was when you were in the pastoral industry.

The minimum rate under the metal industry award is $341.40. That is the base rate, plus the supplementary payment, plus the safety net adjustment. That rate is an entry level rate. It has application to very few people. When people with little or no qualifications or experience come into the industry, they start on that rate. They pretty quickly move up through the classification structure to the higher rates, generally after three to six months.

If you understand anything about the way the federal award system operates, about how supplementary payments were introduced into federal awards and how awards were reconstructed by broadbanding classifications to base them on skill rather than on strict demarcation lines, you will understand that even that rate of $341.40 is a very bare minimum. In fact, people in the industry were getting paid well in excess of that.

When the supplementary payments were introduced into federal awards some years ago, what actually happened was that this produced some of the biggest wage increases for workers on minimum rates in this country that we have ever seen. People in the textile, clothing and footwear industry, people in the hospitality and hotels industry under federal awards, people in the rural industry, people in small manufacturing industries all received huge increases because of the introduction of supplementary payments.

The process was actually called the minimum rates adjustment process. It was endorsed by the federal commission whereby there would be adjustments to federal awards—particularly those for low income workers, people on low minimum rates of pay—to bring their award rates of pay up to more reasonable levels. It was particularly targeted at those people working in industries with little industrial clout that did not have the industrial strength or capacity that people in other industries may have had to go out and bargain for over-award payments. That is what this debate is very much about: it is about providing through an award system protection for people who are at the lower end of the income scale in terms of award coverage.

Nevertheless, the point is that the figures quoted and used by Senator Crane and others on the opposition side are completely and utterly false. It is a deliberate distortion to use that rate, and Senator Jacinta Collins will take that issue up in her contribution. What also has to be remembered in this process is that award rates of pay are not set by trade unions and are not set by federal or state Labor governments; award rates of pay are set by the Industrial Relations Commission.

The people who have done most to oppose any increases for low income workers over the years are those people sitting on the opposite side of the chamber; those opposite whose colleagues out there in the employer organisations have, on every single occasion bar the last couple, opposed national wage increases. When the commission awarded an $8, $10 or $12 wage increase or a two per cent wage increase, it did so after hearing opposition to those increases from the employer ranks and from the coalition parties. You are the people who have constantly argued throughout the 1980s and the 1990s that low income workers should not get any national wage increases at all; yet you have the hide to come in here and say, `Look at these rates, they're too low.'

I have to acknowledge one thing: I would like to see the minimum rates in federal awards higher than what they are. They are certainly a lot higher than the figures you quote, Senator Crane. I would like to see them higher because I think that these workers deserve more. But, ultimately, that is dependent upon decisions of the Industrial Relations Commission.

Senator Crane, I remind you—with your former role in the Western Australian Farmers Federation and, through that, your involvement in the National Farmers Federation—who was it that was opposing national wage increases flowing on to pastoral workers in this country? It was the National Farmers Federation and its constituent state bodies. You know that because you were there, and I was there. I was there in the Industrial Relations Commission on at least four occasions arguing against incapacity to pay cases.

TALK.START.PARA: —Doing deals; that is what you were doing.

—We could never do a deal with your lot. We had to argue day in and day out. Some of those cases went for months and months. You know that. What were we after? We were after a small amount, about a $10 or $12 wage increase; we were after superannuation—and you opposed it. Who was up there in the commission running these cases on behalf of the employers? It was none other than Mr Peter Costello. You had the highly paid barrister representing the New Right in there, arguing on behalf of the NFF that the commission should not give lowly paid rural workers, shearers and station hands a lousy or $8 or $10 because they are not worth it. That is what was being argued.

PARA.TAB: Now you have the hide to come in here and lecture us about minimum rates of pay. What effrontery! What hypocrisy! When you look at federal awards, you do not just look at the award rates of pay. You have to look at all the other conditions that are in there, such as the annual leave, the annual leave loading, the sick leave, the penalty rates, the overtime and the superannuation—that great achievement promoted by this government and endorsed by the Industrial Relations Commission against the opposition of the coalition parties and some major employer organisations. You have to look at the prescribed hours of work. You have to look at the maternity and paternity leave provisions, the training provisions and all the other provisions that exist.

They are all the other elements of federal awards that increase the package for the worker, but they are the elements that the opposition wants to get rid of. They are the elements that the Court government, under its new wave industrial legislation, has virtually abolished. You come in here and say that you have set this minimum rate of $317 a week in Western Australia and how wonderful that is. For a start, it is 30 per cent lower than the figure that was recommended to the minister by an independent expert. Not only is it 30 per cent lower, but the minister has the discretion to set that figure. They are not allowed to go off to the commission and argue these cases. The minister sets the figure.

You talk to us about options and this wonderful approach that the Liberal and National parties have to industrial relations—`Let us give people the option.' You know that giving people the option is to give a very heavy bias in favour of the employer. If employees are lining up for a job, they do not get into a debate with the employer about how much they might be able to be paid. They are told, `That is the rate.' They will be told in Western Australia, `Take the job at $317. Forget all the other benefits like annual leave.'

TALK.START.PARA: —They are told.

—That is right—they are told that. If they so much as complain, they will be ignored; they will not get the job. That is what happens. You say that you give people the option. What a joke! You are dressing it up. You are actually denying people the opportunity to go to an independent umpire.

PARA.TAB: We then also have to look at other matters in relation to the income levels for Australian families, to go to the specific terms of this motion regarding how people can survive on award rates of pay. It is difficult for people to survive on low minimum award rates of pay. I will grant that. As I said, those award rates of pay are set by the commission after hearing argument from the employers and the unions. It is the employers in there who are arguing to keep those rates low.

If anybody is responsible for low minimum rates of pay in this country, it is you lot. You are the ones who oppose them all the time. That is why the government has moved to boost the social wage. That is why we have established the family payment supplement. The family payment supplement, paid to low income earners, can provide up to an additional $94 per fortnight to a family with two children. That represents about $130 in wages—$94 in real terms. That goes onto the minimum award rates of pay.

Then there are the other benefits like the parenting allowance, which is now paid directly to the mothers. There is the child-care subsidy, and there is the Austudy payment that families are assisted by. There is the maternity allowance, recently introduced by the government in the latest budget, which is about $816 upon the birth of a child. And, of course, there is Medicare: one of the greatest social reforms of this country that helps the battlers and provides them with a decent standard of health care—something that you people in the past have been committed to destroying.

So you add all of those things in. You have to add those things in. That is why people under our government are able to survive: firstly, because they have protection under the award system with a no disadvantage test—a guaranteed minimum, not some option—and, secondly, because they have a social wage structure which tops that up.

In my remaining couple of minutes I would like to also quote from the West Australian, because Senator Crane referred to an advertisement in it. Firstly, on page 4 of today's West Australian there is an article by Wendy Pryer, `Farmers query Bill, fear backlash'. You should listen to this carefully, Senator Crane. The article states:

SPEECH.PARA: The WA Farmers' Federation said yesterday the Court Government's new industrial legislation would not help farmers and they would be hurt by the industrial trouble it triggered.

The farmers, for once, know what is happening and they know what is right. You had better get back to Hendy Cowan and get him to tell Minister Kierath and Richard Court to scrap this legislation because it is no good, and even your own supporters do not want it. I will tell you what we get on page 3 of the West Australian. There is an article by Natalie Gibson, `Mean boss fined over workers' pay'. It states:
Perth contract cleaner Salvatore Massara has been heavily fined for the second time in just over a month after pleading guilty to underpaying his employees.

PARA.TAB: Massara, of Mackie Street, Victoria Park, was fined $39,500 in the Industrial Magistrate's Court yesterday for 65 breaches of the award. He was also ordered to pay more than $3200 in outstanding wages to employees he had underpaid.
Massara is yet to pay $14,600 in fines—

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order. I say to whoever asked whether he is a mate of mine that I have never heard of him. But I do not think it is very relevant to be quoting that sort of material, as far as who is fined and who is not fined. I believe that has been made public in the West Australian and there is no point bringing it up here. He is being irrelevant.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—There is no point of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a deliberate attempt to waste my time. The point is that where you have these low little rates of pay you will have people endeavouring to reduce that figure even further. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have heard very little from Senator Forshaw on behalf of the government that put any sustainable arguments against the motion Senator Crane has moved in relation to industrial relations matters, wages in Western Australia and the Western Australian Industrial Relations legislation. We heard a few comments about ancient history. He claimed that Senator Crane, as a representative of the National Farmers Federation, was involved in industrial cases and that the National Farmers Federation opposed what Senator Forshaw described as lowly paid rural workers getting a few dollars increase.

PARA.TAB: But what he forgot to tell us was the situation of the lowly paid farmers at that time. In many instances, they were loss making farmers who clearly could not afford to pay any more in wages at that time and who, because of the abuse of union power by the likes of Senator Forshaw and his mates, in the end were forced to increase wages despite the fact that they could not afford to pay them. This is what we see from the Labor Party side. They do not recognise the impact that increased wages, unless they are matched by increased productivity, have on the costs of production and on the capacity not only of farmers, but of all our industry to compete in the international marketplace.

What we see on the part of the government is a totally unjustified scare campaign against the Liberal and National parties with regard to industrial relations. The advertisement that the Labor Party put in the Western Australian newspapers recently is yet another example of Labor's lies in the run-up to the next federal election. Western Australian Labor politicians seem to struggle with the concept of truth, whether in relation to advertising or best recollections. Certainly, Minister Lawrence seems to be an expert on that subject.

It is important to point out a few facts in this regard. Labor is not only lying about the Western Australian situation; more importantly, it is propagating lies about the federal situation, in particular about what a Liberal and National Party government would do after the next election. The fact is that the detail of the coalition's industrial relations policy has not been released.

TALK.START.PARA: —Well show it to us.
—It will be released—
—What have you got to hide?

—You show us the election and we will show you our industrial relations policy. That is when we will release it. We will release it when our running scared Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has the courage and confidence to call an election or when he simply runs out of time and is forced to call the election. That is the appropriate time for us to release this policy and indeed all of our other policies.
—Call the election this week.

—Let us bring it on. Let us have the election. Let us see whether he has the courage to announce it this weekend. The fact is that when our industrial relations policy is released everyone will see for themselves that it certainly does not contain any of the draconian provisions which Labor is so desperately trying to convince the Australian public it does contain.

PARA.TAB: What this Labor government is attempting to do actually says very little at all about the industrial relations policies of the Liberal and National parties. But it does say a great deal about this Labor government. It says that after 13 years of failure in government, the Labor Party is absolutely desperate. It is desperate to find a way of staying in office after lying its way through the last election. It is desperate to peg back the strong lead that is evident for the coalition in public opinion polls.

So what we see is the government's lies getting bigger and bigger as they attempt to build another massive scare campaign. That is what their attack on the Western Australian industrial relations law is about. That is what their misrepresentation of the federal coalition's industrial relations policy is about.

To give you another recent example, we have had the Prime Minister and various of his acolytes parroting that the coalition will introduce a state income tax. Senator Schacht tried this by way of interjection during my states grants speech last week. He well knows that neither I nor any of my colleagues advocate a state income tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —How do we know?

—We have made it very clear. Why don't you button up, Senator Sherry. What we do advocate in this regard is that there be a fixed share of federal income tax to be distributed to the states according to their relative needs on an untied basis.
—How?

—In the way that it was previously undertaken—with a fixed share being guaranteed to the states and then distributed on a needs basis by the Commonwealth Grants Commission. That is very simple. It has been done before. It has been done quite effectively to the benefit of state governments.

PARA.TAB: That is in marked contrast to this federal Labor government's approach which has been to strangle the states by reducing funding to them and by providing a higher proportion of the pittance that they are giving to states in the form of tied grants rather than untied grants which the states can spend according to their own priorities. We find the states are required to spend according to this government's priorities and not according to their own. We will certainly be waiting with much interest to see what the next Labor lie is in the lead-up the next federal election.

Labor's current story on industrial relations is certainly a huge lie as Senator Crane has pointed out in this motion. The statutory minimum wage of $317.10 in Western Australia is $67 higher than the minimum $250 for an adult apprentice under the metal trades industry award in Queensland, which is set by the Queensland Industrial Relations Commission under the Goss Labor government.

In South Australia, the equivalent adult minimum wage paid to an adult apprentice who has not worked in the industry prior to apprenticeship and which would apply to a first or perhaps second year adult apprentices is $238.10 under a federal award. This notice of motion seeks condemnation on the government for its untrue scare campaign in relation to these matters, particularly in relation to Western Australia, and asks the government to explain how a family in Queensland earning the minimum wage can survive on $67 per week less than the minimum in Western Australia.

One could also ask the government to explain how a family in South Australia earning the minimum federal award wage can survive on $79 less than that which is the minimum in Western Australia and even $12 less than the Queensland minimum wage. This is under a federal award. It was admitted on ABC radio yesterday that some two per cent of the Queensland working population are actually earning that $250 a week minimum. How many people that actually represents, I do not know. This government takes the cake when it comes to the big ask for requiring Australian families to live on inadequate incomes.

We have more than half a million children in Australia aged up to 14 years in families with incomes below the poverty line. Some 760,000 unemployed Australians do not earn any minimum wage. We have the Prime Minister telling university students to `get a job', knowing full well that opportunities for workplace based traineeships and apprenticeships under this Labor government are non-existent. Yet, if they are lucky enough to get a job, under the federal award scheme, they will find they are paid much less than under state jurisdiction.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true.

—It is true. The other thing that is important is that under the Western Australian government's legislation wages growth in WA has been stronger than in any other Australian state. Premier Court and the unions are sitting down to talk this week, as I understand it. It is rumoured that unions have accepted secret ballots. To cap it off, I understand that the Prime Minister has been asked to butt out of these matters.
—That is true also.

—I am glad to hear that it is true because that is what I understand to be the case. One could be forgiven for being sympathetic and even supportive of the wisdom of that instruction. It ill behoves the Prime Minister and his other ministers, including the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton), to criticise our approach to industrial relations. Their approach in the whole time they have been in office has been quite inadequate.

PARA.TAB: The most recent criticism has come from the South Australian employee ombudsman, Mr Gary Collis, a person with a strong trade union leadership background, in his first annual report, which was tabled in the state parliament last week, and which I referred to in question time last week. Let us just hear a few of the things that he said about the situation. He said delays to `achieving an enterprise agreement' in South Australia had occurred because of:

SPEECH.PARA: the decision of some unions to seek federal award coverage for the workplaces in which they have members . . . In at least some cases there are no signs of membership approval being sought for such steps and where agreements under the Federal jurisdiction have been obtained it is often hard to see how the members are better off than they would have been had the agreement been achieved under the state system.
So much for this federal award system. Time and time again it has been shown that workers are better off under the state Liberal jurisdiction. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —This motion accuses the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Beazley) of failing to mention certain details, scapegoats the previous Premier of the Western Australian government and current Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) and also accuses the Deputy Prime Minister of being misleading—typical style for the opposition, I should say. Despite all of these facts, I actually thank Senator Crane for the opportunity to focus on two key issues.
—You're welcome.

—Thank you. The first of those is the importance of the award system. The second is the relevance of a real disadvantage test. But first I should explain how this motion is in itself extremely misleading.

PARA.TAB: Within the context of the award system, the minimum rate of $246.10 is a historical anomaly. It actually does not apply. Senator Crane should know this. It was explained by the minister in question time in the other place yesterday, but it appears that all the opposition has been able to do is update the actual rate included in the award. Either those opposite cannot understand a simple explanation or they are being deliberately misleading—I place emphasis on the latter after hearing Senator Crane's previous comments.

Let me explain it again. Clause 9 of the metal trade industry award can apply only if the award rate in clause 8 is less than the minimum wage in clause 9. Every award wage in clause 8 is greater than the minimum wage in clause 9. Therefore, by simple deduction, clause 9 has no effect. Should I do that again?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I think you'd better.

—I am glad you agreed with me that Senator Crane did actually understand that clause 9 can apply only if the award wage in clause 8 is less than the minimum wage in clause 9. He harked to a different point in his earlier comments. He tried to suggest that there were some employees who would not be covered by classifications in clause 8. That too is misleading.

PARA.TAB: The structural efficiency exercise carried out in the metal trade industry award addressed a particular classification relevant to employees not elsewhere classified. Do you know where those employees went? They went to C14 in clause 8. I think I can quite clearly emphasise that Senator Crane is being deliberately misleading.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am absolutely correct.
—He has no choice at all. Yet under the new arrangements in Western Australia more employees will be subject to a system where they have no award protection.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting when we look at other areas. In some other areas the coalition does seem to understand the notion of choice and imbalance of power. I heard it yesterday in the debate on the Family Law Act. Some seem to understand that there is an imbalance of power in certain situations in relation to family issues mediation. Why can't you accept that in relation to industrial relations? The answer to that is that you do not want to. It is quite clear that you do not want to.

TALK.START.PARA: —We do; we accept that entirely.
—I had my office telephone the shadow minister's office. We were told what it included.
—You got it.

—Yes, we got it. It was very unfortunate, though, for your arguments. All it said was that three issues are being considered. We know that they are being considered. We have been told that they are being considered. We just have not been told what their policy is.

PARA.TAB: Let us look at what three issues are being considered. What is being considered is equal pay for equal work. But Senator Crane just told me that the earlier Court government introduced that in Western Australia. I would have taken for granted from your comments that you would have accepted that condition a long time ago. But, no, we are being told that it is only now that you are considering equal pay. Come to the real world!

You are also considering that the 12 months unpaid maternity leave provision be extended to cover paternity and adoption leave. You are three years behind the game. The other issue you are looking at is paid family leave. I would like to see that actually in your policy. I would like to see it in print, not just being considered.

But that is all we are being told is being considered. All we can really do to try to understand what sort of policy would come into place, and all we can recommend that workers do, is look at your record. The record is what is occurring in the states such as Western Australia, where people are being engaged as casuals only at an hourly rate of $9.10. They have an entitlement to bereavement leave and nothing else. There are no penalty rates, overtime provisions, holiday loadings or annual leave or sick leave entitlements. There is just a casual hourly rate of $9.10. Tell me this: how will the disadvantage test protect those people? It will not, because it is not based on a real base.

The government has a base for its disadvantage test, and it is the award system. The coalition's base is empty. It is nothing. It will be something like the hourly rate suggested by the Kennett government in Victoria of $8.60. That is how you will assess disadvantage. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have an amazing line-up opposite. The apologists for the union movement are working themselves into a lather. It would be funny that the people on the other side are working themselves into a lather were it not for the fact that they are working themselves into a lather to scare the living daylights out of the people that they claim to represent.

PARA.TAB: On the other side of the chamber, we have former union officials. Mind you, old habits die hard. They have always claimed to represent the workers and be concerned about the disadvantaged, yet, when you give them an opportunity to get into power, what do they do?

TALK.START.PARA: —Cut wages!

—They cut wages. They cut the rights of workers who do not want to belong to a union. They cut opportunities for people to get a job. The shameful thing is that the people on the other side laud the Luddites like Jennie George, for heaven's sake, proclaiming them to be great heroes of the workers.

PARA.TAB: I saw a hideous piece of television in which the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) addressed the ACTU and said that he was very pleased because Jennie George had given him a kiss on the cheek. He said that the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) would not be getting a kiss on the cheek from Jennie George. Mr Howard would probably be quite pleased about that. It is probably the only thing Mr Keating said that would amuse the Leader of the Opposition. Not many workers would want a kiss on the cheek from Jennie George, and I will tell you why. The soon-to-be-leader of the ACTU, Jennie George, is the same Jennie George who, instead of protecting the rights of workers—

TALK.START.PARA: —See how far behind you are. She already is.

—We just heard an interjection from Senator Murphy. It is obvious that a thought has just come into Senator Murphy's head. It is well known that, when a thought crosses Senator Murphy's mind, it is the shortest trip in Canberra.

PARA.TAB: Government senators interjecting—
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—Order! Those on my right will cease interjecting.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let them squeal, Mr Acting Deputy President. The truth hurts, and it hurts the people on the other side of the chamber. Jennie George was lauded by the Prime Minister as a hero of the workers. But what did Jennie George do to a factory on the Gold Coast that employed 42 people who said they did not want to belong to a union and they did not want to cop the union award system? Forty-two workers on the Gold Coast lost their jobs because, as was stated on television, Jennie George's position was that, according to her judgment, it was better for those 42 workers, who wanted to exercise their democratic right to not belong to a union, enter into their own voluntary employment agreement and not have the union interfere in the negotiation process, to lose their jobs to protect the integrity of the award system.

PARA.TAB: This is the excuse we get every time the union duds the workers: forget the rights of the individuals; let us talk about protecting the integrity of the award system. It sounds wonderful. That is like protecting the integrity of a sewage system. It really is nonsense—palpable nonsense. The people on the other side seem to think that Jennie George is a hero because she can put people out of work to protect the privileged position of union officials.

In reality, the only concern of those opposite is protecting the interests of their own ilk, protecting the interests of the union movement. But the sad thing for them is that the vast majority of Australians do not belong to unions. Even more of them do not want to belong to unions. Remember, many people are forced to belong to a union because this government has said that we have to have preference for unionist clauses in the federal Industrial Relations Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —You listen, Shayne!

—Indeed, Senator Murphy ought to listen. The more and more we tell Senator Murphy, the less and less it penetrates, because the truth hurts. It should hurt the government to know that some of the things that the Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Brereton, has said are quite distressing. For example, Mr Brereton said:

SPEECH.PARA: The award rate paid to employees includes a margin on top of Mr Reith's $250. I am advised by the DIR that not only are there no full time adult award employees in Queensland being paid $250 per week but also it is impossible to do so . . .

He made this statement on 25 October 1995. At that point he was correct. He was correct by five days and 30c, because on 20 October, a bare five days beforehand, the Queensland government Gazette stated that, under the station hands award, a female domestic of 19 years or older had her minimum wage increased by $6.40 to $250.30. Previously, it had been $243.90. In other words, a bare 30c in six days is the margin for truth in Mr Brereton's statement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you included the cost of meals and accommodation? You tell the truth.

—We have seen members from the government side work themselves into a lather and work themselves into a frenzy, as Senator Forshaw is doing now. Senator Forshaw, control your hormones and listen to a little bit of fact. I know you have difficulty with letting fact get in the way of your prejudice, but hopefully this will be a learning experience for you. I know that has not happened to you for a long time, but here we go—
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. For a person who delights in travelling down hills in a cart with no brakes at a hundred miles an hour—
—What is your point of order?
—Could you ask him to stop the personal abuse?
—There is no point of order.

—I didn't think there was. Thank you very much, Mr Acting Deputy President. But people on the other side who wish to throw interjections across the chamber ought to expect to get something in return. What they are going to get in return, and they do not like it, is a little bit of truth. Just a modicum of truth, Senator Forshaw, because I know you could not handle more than one bit of truth a day.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, there are two points of order: firstly, could you ask Senator O'Chee to address the chair rather than opposition senators; and, secondly, could we have details of the opposition policy in this debate?

—In relation to the second point, that is not a point of order and you know it is not a point of order. In relation to the first point of order, if there were fewer interjections from my right, I am sure that Senator O'Chee would be addressing his remarks through the chair.

—I certainly would, Mr Acting Deputy President. Now it is time for the truth, and this is the truth: the government has attacked Mr Court and the coalition government in WA, saying that they were dreadful people, that they were attacking the rights of workers and that they would reduce the living standards of workers. Of course, this is palpable nonsense.

PARA.TAB: The minimum wage set by Mr Kierath at $317.10 is more, for example, than the minimum wage under the commercial and industrial artists federal award of 1993. It is more than the $304 or the $271 that applied under the award. For example, looking at people who are theatrical employees at the Bibra Lakes Adventure World who are under a federal award, under each of the 11 different categories the minimum wage is $288.15, which is less than the $317.10.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the supplementary payment?

—The supplementary point—Senator Forshaw, you are so ignorant that you cannot understand simple mathematics—is this: the government want to scare people but the government do not want the facts brought out. I tell you what, if I was spreading the nonsense, the prejudice, the bigotry and the fear that the government is spreading, I would not want the facts brought out either. They are a lamentable disgrace for a government. They are a poor excuse for people who purport to represent the rights of workers.

PARA.TAB: I tell you what, the workers of this country are awake to them, Mr Acting Deputy President. That is why the workers of this country are revolting against the rule of the Keating government. That is why their blue collar vote is disappearing and that is why unionisation rates are continuing to drop. Heaven help them! Would anybody belong to a union with the sort of rabble we have over on the other side running a union? I would say no. And that is why hundreds of thousands of other Australians have said no as well. So we say: an end to fear and time for the truth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murphy Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —A little game is being played by the opposition with regard to our record on workers' wages and conditions. I know they get a bit touchy about us referring to their record but, really, that is the only thing we have to compare. As has been said on many occasions, we have nothing else to compare because they have not got anything else for us to consider.

PARA.TAB: They have not told the people of Australia what hourly rates of pay and what conditions they will be entitled to under their industrial relations system if they ever win government. Of course, a very important part of actually winning government is telling people what you are going to give them. It is no good coming in here and saying things are crook under the government and that wages have been reduced and so on. You have to tell the people. If you say you are going to give them something better, tell them what it is.

On wages and conditions, I think I said in here yesterday in reply to some silly question or some motion put up by you lot over there that you people have opposed every wage increase since we have been in office, bar one. It is the height of hypocrisy to try to purport that the wages and conditions of workers have gone backwards under this government. Look at superannuation alone: what was it under you people? Less than 30 per cent were entitled to superannuation. Now more than 90 per cent get it.

What was your position with regard to superannuation guarantee? What were you going to do about that? You said, `We're going to cap it; that's what we're going to do.' In fact, you wanted to say, `We're going to cap it. We're also going to knock it right off.' In terms of pay cuts, it is worth while noting what Mr Howard said on 20 October 1992 in response to a question from John Laws. John Laws says:

SPEECH.PARA: It gets back to something I have been saying for 15 years and I have always used it as a benchmark in my own negotiations: 80 per cent of something is a whole lot better than 100 per cent of nothing.
Mr Howard says:
Absolutely.
What message does that send to the workers of this country? In another interview, the compere asks:
And what if the boss says to me, "I'd like you to work 50 hours a week now, at the minimum award hourly rate and if you don't like it there's lots who'll do it. See you later."?
Mr Howard says:
That becomes a matter of negotiation and you have to make up your mind whether in those circumstances you can get a better deal elsewhere.
God help them if they go to get a better deal elsewhere. He continues:
If you're a good worker you can get a better deal elsewhere.
What sort of an approach is that? Then there is the IR bill—now you see it, now you don't; and we have yet to see it. Mr Howard says:
We will be producing a Bill well before the next election—
this is back in 1992, mind you—
and that is about as far as you can go as far as spelling out the details.

In terms of superannuation, your position really has not changed from Jobsback—or `Jobssack'; it probably should have been called `Jobssack', because that is what it is really all about. On 18 April 1994 Mr Howard said:
Jobsback is not gone. Jobsback remains the policy of the Coalition. There's absolutely no suggestion that Jobsback is gone. Jobsback was not part of Fightback.
On 30 May, he said:
Oh, my IR policy will be reviewed. I don't think the main threads of it should be changed at all.
The next day he has some doubts. He says:
Indeed, well, with a few changes. But essentially what I brought forward at the last election with a few changes.

That is the position. We have seen nothing from the opposition. They would not tell us anything different, nor indeed tell the Australian people anything different. So what have they chosen? They have chosen this sort of smokescreen approach and to say, `Under you people, Australian workers' wages have actually gone backwards.' The reality is that they have increased by seven per cent. Household disposable income has increased by 40 per cent.

PARA.TAB: You said, `Our position has changed.' I thought, `I'll give you people a bit of a go here.' So I looked to Mr Reith and to what he has said on a few occasions. I will quote him on how he sees employment contracts. Laurie Oakes asks:

SPEECH.PARA: Did you decide the big bang reform in industrial relations was the way to go?
Mr Reith says:
It certainly reinforced my view. The labour contracts will really open up the economy, help lower costs of production.

I know Senator O'Chee seems to have all of the knowledge—he is the repository of all wisdom—but I do not know how you lower the cost of production without actually cutting wages. Productivity under this government has improved out of sight. For 26 years this country had a coalition government, and productivity went backwards. If you really are going to lift productivity in this country, you better tell people how you are going to do it and, at the same time, meet the claim of huge wage increases that you are making to them. I am quite sure a lot of employers would be very interested to see how these people are going to do that as well. In terms of unfair dismissal, Mr Reith says:
Well, we'd abolish the court. We would also reinstate effective secondary boycott provisions.

That is the hypocrisy in the opposition's argument with regard to industrial relations. You say that you are the workers' friend. When this government sought to remove draconian legislation and gave the workers back the right to negotiate on a fair and equitable basis, why did you oppose it? That is what is important. You have to tell the Australian public, you have to tell the Australian workers, where you really stand. We have Mr Reith on awards. The interviewer says:
Will there be scope for wage rises under the award system as you seek it?
He says:
Yes, but that obviously is going to change over time as the nature of awards change.

I know what that means, and I think the workers know what that means. That means that if you go into an enterprise agreement and the award is no longer in effect, you people will abolish the awards, as you did in Victoria.

PARA.TAB: Let us look at Victoria in terms of wages and conditions and what Mr Kennett did. The Victorian government recently applied to the Victorian Industrial Commission for an hourly wage rate of less than $8.60. That brings up about $312 per week—between $16,500 and $17,000 per year. That is a joke. What have you consistently told the people? You have said there will be four fundamental aspects to your wages and conditions policy: there will be a single minimum hourly wage, four weeks annual leave, 12 months unpaid parental leave, and 10 days non-cumulative sick leave. What happens to penalty rates? What happens to all of those things that workers have to have to survive? You people say that their wages and conditions are so low that we have not moved their wages and conditions forward enough, yet you are purporting to take all of those things off them.

I want to look at another little matter with regard to where you people really come from, and that is employing people to break strikes. I refer to a person who is being used to break strikes, a Mr Bruce Townsend, who is currently in Queensland. He is being paid by employers, supported by you lot, to break strikes and to crush workers, tapping their phones and doing all sorts of other things to them. They even had to shift an Industrial Relations Commission hearing in Queensland because the place was bugged. Bugged by whom?—by Mr Townsend and a few others who are being paid cash in hand, avoiding tax and doing all the sorts of things that you people support. That is hypocrisy. You ought to be ashamed of the fact that you come into this chamber and purport to say that we do not represent workers sufficiently and that you are the workers' friend. It is the height of hypocrisy and you ought to be condemned for it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I have heard a lot of garbage I have heard it in the last 10 minutes of Senator Murphy's speech. This crowd here are like snakes in a corner and they are looking for any angle to get out of it. I am afraid with the lies they have been telling they are not able to do so. Mr Beazley last week launched a lot of advertisements in Western Australia to try to beat up the industrial relations situation towards the next election. It is said that they just happened to appear at that time. They appeared when the ALP in the polls were down the bottom and on the floor. All the government can do is tell mistruth on top of mistruth to try to beat up the industrial relations of Western Australia because they have nothing whatsoever to run on. A scare campaign is the only way they can do it.

PARA.TAB: I will go on to what Senator Chris Evans had to say last night in his adjournment speech. I will quote what he said. He was talking about Western Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: Under workplace agreements ordinary hours are increased to 40 hours per week to be worked at any time Monday to Friday inclusive. Normally the award is 38 hours plus overtime.
He went on to say that under the new system—in other words rather than being under the award—a person's pay would be cut from $430.60 to $391—a difference of some $41.

PARA.TAB: The after tax pay—the take home pay—brings it down to $36. So he says that by working 10 hours from Monday to Thursday without overtime and having a day off in lieu they are $36 worse off. That fool last night did not tell us—
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Reynolds)—Order! Senator Panizza, it is not appropriate to call a member of this place a fool. Could you withdraw it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I withdraw it. That misinformed senator last night did not realise that that worker has got one day up his or her sleeve and could earn another $100 for that day under that same award. Senator Murphy is laughing at that.
—I am laughing at you, you fool.
—He is misinformed too. He is in the same situation.
—Order! I alert Senator Murphy to the fact that that language is also inappropriate.
—I withdraw.

—I did not hear it, but it does not worry me too much. The point is that Senator Evans did not tell us that that worker can earn another $100 doing the same job for another child minding centre or whatever it was. He did not tell us that. These are the sorts of mistruths that we are getting from this government. He also went on to say that the only option that you have when you work overtime is to get time off in lieu, as if this were something new. Senator Crane, how long has that been in the pastoral award? It has been in the pastoral award for 15 years that I know of.
—Forty that I know of.

—For 15 years or whatever it is it has been in that award. What is new about time off in lieu? Some workers even like it. They can have a game of golf during the week or something. Some workers even like it. But it is condemned by this government; it is condemned over there.
—You have reduced the pay in the first instance.

—Yes, but by completing the work in four days you have got another day up your sleeve in which you can earn another $100. However, under the award system, if you spread it over the five days, you cannot do that; you cannot go out and earn another $100. So you are a mile behind. You also cannot spend some time with your family or have a game of golf. That is what Senator Evans said last night.

PARA.TAB: Senator Evans went on to talk about doctors' certificates. Employers ask for doctors' certificates. Can you tell me anything about honesty in the workplace? Is there anything wrong with providing a doctor's certificate if you are sick? Is there anything wrong with that? Sick pay is there for when you are sick and cannot attend work. But these fellas over there want the right to be able to take sickies whether they are sick or not. That is what they want. There is nothing wrong with a doctor's certificate. Senator Evans told us another mistruth last night when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: John Howard has endorsed the WA principles and the WA industrial relations approach.

That is another mistruth because John Howard has not commented on it whatsoever. John Howard, when the election is called, will bring down our industrial relations policy. That is what he will do. That is when you will see it. So it is a total mistruth by Senator Chris Evans to say something like that.

PARA.TAB: May I turn to an article in the Record newspaper, the Catholic newspaper of Western Australia, on 19 October 1995. It is an article by Father Cappo. It is no secret that Father Cappo was not a friend of ours at the last election. In fact, I rang him up and threatened to kneecap him if he carried on like that any further. Ring him up and find out. I spoke to him at length about what he had to say during the last election. However, this is what he had to say on this one—

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. I think that Senator Panizza's threat to kneecap Father Cappo is one of the most appalling statements that the Senate has heard. I think he should withdraw that sort of abusive threat that he just threw across the chamber about Father Cappo.

—I am advised that there is no technical point of order. However, I do think that making that claim and using violent language is inappropriate in this chamber and that we should, as senators, be considering our language.

—If it offends anyone, I withdraw. It was a throwaway line. I do not think there is too much to worry about. I heard other threats earlier in the day but they were not picked up. We will leave it at that. This is what the article had to say:

SPEECH.PARA: The national director of the Australian Catholic Social Welfare Commission, Father David Cappo, has described many of the industrial relations principles espoused by the Federal Coalition as `good and just', saying that the Commission would be prepared to work with the Coalition towards ensuring that the principles were developed into concrete policies.

PARA.TAB: Fr Cappo was speaking to The Record following a meeting between himself, Coalition industrial relations spokesman Peter Reith, Liberal Party federal director Andrew Robb, and Coalition employment, training and family services spokesman, Dr David Kemp.

`The principles that Mr Reith put forward are good and just principles regarding industrial relations. As I've said to Mr Reith, now we would be more than happy to work towards influencing the policy development'.

SPEECH.PARA: This is from a person who attacked us during the last election. People know what to expect to see from us at the next election and they are quite happy. The article goes on:

The meeting between Fr Cappo and the Liberal Party heavyweights followed comments made by Fr Cappo on ABC Radio's PM program last week in which he called for Coalition industrial relations policy to be `put on the table' and for assurances on the `no-disadvantage' test (the test that workers moving from awards-based work arrangements to enterprise agreements not be disadvantaged).

PARA.TAB: `The "no-disadvantage" test is crucial and it's in that area that I would like to have further dialogue with Mr Reith,' Fr Cappo said.
Fr Cappo also said that Coalition welfare was also significant.

SPEECH.PARA: He went on to say many good things about his discussions with Mr Howard and Mr Reith. This crowd over here—these ill-informed senators—are always saying to us, `Where is your industrial relations policy?' and `Where is your tax policy?' Where is the government's industrial relations policy? Where is the government's tax policy? All we get is scare tactics, scare tactics, scare tactics. That is all that those opposite have. The government said a few weeks ago that it would run on its record. I am very happy to let the government run on its record. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is worth while coming back to Senator Crane's motion before the Senate and restating what the government missed in the debate and failed to address. Senator Crane notes that when the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Beazley) was launching the very misleading advertisements in Western Australia he said that the Court Liberal government had set the minimum weekly wage at $317.10. He failed to add that when the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) was Premier of Western Australia between 1991 and 1992 the minimum weekly wage was $268.80; and, further, that wage rates in a series of federal awards which are under the direct responsibility of the Keating government are significantly below the Western Australian state minimum. That is what we are debating today.

PARA.TAB: I support my colleagues on this motion because, in essence, it goes to the heart of the government's utter misrepresentation of the coalition's industrial relations intentions. The government has been desperate to whip up some sort of fear campaign in Western Australia in the same way as the Queensland Goss government did at the last Queensland election. That attempt fell flat. The federal government has been desperate to peg back the gap in the polls before Christmas. The government knows that if the gap in the polls holds until Christmas it is finished as a government.

As evidence of the failure of that Western Australian blockade, there was nothing more pitiful than the most pathetic address of the head of the ACTU, Jennie George, before only 200 demonstrators on the day of the blockade. I think that said it all. The workers did not come out to support the union- and government-led blockade.

Is it little wonder that union membership is at crisis level? It is now only 35 per cent of the work force. If you take out the Public Service—some 60 per cent of the Public Service is unionised—only 25 per cent of workers in this country are members of a union.

You only have to look at the Asahi case as evidence that the non-union workers of Australia really do want to have the opportunity to negotiate directly with their employers. The unions should know that one of the main reasons they have had such a fall in union membership is that Australian workers feel so alienated from their union heads and bosses. They feel left out of any of the benefits that the union bosses seem to be getting. Many of them happen to get the benefits of a term in the parliament, jobs on government boards or direct grants to their union offices. There have been some $100 million in direct grants to unions by this government in the last 10 or so years—$16 million in the last 12 months.

We only have to look to the last week or two to see one of the best reasons workers feel so alienated from their unions. That came from one of the most prominent union bosses, Mr Bill Kelty. The integrity of the union superannuation funds was put at risk because Mr Bill Kelty sought to intimidate, if not blackmail, the AMP Society with regard to union superannuation funds. It had nothing to do with the daily lives of the workers; it had nothing to do with their welfare. It had more to do with the board dispute at Coles Myer.

I think the first mistakes of the union movement were made in around 1987 when they started to introduce the plan to reconstruct the unions to the point where they would have only some 20 major unions. That was a Kelty plan also, entitled Future strategies for the trade union movement. I think that went hand in hand with another document called Australia Reconstructed. The government gave them some $40 million to introduce that plan for superunions. History shows that that has been an utter failure because it has further alienated workers. In fact, the amalgamation of many of these unions has really been not to the benefit of the workers or for the care of the workers but for simple power plays and factional plays within the unions.

The workers feel even more alienated when they see the stronger unions that have come about because of these amalgamations, like the Transport Workers Union. They have been able to grab greater pay rises outside the government's much-loved Accord. The Transport Workers Union recently won a 15 per cent pay rise. This has had a cascading effect on workers in other industries. In fact, it has put them at a great disadvantage. In many respects, a protection racket is being run where the big, powerful unions are able to use their muscle to get huge pay rises to the detriment of workers in other industries. All of these costs, particularly in the Transport Workers Union, cascade throughout the economy.

The same is true for the Western Australian blockade. It never related to jobs or the welfare of the workers. It simply related to the empowering of the union. In fact, the industrial relations reforms brought in by the Court government had more to do with empowering the workers, if you look at some of the proposed changes, such as a form of secret ballots. That point, I hear today, is under negotiation.

Another proposed change is that workers will have the right to prevent expenditure of their membership fees on political donations. Why shouldn't they have that choice? It will be only a choice as they see fit. Employees can nominate their own superannuation fund, and union officials must adopt modern principles of financial accounting. What is wrong with that? Because it is all for the benefit of the workers.

This pattern of government interference in the industrial relations of this country and union bosses getting together, as they have in Western Australia, has flowed through to the Tweed Valley case, a well-known and publicised case. In this case, workers have successfully negotiated with their employer, on a one-on-one basis, to cash out their sick leave. I believe they did not cash out all their sick leave; it was only half or some three or four days—just a part of their sick leave entitlements. When you look at the details of this case, you will find that they were allowed to take the full sick leave, but some of the days were not on pay.

Because they were not taking their whole sick leave throughout the year, the workers decided to trade that off and to cash it out to have the advantage of something they were not receiving anyway. The government happened to think that was a very stupid idea. It treated the workers as if they were stupid and that they needed the union to tell them otherwise. This was the very basis of Labor's approach to the Tweed Valley case.

The government did not think the workers were bright enough to make their own decision. The example of this is on 26 September, when the Assistant Minister for Industrial Relations, Gary Johns, said on TV that the Tweed Valley workers `traded away their right to sickness leave. That's a stupidity. They shouldn't be doing that'. If they shouldn't be doing that, why hasn't the government interfered in other examples of enterprise bargaining where similar circumstances have arisen? The reason is that the Tweed Valley case was a political move by the government to try to highlight a fear campaign against the industrial relations intentions of the coalition.

It just so happens that those workers lost out where others haven't who have done the same thing because we are running close to an election and because this government now has become so desperate. There are several examples where sick leave has been traded out, as it has been in the Tweed Valley case. There are other examples, such as in meat workers union, where the government has interfered of late simply to beat up some sort—(Time expired)
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Crane's) be agreed to
Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: On 30 June 1995, the following matter was referred to the Committee of Privileges:

Having regard to the report of the Select Committee on Unresolved Whistleblower Cases on the alleged intimidation of a witness, whether there was any improper interference with a person who provided evidence to that committee on account of that evidence, and, if so, whether any contempt was committed by that improper interference.

The committee followed its normal practice of writing to the person who raised the matter with the select committee, Mr Peter Jesser, a senior lecturer in the Faculty of Business at the University of Southern Queensland, and to Professor Craig Littler, who was specifically mentioned in the report. The committee has received a submission from Mr Jesser, which it has attached as Appendix A to this report. Professor Littler sought further information from the committee before responding to its invitation to make a submission.

PARA.TAB: In the light of the committee's consideration of Mr Jesser's submission, however, the committee determined to make a finding that no contempt of the Senate has been committed. It therefore decided that it should report its finding to the Senate as quickly as possible to allay the concerns of people who might otherwise be involved.

The committee draws attention to the report tabled today by the Senate Select Committee on Unresolved Whistleblower Cases and in particular to volume 6 of the documents published with the report. The committee had access to the tabled documents in deliberating on the matter referred. Any senator who wishes to pursue the matter further may wish to consult those documents in which substantive responses to certain matters raised by Mr Jesser have been provided both by the University of Southern Queensland and by the department in which he is a senior lecturer. I do commend the report to the Senate. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.
