SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to draw the attention of the Senate and of this nation to the terrible plight of the long-term unemployed in this country. Today Senator Troeth and I, along with a number of other colleagues, planned to speak on this matter in a matter of public importance which, because of procedures of the Senate, did not come on this afternoon. I would just like to read what that matter of public importance was:

SPEECH.PARA: The appalling and entrenched levels of long-term unemployment and the failure of the Keating government to address this scourge that is crippling Australian society.

What we have, and what I would like to draw to people's attention, is a government here which is covering up what is happening with unemployment in this country, particularly the plight of the long-term unemployed. It is only when you have bodies like Senate committees that delve into matters in great depth do you find out what is really happening in this society.

PARA.TAB: Such an opportunity came to the Senate Employment, Education and Training References Committee when we conducted a series of hearings into long-term unemployment right around Australia. We had witnesses in every state and major regional areas of Australia that told us the real story about unemployment in this country which is at incredibly high levels. Don't believe the official rate: you have to more than double the official rate to get to the real rate of unemployment in this country. In reality, back in the depths of our recent recession, we had more than 20 per cent of the country unemployed—not only registered people but also people who were underemployed. In other words, they worked one or two days a week and still could not find enough work.

Out of this whole group, the greatest concern should be about the long-term unemployed, whose numbers have risen over the last 10 years to almost 30 per cent of the total unemployed in this country. This is a matter of enormous concern about which the committee took evidence right around the country. I would just like to provide the Senate with some of the flavour of what is going on out there. Witnesses before us made the following comments:

SPEECH.PARA: I feel abandoned by the system . . . exploited by the system—abused by the system—and held captive by the system.
In an area like Whyalla, people told us this: `We are sick and tired of training for training sake. We are disillusioned with training programs that are getting us nowhere.' Another witness said:
. . . participants in work experience programs . . . after six months of feeling really happy and that they are up and going, all of a sudden their placement ends . . . are dead in their tracks . . .
This is probably the most tragic comment of all:
. . . it is more comfortable to remain lying in the gutter than to be picked up and dropped back in it again.

This is the despair that is out there with the long-term unemployed people. What our committee did manage to uncover was the way in which this government is covering up the extent of the problem. That is of tremendous danger to our society, because if we hide this problem then the people in the community are going to think, `Well, it's not such a problem,' and therefore public policy will not be directed towards them. What we have developing in this country is a major underclass of people who have not had any work and do not have any prospect of having any work. There are in some areas of Australia up to three generations of people now who have never worked. That is a disgrace and a condemnation of this government's record.

PARA.TAB: But what has the government done about it? Yesterday, the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Mr Crean, came out and tried to tell us how well his programs under Working Nation were working. He was basing this on a report of the Department of Employment, Education and Training. Unfortunately, Senator Schacht, who answered my question in the Senate today, had not even bothered to look at this report and certainly had not even bothered to look at the minister's propaganda on this matter—at least he might have repeated that but he did not even do that. Let me read from the department's report how it says its programs are working, and I will read between the lines for you and tell you what it is really saying. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: There is a jobs compact and most people realise this is aimed at guaranteeing training and/or work to the long-term unemployed.

How many people are in this jobs compact? The report says that there was a fall in the number of jobs compact clients from more than 300,000 in July 1994 to 275,800 in July 1995. What a marvellous drop that is! I remind people that the height of the boom was from mid-1994 to mid-1995. During this boom they managed to get the figure down by 24,000 people—that is, less than 10 per cent—and they are trying to say that this was a great success!

PARA.TAB: One of the government's programs and strategies is case management. Let us look at how successful case management is. They were supposed to be moving a lot of case management into private contracting, to Employment Assistance Australia. How well has that been going over this period? There were 376,000 clients entering case management and 347,000 of those were with Employment Assistance Australia, which is the government body. The contracted case managers had only 29,500, according to that government report, which is less than 10 per cent. If you work that out across the whole of Australia by electorate, you find it is a minuscule number of people who have been put into this private case management system.

One of the major criticisms of our committee was the way in which the government was supposed to be implementing Working Nation and that is reflected in these figures. It is incredibly slow to get things under way. The government set up this program to solve the problems of the long-term unemployed that came out of the last recession. At the speed they are travelling with this, we will be into the next recession before anything starts to happen. Yet yesterday the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean) was trying to say, and it is in the press today, how marvellous it is. Let us listen to what Simon Crean had to say:
In its first year of operation, Working Nation has achieved very significant results and has established the framework for further substantial achievements. . .

SPEECH.PARA: What nonsense. That is not the case. That is not what his own department says. It is certainly not what we found out when we had our major inquiry. He went on to say:

PARA.TAB: Since the introduction of Working Nation, the seasonally adjusted unemployment rate had declined to 8.3 per cent . . .

SPEECH.PARA: He was talking about June 1995. I have news for the minister. The figures are out for this month and it is not June. It is now October and the figure is on the rise. Unemployment is on the rise in this country. And today we found out that inflation is on the rise. What we have is the double whammy, the double loss, which is rising inflation and rising unemployment. That is the real picture of what is happening in this country.

PARA.TAB: The government has not put in place programs to solve this problem. What they have done is called churning the dole queue. What that means, under its Working Nation program, is that people receive training and that is often combined with employment, which in principle is a good idea, but under the government training program this only works for six months. What happens at the end of six months? Our inquiry found that half of them do not get a job. What happens to that half? What happens is that they go back not onto the long-term list where they might have been for a few years with a whole lot of extra benefits and assistance but to the start of the queue. Those people have to wait for months to get any assistance. That is one of the major tragedies of the government's program. People whose self-esteem has risen lose that, and because they do not have the opportunities, they are less employable. That is one of the most negative outcomes of Working Nation.

Those people who are in that situation are taken off the long-term list. The government is trying to make out how fast long-term unemployment is coming down. A lot of it, as I indicated, is the churning of the queue. It is the failure of Working Nation. I am glad that the Senate now has a report which tells the true story to the people of Australia—that Working Nation is not working.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are three matters I want to address in the adjournment debate tonight. Firstly, I want to follow up on comments I made on Tuesday night of this week in the adjournment debate, when I got up and defended the Governor-General, His Excellency Bill Hayden, from some pretty severe attacks that were happening in sections of our media. I said this on that occasion:

SPEECH.PARA: I contend in this place and will contend publicly that whatever any public figure does when that public figure is on holidays is that individual's own business. If they choose to go off to Banff in Canada and have a relaxing holiday and stay at hotels reported to cost 1,500 bucks a night, that is their business; it is nobody else's business.
I went on to say:

PARA.TAB: I would defend the Governor-General's right to move to Vancouver, as was reported in the same paper on Monday of this week. He is reported to have stayed at a hotel in Vancouver costing $1,350 per night. The Governor-General, Mr Hayden, is reported to have said that he got that hotel for $800 a night. Good on him. If it saves him a quid, I am all for that too. I reiterate: it is nobody else's business what he does when he is on holiday.

SPEECH.PARA: They are the comments that are on the public record. It has been brought to my attention that it is our business, indeed everybody's business, what has gone on in Banff and Vancouver. It has been put to me that the bills that I have spoken about are, in fact, being picked up by the taxpayers of Australia. I have not immediately accepted those assertions. I have sought, by contacting the Governor-General's office, to get clarification of whether or not the taxpayers, through the credit cards issued at Government House, are paying for His Excellency Mr Hayden and his wife whilst they are on holidays in Canada. To date, I have not had a response to the query that went over to Government House yesterday.

PARA.TAB: If, in the next two weeks, the inquiry comes back and what has been put to me is confirmed—that, indeed, the taxpayers are paying these bills—I will, when this parliament returns or possibly even before it returns, during estimates committees, be asking that His Excellency pay those, what I consider to be, personal bills out of his own personal account. I do not think the taxpayers of Australia should pay for the holidays of governors-general or parliamentarians. I would hope that what I have been told since is not the case and, if it is the case, I hope it would be rectified.

The second matter I want to address is a matter of some good news and emanates from a memorandum of understanding which was signed between Australia and China on 25 January this year. Under the terms of that MOU, China agreed to the return and the continued protection of Sino-Vietnamese boat people who could confirm that they had been resettled as refugees in China after fleeing Vietnam in the 1970s and early 1980s.

More than 800 people arrived illegally in Australia late last year and early this year. I am very pleased to report to the Senate that this morning a seventh group—this time of 96 people who were covered by the MOU, and the largest group so far—flew out of Port Hedland bound for Nanning in southern China. They had arrived in Australia between November last year and March this year in six boats codenamed the Brolga, the Galah, the Heron, the Jabiru, the Kookaburra and the Nightingale. As was the case with all previous six departures, this flight left without incident, and arrangements have been made in China for their safe arrival. This latest flight brings to 465 the number of people returned under the agreement.

I am going to tempt fate by commending the fact that, since the first return of people back to China in May of this year, no other boats from that part of the world carrying illegals into Australia have descended on our shores. I hope I do not live to regret the recognition of that fact, but a fact indeed it is. Certainly that fact has something to do with the fact that we are returning people who arrive illegally on our shores.

The third matter that I want to address tonight relates to the locale where I will be tomorrow night: it is indeed wonderful Wanneroo in Western Australia. I want to refer to the editorial that appeared in our West Australian newspaper last Friday, 20 October. It was headed `Open up on Wanneroo, Mr Court'. I want to quote a small part of that editorial. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Openness and accountability seem to have become hollow words for the Court Government.

PARA.TAB: Although ministers are fond of bandying them about, they show no commitment to the principles the words convey. If they did, they would insist that the inquiry into what has become known as Wanneroo Inc was carried out with the full powers and privileges of a royal commission.
Premier Richard Court's rearguard action against moves to open the Kyle inquiry into the Wanneroo City Council can only reinforce the community perception that the Government has something to hide.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps what the government is seeking to hide is the matter contained under a headline in the Australian newspaper of yesterday, 25 October, entitled `Police told of $30,000 Wanneroo gift: MP'. The article commenced:

PARA.TAB: Police have been told that the West Australian Attorney-General, Ms Edwardes, received $30,000 in political donations from a corrupt mayor, the State Parliament was told yesterday.

SPEECH.PARA: Mrs Edwardes is reported in the body of the article as saying:
No, I am not aware of those allegations. I am aware though that Dr Bradshaw—
the former mayor, who is now in gaol—
has said that he had raised up to $30,000 over 10 years.
That is a surprising annunciation from the No. 1 law officer in Western Australia, Ms Cheryl Edwardes—a very surprising statement.

PARA.TAB: On June 7 last year in the West Australian newspaper a fairly large headline stated `Edwardes "got donations"'. The article, which appeared just over 12 months ago, stated that Dr Bradshaw had:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . publicly cut his friendship with Mrs Edwardes and Wanneroo MLA Wayde Smith and agreed that Mrs Edwardes had received at least $30,000 in campaign funds through his efforts.
The article continued:

PARA.TAB: Dr Bradshaw said that part of a $15,000 donation he sought in January 1989 went to Mrs Edwardes's State election campaign.

SPEECH.PARA: That is there in the public arena in the one and only daily newspaper that we have in Western Australian. Yet the attorney, the first law officer of the state of Western Australia, gets up in the state parliament and denies that she is aware of the allegation. I suggest that there is something not at all wholesome happening in my state of Western Australia as it relates to Wanneroo.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. Senator McKiernan, an acting deputy president himself, knows that it is contrary to standing orders to reflect upon a member of any parliament. Ms Cheryl Edwardes is a member of the state parliament of Western Australia, and she is the Attorney-General. She has vigorously and quite properly denied any wrongdoing or receiving gifts of the nature outlined by Senator McKiernan. What Senator McKiernan is doing, with the greatest respect, is regurgitating and recycling untruths for political advantage. It is my view that he ought not be able to proceed any further in his attack upon Mrs Edwardes and in his reflection upon her integrity not only as a member of parliament but also as the Attorney-General of Western Australia.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—I was not sufficiently aware that Senator McKiernan was referring to that member of parliament. If he was, I would ask him to take that into account.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think I was. I think the matter can be completely cleared up by opening up the inquiry in the way that the West Australian editorial that I spoke of before suggested. Give it the powers of a royal commission. Allow individuals to give evidence. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Troeth Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also wish to comment on the Senate Employment, Education and Training Committee's long-term unemployment report which was released today and the government claim in their more recent publication Shaping the nation that Australia is leading the OECD in the generation of new jobs. In the report that was released today we were reminded that the unemployment rate in Australia was two per cent higher than the OECD average for the period 1973 to 1992.

PARA.TAB: The government claims that since April 1993 employment growth has led to 670,000 new jobs. In fact, the recent recession destroyed 337,300 jobs, and the number of unemployed people still exceeds the worst figures at the peak of the recession in the early 1980s. The incidence of long-term unemployment at 30 per cent in Australia is much worse than the rate of approximately 15 per cent in Japan and 12 per cent in the United States. So the government's claim that its programs are having a significant impact is simply not true.

Last week's ABS figures showed that long-term unemployment had increased in the previous month, up 6,600 to a total of 237,700, and long-term unemployment as a proportion of total unemployment rose from 30.7 per cent to 31.1 per cent. Unemployment is unwelcome, whatever its duration, but long-term unemployment has particularly disturbing ramifications.

A recent report by the Brotherhood of St Laurence entitled Unequal lives—low income and the life chances of three year olds talks about the growing divide between those families with children who have no parent in paid work and those who have two parents in a job. The report states:
In the long term this polarisation has the potential to produce markedly unequal life chances for children and reduce social cohesion.

SPEECH.PARA: Australian studies show that there is a relationship between low parental income, a low level of educational attainment and long-term unemployment.

PARA.TAB: The Brotherhood of St Laurence report showed some disturbing detrimental effects on children brought up in low income families. They were more likely to have their health rated as fair rather than excellent by their mothers; they were more likely to have mothers that said they were having problems managing the child; they were facing multiple stresses such as serious disagreements with their partner—the mother or the father—serious financial problems and serious housing problems; and they were less likely to be satisfied with their local area as a good place to bring up young children.

Similarly, the report tabled by the Senate committee today described, on page 3, young people `who were slipping between the cracks of society . . . spending days and weeks watching TV, sleeping and withdrawing from society'.

Both in suburban and regional Australia, unemployment has become endemic in some areas. By the middle of 1994 there were 703,900 children aged between 0 and 14 years growing up in families where no parent was employed. The parents of more than half of those children, 448,200, were not in the labour force. Most were single parents, predominantly women, with caring responsibilities. In these areas, both in suburban and regional Australia, national programs must be tailored to the needs of those regions in order for them to have any chance of being effective. A program which will work in Tweed Heads may not necessarily work in Burnie.

I have mentioned training programs. Let us look at some of those training programs and their outcomes. One of the programs specifically targeted to indigenous people is the community development employment project. The evidence put to the committee suggests that opinion in the Aboriginal community is divided about the benefits of the scheme. One indigenous witness told the committee:

SPEECH.PARA: It—
meaning the CDEP—
is also a way of disguising unemployment figures in terms of Aboriginal people.

That witness also contended that the CDEP failed to provide adequate training for future employment. The figures that I am about to quote relate to the status of clients about three months after program assistance had ended—that is, after they had been through a labour market training program. In regard to Aboriginal employment, 57.3 per cent were still unemployed three months after program assistance had ended; in jobtrain, 63.4 per cent were still unemployed; in job clubs, 59.4 per cent were still unemployed; in jobskills, 60.3 per cent were still unemployed; and, in the environmental program LEAP, 60.7 per cent were still unemployed. Even the most successful of these programs, jobstart, had a rate of 37.6 per cent unemployment three months after completion, so these programs simply are not working.

PARA.TAB: If we look at the numbers of those in what is called continuing program assistance, the figures are even more interesting. For those who are uninitiated in DEETspeak, continuing program assistance means that people are in another training program three months after finishing the first one. Of these people—that is, those who have gone on to the second training program—48.2 per cent reappear in the office of labour market assistance; 30.1 per cent reappear in jobtrain; 27.4 per cent reappear in Aboriginal employment; 29.8 per cent in job clubs; and 19.1 per cent in LEAP. This is a damning indictment of what the government chooses to call a successful program to look after the interests of the unemployed.

A more cynical person than I would suggest that the plethora of training programs that are starting now—at the end of October 1995—are being used to remove people from unemployment lists in the lead-up to the election. The unemployment problem, it could be suggested, has been overtaken by the blatant desire of this government to be re-elected.

Another criticism of Working Nation that my colleague Senator Tierney made is the fact that restricted access to labour market programs is, in itself, creating a class of long-term unemployed. Being a long-term unemployed is a barrier to obtaining employment, because employers are not so anxious to take those people on.

What has been the impact of this extended period of unemployment Australia has endured? Between 1976 and 1981 in the least affluent five per cent of neighbourhoods, average household incomes fell by over $7,000 in absolute terms, and the income gap between the top and bottom five per cent of neighbourhoods almost doubled to over $20,000.

A recent international study by the Joseph Rowntree Foundation ranked Australia fourth behind Norway, New Zealand and Britain in the growth of inequality in the 13 years from 1979 to 1992. At the heart of this inequity has been the inadequate growth of jobs since the 1970s and this government's failure to adequately tackle the problem of unemployment. The government have often quoted their version of the social wage based on models created by the National Centre for Social and Economic Modelling. I will quote from an article written recently by Petro Georgiou, my colleague in the other place. He wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: These models allocate total State and Federal expenditure on health, education and housing to different household types, according to how much they are estimated to use government services. The models—
that is, those used by the government—

indicate that the lowest income groups get the most benefit from the social wage. The problem with the NATSEM models is that they do not use actual incomes, but constructed hypothetical, equivalent incomes.

When the actual incomes people receive are used, Labor's claim that the social wage is progressive is a sham. On the basis of actual incomes, the lowest earning 40 per cent of households receive 35.5 per cent of the money spent on the social wage, and the top earning 40 per cent of households receive 46.6 per cent.

PARA.TAB: The government calculates the real increase in the social wage since 1983 as $736 for every Australian. This of course comes nowhere near the $7,000 absolute decline in household incomes in the poorest five per cent of neighbourhoods. This government likes to talk about the $2.2 billion it spent on Working Nation but, when all this rhetoric is laid aside, the government cannot escape the fact that there are still over 763,100 people classified as unemployed; and the long-term unemployed make up over one-third of that total.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to share some thoughts on what I believe is an extremely significant change in community values in relation to the destruction of our ecologically precious old-growth forests. On Sunday, 8 October, St Francis Day, I was privileged to participate in an Earth Day mass at Christchurch, Claremont in my home state. It was an occasion of celebration, reverence for life and joy in which parishioners brought their animal family members for blessing and focused on our mutual needs to love and care for the earth.

PARA.TAB: I am sure this was not the only St Francis Day celebration of this kind. I would like to draw my colleagues' attention to another gathering on Sunday, 8 October in Sydney, where a group of people from different churches called Christians for the Environment held a service called the `Celebration of the Gift of the Forest', choosing Lane Cove Valley because it was the first logging site in Sydney.

Church leaders and groups involved in Christians for the Environment are concerned about the fate of our forests and see responsibility for the environment as fundamental to their faith. I quote from a letter to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) that they have written:

SPEECH.PARA: Christians everywhere are beginning to become aware of their responsibility for the restoration of God's creation and the need to actively support these issues.

Christians for the Environment called on the Prime Minister to ensure that the government clearly acts to reform forest industry and provide protection for the full range of conservation values of Australia's forests. Because I know time is short and I want to give Senator Woodley a chance to speak, I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard at this point in my speech a statement from Christians for the Environment—I have shown it to members on both sides of the chamber.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: A STATEMENT FROM
Christians for the Environment
OCTOBER 7TH 1995
CHURCHES SPEAK OUT
WE NEED TO PRESERVE BIODIVERSITY

PARA.TAB: Churches are speaking out and supporting the preservation of all old growth forests and wilderness areas at a worship service to be held 2pm at the Naamaroo Conference centre, Lane Cove, October 8th. Biodiversity is a critical aspect of a healthy environment. These old growth forest and wilderness areas must therefore be preserved for the present and future well-being of all creation.

There is a spiritual dimension to the forests, as well as a biological, social and economic one. The political agenda must take this spirituality on board: we must value God's creation appropriately. Forests are a vital part of this creation and of its ongoing sustainability.

The inter relatedness of healthy forests and life—including human life—on this planet is testimony to the fact that forests are more than gifts from God for human beings to exploit. Our God-given human calling is to work responsibly with the rest of creation for human well being. But human well being in the long term is integrally related to the correct, sustainable use of God given forest resources.

Christian faith suggests that we are to work with God for the redemption of the whole world. Theologically and socially we argue that it is vital for us to nurture existing native forests and their biodiversity in order to work for a sustainable life style. The destruction of forests has an impact beyond the immediate areas where logging has taken place. The loss of old growth forests and wilderness areas means a loss to a whole diverse ecosystem of which human beings are a part. Loss of forests is a loss to this whole community of living things.

The churches along with other groups have a role to play in reminding society of the giftedness of the forests and so to make a commitment to responsible management of these forests and wilderness areas. The current harvesting of old growth forests and wilderness areas is unsustainable. As whole ecosystems Forests must be nurtured and conserved rather than exploited and destroyed or reduced in size and potential. We seriously question selective logging given the importance of forest biodiversity. Wood production and supply must be taken from plantations. This is particularly so in relation to wood chips. Nothing to our mind represents the utter exploitation and devastation of the God given ecosystems more than wood chipping.

We recognise that it is also necessary to provide support for forest workers where restructuring in the logging industry is necessary to maintain a creative sustainability. In any restructuring of the forest industry we, the churches, must commit ourselves to the support of people and communities whose lives currently depend on the forests for a living. We are indebted to their work for gifting us with wood products and for contributing to the life style we enjoy. The necessary restructuring of the forest industry must be undertaken with compassion and understanding for those engaged in the industry. Forest workers must not be the only group within our society to carry the weight of the necessary restructuring of the forest industry if we are to maintain our commitment to creation.
We applaud the attempts being made by the Commonwealth government to undertake

SPEECH.PARA: a process of consultation. But heritage forests are still at risk.

PARA.TAB: We are very concerned about particular issues raised by conservation groups. For example, we are very concerned that State forest agencies have hidden the real extent of old growth forests, and that some have excluded particular types of forest from the DFA'S. The Commonwealth government's DFA plan to create a breathing space has been undermined by State governments and their forest agencies. We also support the need for States to create reserves which follow ecologically meaningful boundaries. Such reserves must preserve their biodiversity. Ecologically sustainable management practices must be encouraged.

SPEECH.PARA: This statement is supported by:- New South Wales Ecumenical Council, The Uniting Church of Australia, The Sydney Anglican Social Issues Committee, The Catholic Church

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I believe it is an indication that a very significant threshold has been reached and is marked by services like the two I have mentioned and also by calls from churches and church leaders across all denominations. An example is the statement I have just incorporated. It is like an open letter which has been sent to the major political parties from religious leaders, calling for a stop to all logging of old-growth forest.

PARA.TAB: The letter also expresses concern for those people in woodchip producing communities and states that Christian social justice demands that the wider community, governments and woodchip exporters look to the needs of those involved in this activity. It is a most beautiful and moving statement. I would love to read it out, but I will seek leave at the end of my remarks to have it incorporated in Hansard. I believe it marks the point where concern on this issue transcends not only church boundaries, but also the boundaries of political parties.

I often make the statement that politicians are not leaders in the community; we follow the lead of the community. I believe the community is making a call to all politicians who may be involved in the decision making processes that are leading to the inevitable destruction and loss of our precious old-growth forests and the rare and endangered species within them. I urge that we be obedient to the call and be led by the community, instead of leading it down a path of destruction. I seek leave to have incorporated an open letter to both major political parties from religious leaders. The letter includes their names.
Leave granted.

PARA.EMPHASIS: An Open Letter to Both Major Political Parties from Religious Leaders

PARA.TAB: Christians have always believed that the natural world is God's creation and that its beauty and complexity mirror God's splendour. To destroy irresponsibly the natural world, for whatever purpose, is to distort one of our most precious images of God.

In the past in Australia, through ignorance of the ecological complexity of our country, and through greed, we have already destroyed much of our natural inheritance. However, with better knowledge and a heightened ecological sense, we have no ethical justification whatsoever to continue destroying the natural world and distorting the creation of God.

It is clear to us that Australia's old growth forests are both ecologically precious and of great natural beauty. They also are home to rare and endangered species. As such, they mirror the creativity of God.

Therefore to continue to log them, for whatever purpose, must be considered ethically and even morally wrong. The text of the Book of Genesis, often referred to by those seeking to justify such destruction [`be fruitful and multiply, and fill the earth and subdue it; and have dominion' (Gen 1:28)], does not grant to humans the right to exploit, let alone to destroy, God's creation. To use the text to justify environmental destruction is a fundamentalist misreading of the text.

We make this statement fully aware of the implication for woodchipping producing communities and of Australia's export demands. Certainly, `Christian social justice demands that the wider community, governments and woodchip exporters look to the needs of those involved in this activity'. However, we accept the clear scientific and economic evidence that we already have in Australia plantations of both soft and hardwood timbers well in excess of our present needs. We also accept the fact that the plantation industry is able to provide more employment and jobs than those provided by the logging of old growth forests for woodchip export.

We therefore call on both political parties to confront this issue. Governments face a moral and ethical demand that they stop all logging of old growth forests on both private but especially on public land. There is simply no economic justification for this to continue in the face of our ethical obligations to protect the natural world. To continue such activities irresponsibly would be sinful.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the report of the Senate Select Committee on Unresolved Whistleblower Cases, which was handed down today in the Senate. I will make a few comments in the few minutes available to me, and in the weeks ahead if that is possible. This is a very cautious report. It certainly follows some very narrow terms of reference, which we were given. Those terms of reference were negotiated very carefully, and it was important that they be agreed to by the parties. For that reason, I certainly supported those terms of reference and have agreed with this report to the need for it to be unanimous. We certainly achieved that.

PARA.TAB: I underline that it is a cautious report. I will give a couple of examples. On one of the critical issues, which is the shredding of the Heiner documents in Queensland, the committee says:

SPEECH.PARA: With the benefit of hindsight, the Committee considers that the shredding of the Heiner documents may have been an exercise in poor judgment. Greater consideration ought to have been given to alternative approaches to resolving the problems associated with the inquiry. In particular, the Committee considers more heed should have been given to the `Crown as a model litigant' notion: it might have been more appropriate for the Queensland Government to have retained the documents for a certain period to allow for their production, if required, in legal action.

That is a criticism of the Queensland government—cautious, nevertheless a criticism. I wanted to press some stronger words than that on the committee. That was prompted by the findings and advice of Callinan QC, who, in a letter which has been released and published by the committee, quite clearly pointed out that sections 129 and 119 of the criminal justice code in Queensland clearly indicate that the shredding of documents in this kind of event may be a criminal act. Callinan made no judgment on that because obviously that would need to be tested in a court. But he does say:

It is evident from all of the above that the Criminal Justice Commission has not given serious attention to the implications of destroying documents knowingly in order to avoid or render more difficult litigation. They have ignored these serious matters. Arguably relevant provisions are as follows.
After quoting from the criminal code, he goes on to say:

Again the Criminal Justice Commission's narrow/strict interpretation of `judicial proceeding' is too significant to ignore. There are now clear compelling reasons for these matters to be investigated comprehensively. Mr Barnes made findings of fact which were not based on all of the relevant documentation.

There is a lot more to that. I personally agree with Callinan's opinion and with the opinion of Neil Turner, a National Party MP from Queensland who was very critical of the CJC's performance, particularly in this matter. When I have more time, I will read into the record what he said in a dissenting report, because I believe that what he said is accurate.

PARA.TAB: Some of the documentation presented to this committee was so critical. Although the Senate is not a court—we need to underline that—and it was unable to do very much beyond hearing the evidence and commenting upon it, all of the cases before us clearly require extensive and further investigation and arbitration. Perhaps the most critical document

SPEECH.PARA: ation are the submissions of Robert Butler. I believe that there has been an abuse of power by the CJC. I believe it needs to be far more accountable than it has been. Perhaps the way to obtain such accountability is for Queensland to have a Senate.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Broadcasting Authority (ABA) has advised the following:

PARA.TAB: (i) Projected staffing levels are set out in the attached table. In addition to the staffing identified in that table, four statutory office holders (three full time and one part time) are employed at equivalent SES Band 3 levels and there is one Associate Member for which the ABA does not contribute any salary costs.

(ii) The general work level standards for all Australian Public Service classifications are overseen by the Department of Finance. Functions and activities of staff are consistent with these standards and are directed towards fulfilling the functions of the ABA.
The primary functions of the ABA are set out in section 158 of the Broadcasting Services Act 1992. These functions may be summarised as follows:

(a) to provide advice to the Spectrum Management Agency in relation to the spectrum plan and frequency band plans under the Radiocommunications Act 1992 and the designation of bands for broadcasting purposes;
(b) to plan the availability of segments of the broadcasting services bands on an area basis;
(c) to allocate, renew, suspend and cancel licences and to take other enforcement action under the Act;
(d) to conduct investigations or hearings relating to the allocating of licences for community radio and community television services;
(e) to design and administer price-based systems for the allocation of commercial television broadcasting licences and commercial radio broadcasting licences;
(f) to collect any fees payable in respect of licences;
(g) to conduct or commission research into community attitudes on issues relating to programs;
(h) to assist broadcasting service providers to develop codes of practice that, as far as possible, are in accordance with community standards;
(i) to monitor compliance with those codes of practice;
(j) to develop program standards relating to broadcasting in Australia;
(k) to monitor compliance with those standards;
(l) to monitor and investigate complaints concerning broadcasting services (including national broadcasting services);
(m) to inform itself and advise the Minister on technological advances and service trends in the broadcasting industry; and
(n) to monitor, and to report to the Minister on, the operation of the Act.

In addition, the ABA has other functions under the Act and other legislation. These include giving opinions concerning the category to which broadcasting services belong, and determining additional, or clarifying existing, criteria for those categories; giving opinions on whether a person is in a position to exercise control of a licence, company or newspaper; and administering aspects of the ownership and control rules applying to certain categories of licences.
For the purpose of exercising its powers and functions under the Act, the Authority is obliged to take account of:
the objects of the Act and the regulatory policy set out in the Act;
any general policies of the Government notified to the ABA by the Minister;
any directions given to the ABA by the Minister; and
Australia's obligations under any convention to which Australia is a party or any agreement between Australia and a foreign country.

The Australian Telecommunications Authorities (AUSTEL) Mission is to facilitate an open, fair and competitive communications environment for Australia, enabling provision of world class facilities and services. AUSTEL is managed by a Board and is organised into six branches carrying out the following functions and activities:

ANSWER.PARA: Consumer Affairs Branch—To promote and protect the interests of consumers concerning the provision of, and access to, telecommunications services and facilities in a fair, efficient and equitable manner.

Carrier Monitoring Unit—To monitor and report on the carriers' performance in the operation of their networks, delivery of service and treatment of their customers, and to promote carrier competition through informed customer choice.
Industry Affairs Branch—To promote the development of a competitive and equitable environment so ensuring that the benefits of competition are realised by consumers.

Technical Standards Branch—To ensure the safety and technical quality of Australian telecommunications services and equipment and cabling and to provide the maximum opportunity for Australian industry participation in the local and global telecommunications market, and maximise industry competition and consumer choice.
Technical Regulation Branch—To provide advice and the regulatory processes that contribute to AUSTEL's corporate goals in technical regulation and law enforcement.
Corporate Resources Branch—Timely, responsive and cost effective corporate management and support in partnership with operational branches to enable AUSTEL to achieve its mission.

PARA.TAB: 5. How much will the Commonwealth contribute to the ITU in 1995-96? What will be the source or sources of this contribution? What contributions will the carriers make to funding of the Commonwealth's contribution to the ITU in 1995-96?

ANSWER.PARA: The contribution to the International Telecommunications Union in 1995/96 is estimated to be 4.950 million Swiss Francs. Based on an exchange rate at 3 April 1995 of $A0.8223 per Swiss Franc, the 1995/96 budget shows a contribution of $6.012 million. As at 3 July 1995 the contribution is $6.19 million. The exact sum to be paid will depend on the exchange rate between the Australian dollar and the Swiss Franc, at the time of payment. The International Telecommunications Union's budget covers the activities of its Radiocommunication, Telecommunication Standardisation and Telecommunication Sectors.
The contribution is paid from appropriations to the Department of Communications and the Arts.

1995/96 carrier licence fees will increase to the extent necessary to recover the `Telecommunication Standardisation' component of Australia's International Telecommunications Union contribution. That component (estimated at $1.48 million) represents 24 per cent of Australia's contribution, and will be recovered from carriers on the same proportional sharing basis as for the 1995/96 carrier licence fees, ie. in proportion to their 1994/95 shares of the total timed traffic.
In addition, 43 per cent of Australia's contribution is attributed to the `Radiocommunication' component and is recovered through radiocommunications licence fees.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, upon notice, on 25 September 1995:

PARA.TAB: How much did the department spend on domestic air travel in the 1985-86, 1986-87, 1987-88, 1988-89, 1992-93 and 1994-95 financial years.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission has provided the Minister of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs with the following information in response to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: The Commission did not come into existence until March 1990. To obtain the information on predecessor organisations would involve the Commission in considerable research, and I am not prepared to authorise the time and resources entailed in collecting the information. It is likely in any case that expenditure records prior to 1988-89 have been destroyed as permitted under the Archives Act 1983.
Details in respect of 1992-93 and 1994-95 are as follows:

ATSIC at all times attempts to minimise administrative expenditure, including expenditure on domestic air travel in order to provide the maximum financial assistance for programs for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians.

ATSIC's travel expenditure, however, must be considered against the nature of the agency. Elected representatives are required to travel regularly to Regional Council meetings, and often air travel is the only practical alternative. ATSIC Commissioners represent zones across Australia, and must travel to all Commission meetings. Much of the travel for ATSIC staff is to rural and remote Australia, at times involving travel by chartered aircraft, and such travel is disproportionately more expensive than business travel to Australian capital cities.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 28 September 1995:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the decision of the full Federal Court involving the salvage of an oil tanker and the assessability of that income, can an assurance be given that prizes won on radio and television programs will not be subject to income tax, except in circumstances where the winner could be deemed to be a professional entertainer.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: The Commissioner of Taxation has responsibility for administration of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936.

The Commissioner issued a media release on 28 September 1995 which addresses the concerns raised in recent media reports about the application of the principles in FC of T v Holmes 95 ATC 4476 (referred to as Holmes' case and sometimes the Kirki case).

The Commissioner has confirmed that the Australian Taxation Office has no intention of changing its `tax-free' policy toward taxpayers who win competitions, lotteries or by occasionally placing a bet. People who participate casually in a competition and win a prize are not liable to tax on their winnings.

People who make a living out of appearance fees and winnings on game shows or who are professional punters may, however, be subject to income tax. Broadly, the only time a prize is treated as assessable income is where it has been earned as a result of the work the taxpayer does.

PARA.TAB: (1)(a) With regard to points (i) and (iii), the Department does not maintain centralised records identifying staff who were overseas born or who are able to speak one or more languages other than English.

(ii) The term `people of a non-English speaking background' (NESB) is used in the PSC EEO Program Guidelines to describe persons who have migrated to Australia and whose first language is a language other than English, and the children of such persons.

In EEO statistics for the APS, NESB staff are classified as either NESB1 (first generation) or NESB2 (second generation). Most people who were born overseas and whose first language was not English are classified as NESB1. Those who arrived in Australia before the age of five are classified as NESB2, along with Australian-born people with parents of NESB.

Consolidated statistical records of such persons who are permanent employees of the department of Human Services and Health are maintained on the NOMAD automated personnel system. The records are derived from information voluntarily supplied by permanent staff of the Department who elect to self identify as being a person of a non-English speaking background by completing an EEO Record.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 31 August 1995 (Hansard page 813) Senator Watson asked me the following question without notice:

PARA.TAB: Approximately two years ago the government gave a guarantee or an assurance that the Reserve Bank would act as a lender of last resort to an Australian bank which was subject to a run on its deposit base as a result of depositors withdrawing a high percentage of their funds from that bank. Since that time there have been certain suggestions that that protection may be somewhat qualified support. Can the minister confirm that the Reserve Bank still has an unequivocal policy and resolve of acting as lender of last resort to all Australian trading and savings banks?
The Treasurer has provided the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

There is no formal guarantee of bank deposits in Australia by the Reserve Bank. However, the Banking Act 1959 places a duty on the Reserve Bank to use its powers for the protection of depositors of all banks authorised under the Act. To this end, the Reserve Bank closely monitors the operations of banks to see that they adhere to sound management practices and comply with various prudential requirements.
The Banking Act also contains some specific provisions to protect the position of depositors. In particular, if a bank appears likely to be unable to

ANSWER.PARA: meet its obligations, the Reserve Bank has the power to investigate its affairs and, if necessary, to assume control and manage the bank until such time as its depositors are repaid. In addition, the Act provides that the assets of a bank in Australia be available to meet its deposit liabilities in Australia in priority to all its other liabilities.

PARA.TAB: Banks in Australia do not have an automatic right of access to loans from the Reserve Bank in the event of a liquidity shortfall. Management of each bank's liquidity is the responsibility of the bank itself.

However, if an otherwise soundly managed bank were to experience liquidity difficulties, the Reserve Bank is able, at its discretion, to make support available. Any such support would be considered against the need to maintain stability and confidence in the financial system generally.
There have been no recent changes in any of these arrangements.
